question:
Question 1 A heat pump, operating in reversed Carnot cycle, maintains a steady air temperature
of 300 K inside an auditorium. The heat pump receives heat from the ambient air.
The ambient air temperature is 280 K. Heat loss from the auditorium is 15 kW. The
power consumption of the heat pump is __________ kW (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given: Inside temperature (hot reservoir), [latex] T_H = 300 \text{ K} [/latex] Ambient temperature (cold reservoir), [latex] T_C = 280 \text{ K} [/latex] Heat loss from auditorium = Heat supplied by heat pump = [latex] Q_H = 15 \text{ kW} [/latex] Step 1: Coefficient of performance (COP) of a Carnot heat pump: [latex] COP_{HP} = \frac{T_H}{T_H - T_C} = \frac{300}{300 - 280} = \frac{300}{20} = 15 [/latex] Step 2: Power consumption of heat pump: [latex] COP_{HP} = \frac{Q_H}{W} \Rightarrow W = \frac{Q_H}{COP_{HP}} = \frac{15}{15} = 1 \text{ kW} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{1.00 \text{ kW}} [/latex]

question:
Question 2 A thermodynamically closed system contains 1 kg of hydrogen. The system
undergoes a reversible polytropic process with polytropic index 1.3. The work
output during the process is 400 kJ. During the process, hydrogen behaves as an
ideal gas with constant specific heats. The absolute value of heat transfer during the
process is __________ kJ (rounded off to 1 decimal place). Specific heat of hydrogen at constant pressure [latex] = 14.56  kJ \; kg^{-1} K^{-1} [/latex] Specific heat of hydrogen at constant volume [latex] = 10.4  kJ\; kg^{-1} K^{-1} [/latex]
solution: Given: Polytropic process with index [latex] n = 1.3 [/latex] Work output, [latex] W = 400 \text{ kJ} [/latex] [latex] m = 1 \text{ kg} [/latex] [latex] C_p = 14.56 \text{ kJ/kg·K}, \quad C_v = 10.4 \text{ kJ/kg·K} [/latex] Step 1: Use the formula for heat transfer in a polytropic process: [latex] Q = \frac{n - \gamma}{\gamma - 1} \cdot W [/latex] Where [latex] \gamma = \frac{C_p}{C_v} = \frac{14.56}{10.4} = 1.4 [/latex] Step 2: Substitute the values: [latex] Q = \frac{1.3 - 1.4}{1.4 - 1} \cdot 400 [/latex] [latex] Q = \frac{-0.1}{0.4} \cdot 400 = -100 \text{ kJ} [/latex] Step 3: Take the absolute value of heat transfer: [latex] |Q| = 100 \text{ kJ} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{100.0 \text{ kJ}} [/latex]

question: Question 3 A thermal power plant is running with no reheat or regeneration. The specific enthalpy and specific entropy of steam at the turbine inlet are  [latex]3344 \; kJ \; kg^{-1}[/latex] and  [latex]6.5 \; kJ\;  kg^{-1} K^{-1}[/latex] respectively. The turbine isentropic efficiency is 0.9, and the mass flow rate of steam at the turbine inlet is  [latex]102 kg \; s^{-1}[/latex]. The turbine power output is __________ MW (rounded off to 1 decimal place). Properties of saturated liquid and saturated vapor at turbine exit pressure Saturated liquid water Saturated water vapor Specific enthalpy [latex](\text{kJ kg}^{-1})[/latex] Specific entropy [latex](\text{kJ kg}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1})[/latex] Specific enthalpy [latex](\text{kJ kg}^{-1})[/latex] Specific entropy [latex](\text{kJ kg}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1})[/latex] 341 1.1 2645 7.6
solution: Given: Turbine inlet enthalpy: [latex] h_1 = 3344 , \text{kJ/kg} [/latex] Turbine inlet entropy: [latex] s_1 = 6.5 , \text{kJ/kg K} [/latex] Turbine isentropic efficiency: [latex] \eta_{\text{turbine}} = 0.9 [/latex] Mass flow rate: [latex] \dot{m} = 102 , \text{kg/s} [/latex] At turbine exit pressure: Saturated liquid: [latex] h_f = 341 , \text{kJ/kg}, \quad s_f = 1.1 , \text{kJ/kg K} [/latex] Saturated vapor: [latex] h_g = 2645 , \text{kJ/kg}, \quad s_g = 7.6 , \text{kJ/kg K} [/latex] Step 1: Use isentropic assumption to find dryness fraction at isentropic exit [latex] s_2^s = s_1 = 6.5 , \text{kJ/kg·K} [/latex] [latex] s_2^s = s_f + x_s (s_g - s_f) [/latex] [latex] 6.5 = 1.1 + x_s (7.6 - 1.1) [/latex] [latex] x_s = \frac{6.5 - 1.1}{6.5} = \frac{5.4}{6.5} = 0.8308 [/latex] Step 2: Enthalpy at isentropic exit [latex] h_2^s = h_f + x_s (h_g - h_f) [/latex] [latex] h_2^s = 341 + 0.8308 (2645 - 341) [/latex] [latex] h_2^s = 341 + 0.8308 \cdot 2304 = 341 + 1914.3 = 2255.3 , \text{kJ/kg} [/latex] Step 3: Actual enthalpy at turbine exit using efficiency [latex] \eta_{\text{turbine}} = \frac{h_1 - h_2}{h_1 - h_2^s} [/latex] [latex] 0.9 = \frac{3344 - h_2}{3344 - 2255.3} = \frac{3344 - h_2}{1088.7} [/latex] [latex] 3344 - h_2 = 0.9 \cdot 1088.7 = 979.83 [/latex] [latex] h_2 = 3344 - 979.83 = 2364.2 , \text{kJ/kg} [/latex] Step 4: Turbine power output [latex] P = \dot{m} (h_1 - h_2) = 102 \cdot (3344 - 2364.2) [/latex] [latex] P = 102 \cdot 979.8 = 99939.6 , \text{kW} = 99.94 , \text{MW} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{99.9 , \text{MW}} [/latex]

question: Question 4 The thermal efficiency of an ideal air-standard Otto cycle is 0.5. The value of specific heat ratio of air is 1.4. The compression ratio of the cycle is ______________ (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution:
Given: Thermal efficiency of Otto cycle [latex] \eta = 0.5 [/latex]
Specific heat ratio of air [latex] \gamma = 1.4 [/latex]
We are to find the compression ratio [latex] r [/latex]. Step 1: The efficiency of an ideal Otto cycle is given by:
[latex] \eta = 1 - \dfrac{1}{r^{\gamma - 1}} [/latex] Step 2: Substitute the known values:
[latex] 0.5 = 1 - \dfrac{1}{r^{1.4 - 1}} = 1 - \dfrac{1}{r^{0.4}} [/latex] Rearranging:
[latex] \dfrac{1}{r^{0.4}} = 0.5 [/latex]
[latex] r^{0.4} = 2 [/latex] Step 3: Raise both sides to the power [latex] \dfrac{1}{0.4} = 2.5 [/latex]:
[latex] r = 2^{2.5} = \sqrt{2^5} = \sqrt{32} \approx 5.657 [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{5.7} [/latex] (rounded off to 1 decimal place)

question: Question 5 In a psychrometric chart, one axis represents dry-bulb temperature. The axis, that is perpendicular to the dry-bulb temperature axis, represents
solution: Step 1: Understanding the Psychrometric Chart A psychrometric chart is a graphical representation of air properties, commonly used in HVAC and thermodynamics. It helps analyze air-conditioning processes by displaying various properties of moist air. Step 2: Identifying the Axes - The **horizontal axis** represents the **dry-bulb temperature (DBT)**, which is the temperature of air measured using a regular thermometer. - The **vertical axis (perpendicular to the dry-bulb temperature axis)** represents **specific humidity**, also known as **humidity ratio**. Step 3: Understanding Specific Humidity Specific humidity [latex] \omega [/latex] is defined as: [latex] \omega = \frac{m_v}{m_a} [/latex] where: [latex]m_v[/latex] = mass of water vapor (kg) [latex]m_a[/latex] = mass of dry air (kg) This represents the **mass of water vapor per unit mass of dry air**, making it a key parameter in psychrometric analysis. Step 4: Choosing the Correct Option Since the **specific humidity** is plotted on the axis perpendicular to the dry-bulb temperature axis, the correct answer is: (B) Specific Humidity

question: Question 6 Air inside a rigid, thermally-insulated tank undergoes stirring as shown in the figure below. Which one of the following options is correct?
solution: The tank is rigid, so volume is constant: no boundary work is done. It is thermally insulated, so no heat exchange: adiabatic process. Stirring does work on the system, increasing its internal energy [latex] U [/latex]. For ideal gases, at constant volume, an increase in [latex] U [/latex] leads to an increase in temperature and enthalpy [latex] H = U + pV [/latex] also increases. The process is irreversible (due to stirring), so entropy increases. Therefore: Both the enthalpy and the entropy of the air increase.

options.A: The enthalpy of the air increases while the entropy of the air remains constant
options.B: Both the enthalpy and the entropy of the air remain constant
options.C: Both the enthalpy and the entropy of the air increase
options.D: The enthalpy of the air decreases while the entropy of the air increases

question: Question 7 A heat pump (H.P.) is driven by the work output a heat engine (H.E.) as shown in the figure. The heat engine extracts [latex]150 \mathrm{~kJ}[/latex] of heat from the source at [latex]1000 \mathrm{~K}[/latex]. The heat pump absorbs heat from the ambient at [latex]280 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] and delivers heat to the room which is maintained at [latex]300 \mathrm{~K}[/latex]. Considering the combined system to be ideal, the total amount of heat delivered to the room together by the heat engine and heat pump is ____ [latex]\mathrm{kJ}[/latex] (answer in integer).

Question 8 A piston-cylinder arrangement shown in the figure has a stop located [latex]2 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] above the base. The cylinder initially contains air at [latex]140 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] and [latex]350^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] and the piston is resting in equilibrium at a position which is [latex]1 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] above the stops. The system is now cooled to the ambient temperature of [latex]25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]. Consider air to be an ideal gas with a value of gas constant [latex]R=0.287 \mathrm{~kJ}[/latex] (kg.K). The absolute value of specific work done during the process is _______ [latex]\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] (rounded off to 1 decimal place).

Question 9 Consider an air-standard Brayton cycle with adiabatic compressor and turbine, and a regenerator, as shown in the figure. Air enters the compressor at [latex]100 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] and [latex]300 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] and exits the compressor at [latex]600 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] and [latex]550 \mathrm{~K}[/latex]. The air exits the combustion chamber at [latex]1250 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] and exits the adiabatic turbine at [latex]100 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] and [latex]800 \mathrm{~K}[/latex]. The exhaust air from the turbine is used to preheat the air in regenerator. The exhaust air exits the regenerator (state 6) at [latex]600 \mathrm{~K}[/latex]. There is no pressure drop across the regenerator and the combustion chamber. Also, there is no heat loss from the regenerator to the surroundings. The ratio of specific heats at constant pressure and volume is [latex]c_{p} / c_{v}=1.4[/latex]. The thermal efficiency of the cycle is _____ [latex]\%[/latex] (answer in integer).
solution: [latex]\mathrm{T}_{1}=300 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{T}_{2}=550 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{T}_{4}=1250 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{T}_{5}=800 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{T}_{6}=600 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] [latex]\gamma=1.4[/latex] [latex]W_{\text {net }}=C_{P}\left(T_{4}-T_{5}\right)-C_{P}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right)[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{R}}=\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{6}-\mathrm{T}_{1}\right)[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{S}}=\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}+\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{R}}[/latex] So, [latex]\eta=\frac{W_{\text {net }}}{Q_{s}}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{4}-\mathrm{T}_{5}\right)-\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{2}-\mathrm{T}_{1}\right)}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{4}-\mathrm{T}_{5}\right)-\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{2}-\mathrm{T}_{1}\right)+\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{6}-\mathrm{T}_{1}\right)}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{(1250-800)-(550-300)}{(1250-800)-(550-300)+(600-300)}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{450-250}{450-250+300}=\frac{200}{500}=40 \%[/latex]

the nozzle. If [latex]E[/latex] and [latex]F[/latex] denote the flow conditions just upstream and downstream of
the normal shock, respectively, which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE?
solution:
For shock, flow must change from supersonic to
subsonic

options.A: Static pressure at [latex]E[/latex] is lower than the static pressure at [latex]F[/latex]
options.B: Density at [latex]E[/latex] is lower than the density at [latex]F[/latex]

question: Question 11 Which one of the following statements regarding a Rankine cycle is FALSE?
solution: Superheating in Rankine cycle increases the cycle efficiency because of increase in mean temperature of heat addition. With increase in pressure of boiler, the cycle efficiency increases. So, the given statement is wrong. With decrease in condenser pressure, the cycle efficiency increases because of decrease in mean temperature of heat rejection. The pressure of turbine outlet is governed by the condenser temperature. Decreasing the cooling water temperature, creates more vacuum in condenser which results in pressure drop and vice-versa.

options.A: Superheating the steam in the boiler increases the cycle efficiency.
options.B: The pressure at the turbine outlet depends on the condenser temperature.
options.C: Cycle efficiency increases as a condenser pressure decreases.
options.D: Cycle efficiency increases as boiler pressure decreases.

question: Question 12 A furnace can supply heat steadily at [latex]1200 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] at a rate of [latex]24000 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{min}[/latex]. The maximum amount of power (in kW) that can by using the heat supplied by the furnace in an environment at [latex]300 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] is

Question 13 Consider a mixture of two ideal gases, X and Y, with molar masses [latex]\bar{M}_X=10kg/kmol [/latex] and [latex]\bar{M}_Y=20kg/kmol [/latex], respectively, in a container. The total
pressure in the container is 100 kPa, the total volume of the container is [latex]10m^3 [/latex]
and the temperature of the contents of the container is 300 K. If the mass of
gas-X in the container is 2 kg, then the mass of gas-Y in the container
is ____ kg. (Rounded off to one decimal place) Assume that the universal gas constant is 8314 [latex]J \;kmol^{-1}K^{-1}[/latex]

Question 14 Consider a fully adiabatic piston-cylinder arrangement as shown in the figure. The piston is
massless and cross-sectional area of the cylinder is [latex]A[/latex]. The fluid inside the cylinder is air
(considered as a perfect gas), with [latex]\gamma [/latex] being the ratio of the specific heat at constant pressure to
the specific heat at constant volume for air. The piston is initially located at a position [latex]L_1 [/latex]. The
initial pressure of the air inside the cylinder is [latex]P_1 \gt \gt P_0 [/latex], where [latex]P_0 [/latex] is the atmospheric pressure.
The stop [latex]S_1 [/latex] is instantaneously removed and the piston moves to the position [latex]L_2 [/latex], where the
equilibrium pressure of air inside the cylinder is [latex]P_2 \gt \gt P_0 [/latex]. What is the work done by the piston on the atmosphere during this process?
solution:
Initial volume [latex]\mathrm{V}_{1}=\mathrm{L}_{1} \times \mathrm{A}[/latex] Final volume [latex]V_{2}=L_{2} \times A[/latex] Work done by atmospheric air [latex]=\int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}} P d v[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& =P_{0} \int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}} d V \\
& =P_{0}\left(L_{2} A-L_{1} A\right) \\
& =P_{0} A\left(L_{2}-L_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 15 Which one of the following statements is FALSE?

options.A: For an ideal gas, the enthalpy is independent of pressure.
options.B:
For a real gas going through an adiabatic reversible process, the process equation is given by [latex]PV^\gamma =[/latex] constant, where [latex]P[/latex] is the pressure, [latex]V[/latex] is the volume and [latex]\gamma [/latex] is the ratio of the specific heats
of the gas at constant pressure and constant volume.
options.C:
For an ideal gas undergoing a reversible polytropic process [latex]PV^{1.5} =[/latex] constant, the equation
connecting the pressure, volume and temperature of the gas at any point along the process is [latex]\frac{P}{R}=\frac{mT}{V}[/latex]  where [latex]R[/latex] is the gas constant and  [latex]m[/latex] is the mass of the gas.
options.D:
Any real gas behaves as an ideal gas at sufficiently low pressure or sufficiently high
temperature.

question:
Question 16 A heat engine extracts heat [latex] (Q_H)[/latex] from a thermal reservoir at a temperature of
[latex]1000 K[/latex] and rejects heat [latex] (Q_L)[/latex] to a thermal reservoir at a temperature of [latex]100 K[/latex],
while producing work [latex] (W)[/latex]. Which one of the combinations of [latex] (Q_H,Q_L,W)[/latex] given is allowed?
solution:
For a reversible engine, the rate of heat rejection
is minimum. For process to be feasible [latex] \oint \frac{dQ}{T}\leq 0[/latex] for option (b)
[latex] \oint \frac{dQ}{T}=\frac{Q_H}{T_1}-\frac{Q_2}{T_2}=\frac{2000}{1000}-\frac{750}{100} \lt 0[/latex] So cyclic process is possible.

question:
Question 17 Consider an isentropic flow of air (ratio of specific heats = 1.4) through a duct as
shown in the figure. The variations in the flow across the cross-section are negligible. The flow
conditions at Location 1 are given as follows: ??[latex] P_1=100kPa, \rho _1=1.2kg/m^3,u_1=400m/s[/latex] The duct cross-sectional area at Location 2 is given by [latex] A_2=2A_1[/latex], where[latex] A_1[/latex]
denotes the duct cross-sectional area at Location 1. Which one of the given
statements about the velocity [latex] u_2[/latex] and pressure [latex] P_2[/latex] at Location 2 is TRUE?
solution:
Step -1:
First identify type of flow - Subsonic or
Supersonic by finding out Mach number Mach no at start of flow [latex]
M_a=\frac{u_1}{C_1},\; where, \; C_1=\sqrt{\gamma RT_1}
[/latex] [latex] u_1 [/latex] is velocity of gas [latex] C_1 [/latex]is velocity of sound [latex] \begin{aligned}
P_1 &=\rho _1RT_1 \\ 
 T_1&= \frac{P_1}{\rho _1R}=\frac{100}{1.2 \times 0.287}=290.36K\\ 
C_1 &=\sqrt{1.4 \times 287 \times 290.36} \\ 
 &= 341.56 m/sec\\ 
Ma_1 &=\frac{400}{341.56}=1.017 
\end{aligned} [/latex] Flow is supersonic flow. Hence, diverging duct
is nozzle so [latex] u_2 \gt u_1 [/latex] and [latex] P_2 \lt P_1 [/latex].

question:
Question 18 At steady state, [latex]500 kg/s[/latex] of steam enters a
turbine with specific enthalpy equal to [latex]3500 kJ/
kg[/latex] and specific entropy equal to  [latex]6.5 kJ \dot kg^{-1}\dot K^{-1}[/latex]. It
expands reversibly in the turbine to the condenser
pressure. Heat loss occurs reversibly in the turbine
at a temperature of [latex]500 K[/latex]. If the exit specific
enthalpy and specific entropy are [latex]2500 kJ/kg[/latex] and
 [latex]6.3 kJ\dot kg^{-1} \dot K^{-1}[/latex], respectively, the work output from
the turbine is ________ MW (in integer).
solution:
Mass flow rate of stem [latex] \dot{m}=500kg/s [/latex] [latex]h_1=300 kJ/kg [/latex] [latex] S_1=6.5 kJ/kgL[/latex] [latex] h_2=2500kJ/kg[/latex] [latex] S_2=6.3 kJ/kgK[/latex] Surrounding temperature [latex]T_o=500 K [/latex] Work output from turbine [latex] \begin{aligned}
W_T&=(h_1-h_2)-T_o(S_1-S_2)\\
&=(3500-2500)-500(6.5-6.3)\\
&=1000-100\\
&=900 kJ/kg
\end{aligned}[/latex] Power output of turbine [latex] \begin{aligned}
P&=\frac{W_T}{kg} \times \dot{m}\\
&=900 \times 500\\
&=450000 kW\\
&=450 MW
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 19 A rigid tank of volume of 8 [latex]m^3[/latex] is being filled up
with air from a pipeline connected through a valve.
Initially the valve is closed and the tank is assumed
to be completely evacuated. The air pressure and
temperature inside the pipeline are maintained at
600 kPa and 306 K, respectively. The filling of the
tank begins by opening the valve and the process
ends when the tank pressure is equal to the pipeline
pressure. During the filling process, heat loss to
the surrounding is 1000 kJ. The specific heats of
air at constant pressure and at constant volume are
1.005 kJ/kg.K and 0.718 kJ/kg.K, respectively.
Neglect changes in kinetic energy and potential
energy. The final temperature of the tank after the
completion of the filling process is _________ K
(round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Initially the tank is completely evacuated ([latex]m_1 = 0[/latex]) After the gas is filled with tank, the gas pressure in
the tank is 600 kPa. Heat lost to surroundings (Q) = 1000 kJ [latex]c_p=1.005 KJ/kgK [/latex] [latex] c_v=0.718KJ/kgK[/latex] [latex]R=c_p-c_v=0.287 kJ/kgK [/latex] (Changes in KE and PE are negligible) Final temperature of gas  [latex] T_f=?[/latex] m = mass of gas entering to tank The energy balance equation is energy carried by
gas in the pipe = energy of gas in the rigid tank +
Heat lost to surrounding [latex]\begin{aligned}
mh_i&=mu_f+Q\\
h_i&=u_f+\frac{Q}{m}\\
C+pT_i&=C_vT_f+\frac{1000}{\frac{16724.73868}{T_f}}
\end{aligned} [/latex] Mass of gas in the tank [latex]\begin{aligned}
m=\frac{P_fV_f}{RT_f}\\
&=\frac{600(8)}{0.287(T_f)}\\
&=\frac{16724.73868}{T_f}\\
1.005(306)&=0.718T_f+\frac{1000T_f}{16724.73868}\\
&=0.718T_f+0.05979T_f\\
&=0.77779T_f\\
\therefore \; T_f&=\frac{1.005 \times 306}{0.77779}\\
&=395.389K\approx 395K
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 20 Consider 1 kg of an ideal gas at 1 bar and 300 K
contained in a rigid and perfectly insulated container.
The specific heat of the gas at constant volume [latex]c_v[/latex]
 is equal to [latex]750 \; Jkg^{-1}K^{-1}[/latex]. A stirrer performs 225 kJ of
work on the gas. Assume that the container does not
participate in the thermodynamic interaction. The
final pressure of the gas will be ______ bar
(in integer).
solution:
[latex]m = 1 kg, P_1
 = 1 \;bar, T_1
 = 300 \;K [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
V &= \text{Constant} \\ 
 W_{expansion}&= 0\\ 
C_V &=750\frac{J}{kgK}=0.75\frac{kJ}{kgK} \\ 
 W_{stirrer}&= 225kJ\;\;\;(-ve \;\; work)\\ 
 P_2&=? \\ 
 \therefore W&= W_{expansion}+W_{stirrer}\\
&=0-225=-225kJ
\end{aligned}[/latex] Using Ist law of thermodynamics [latex]\begin{aligned}
Q-W&=dU=mc_v(T_2-T_1)\\
0-(-225)&=1 \times 0.75(T_2-300)\\
T_2&=600K\\
\therefore \frac{P_2}{P_1}&=\frac{T_2}{T_1}\\
P_2&=\frac{600}{300} \times 1 =2\; bar
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 21 Which one of the following is an intensive property
of a thermodynamic system?
solution: Intensive property -> Density Mass, energy and volume are extensive properties.

question:
Question 22 An engine running on an air standard Otto cycle
has a displacement volume 250 [latex]cm^3[/latex]  and a clearance volume 35.7 [latex]cm^3[/latex]. The pressure and temperature at
the beginning of the compression process are 100
kPa and 300 K, respectively. Heat transfer during
constant-volume heat addition process is 800 kJ/kg. The specific heat at constant volume is 0.718 kJ/kg.K and the ratio of specific heats at constant
pressure and constant volume is 1.4. Assume the
specific heats to remain constant during the cycle.  The maximum pressure in the cycle is ______ kPa
(round off to the nearest integer).

Question 23 In a steam power plant based on Rankine cycle,
steam is initially expanded in a high-pressure
turbine. The steam is then reheated in a reheater
and finally expanded in a low-pressure turbine. The
expansion work in the high-pressure turbine is 400
kJ/kg and in the low-pressure turbine is 850 kJ/kg,
whereas the pump work is 15 kJ/kg. If the cycle
efficiency is 32%, the heat rejected in the condenser
is ________ kJ/kg (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
W_{HPT}&=400kJ/kg\\
W_{LPT}&=850kJ/kg\\
W_{P}&=15kJ/kg\\
\eta &=0.35=\frac{W_{net}}{Q_S}\\
Q_S&=3859.375 kJ/kg\\
\therefore \; W_{net}&=Q_S-Q_R\\
Q_R&=3859.375-1235\\
Q_R&=2624.37 kJ/kg
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 24 A polytropic process is carried out from an initial
pressure of 110 kPa and volume of 5 [latex]m^3[/latex]
 to a final volume of 2.5 [latex]m^3[/latex]. The polytropic index is given by
n = 1.2. The absolute value of the work done during
the process is _______ kJ (round off to 2 decimal
places).
solution:
Polytropic process] [latex]\begin{aligned}
P_1 &= 110 kPa,\\
V_1&= 5m^3,\\
V_2&=2.5 m^3,\\
n&=1.2\\
\Rightarrow \; P_1V_1^n&=P_2V_2^n\\
P_2&=P_1\left ( \frac{V_1}{V_2} \right )^n\\
&=110 \times \left ( \frac{5}{2.5} \right )^{1.2}\\
P_2&=252.71 kPa\\
W&=\frac{P_1V_1=P_2V_2}{n-1}\\
&=\frac{110 \times 5-252.71 \times 2.5}{1.2-1}\\
W&=-408.92kJ\\
|W|&=408.92kJ
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 26 An adiabatic vortex tube, shown in the figure given below is supplied with 5 kg/s of air (inlet 1) at 500 kPa and 300 K. Two separate streams of air are leaving the device from outlets 2 and 3. Hot air leaves the device at a rate of 3 kg/s from outlet 2 at 100 kPa and 340 K, and 2 kg/s of cold air stream is leaving the device from outlet 3 at 100 kPa and 240 K. Assume constant specific heat of  air  is  1005 J/kg.K  and  gas  constant  is  287 J/kg.K. There is no work transfer across the boundary of this device. The rate of entropy generation is  ________kW/K (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left(\frac{d S}{d t}\right)_{C . V} &=\dot{S}_{i}+\dot{S}_{g e n}-\dot{S}_{\theta} \\ \dot{S}_{\text {gen }} &=\dot{S}_{e}-\dot{S}_{i} \\ &=\dot{m}_{2} s_{2}+\dot{m}_{3} s_{3}-\dot{m}_{1} s_{1} \\ &=3\left(s_{2}-s_{1}\right)+2\left(s_{3}-s_{1}\right) \\ &=3 \times 0.587+2(0.237) \\ &=2.235 \mathrm{~kW} / \mathrm{K} \simeq 2.2 \mathrm{~kW} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 29 In the vicinity of the triple point, the equation of liquid-vapour boundary in the [latex]P-T[/latex] phase diagram for ammonia is [latex]\ln P=24.38-3063/T[/latex], where [latex]P[/latex] is pressure (in Pa) and [latex]T[/latex] is temperature (in K). Similarly, the solid-vapour boundary is given by [latex]\ln P=27.92-3754/T[/latex].  The temperature at the triple point is  ________K (round off to one decimal place).
solution: Liquid vapour, [latex]\ln P=24.38-\frac{3063}{T}[/latex] Solid vapour,[latex]\ln P=27.92-\frac{3754}{T}[/latex] At triple point temperature of solid, liquid and vapour is same. [latex] \therefore [/latex]equating [latex] 24.38-\frac{3063}{T}=27.92-\frac{3754}{T}[/latex] Multiplying by T on both sides [latex] \begin{aligned} 24.38 T-3063 &=27.92 T-3754 \\ 3.54 T &=691 \\ T &=195.197 \mathrm{~K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 Consider a steam power plant operating on an ideal reheat Rankine cycle. The work input to the pump is 20 kJ/kg. The work output from the high pressure turbine is 750 kJ/kg. The work output from the low pressure turbine is 1500 kJ/kg. The thermal efficiency of the cycle is 50 %. The enthalpy of saturated liquid and saturated vapour at condenser pressure are 200 kJ/kg and 2600 kJ/kg, respectively. The quality of steam at the exit of the low pressure turbine is ________ % (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h_{f} &=200 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{g} &=2600 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{p} &=20 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}=h_{6}-h_{5} \\ h_{1}-h_{2} &=750 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{3}-h_{4} &=1500 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \eta &=0.5=\frac{W_{\mathrm{NET}}}{Q_{s}}=\frac{W_{T}-W_{P}}{Q_{s}}\\ 0.5 &=\frac{750+1500-20}{Q_{S}} \\ Q_{S} &=4460 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \eta &=1-\frac{Q_{R}}{Q_{S}} \\ \frac{Q_{R}}{Q_{S}} &=0.5 \\ Q_{R} &=2230 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ Q_{R} &=h_{4}-h_{5} \\ 2230 &=h_{4}-200 \\ h_{4} &=2430 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{4} &=h_{f}+x\left(h_{g}-h_{f}\right) \\ 2430 &=200+x(2600-200) \\ x &=0.9291 \\ x &=93 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The fundamental thermodynamic relation for a rubber band is given by [latex]dU=TdS+\tau dL[/latex], where [latex]T[/latex] is the absolute temperature, [latex]S[/latex] is the entropy, [latex]\tau[/latex] is the tension in the rubber band, and [latex]L[/latex] is the length of the rubber band. Which one of the following relations is CORRECT:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} d U&=T d s+\tau d L \\ \left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial L}\right)_{S}&=\left(\frac{\partial \tau}{\partial S}\right)_{L}\\ \text { Comparing with } M=\left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\right)_{y}& \\ T&=\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial S}\right)_{L}\\ \text { Comparing with } N=\left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\right)_{x} \\ \tau&=\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial L}\right)_{S} \\ M&=\left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\right)_{y} \\ N&=\left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\right)_{x} \\ d z&=M d x+N d y \end{aligned}[/latex] If z is exact different [latex] \left(\frac{\partial M}{\partial y}\right)_{x}=\left(\frac{\partial N}{\partial x}\right)_{y}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A rigid insulated tank is initially evacuated. It is connected through a valve to a supply line that carries air at a constant pressure and temperature of 250 kPa and 400 K respectively. Now the valve is opened and air is allowed to flow into the tank until the pressure inside the tank reaches to 250 kPa at which point the valve is closed. Assume that the air behaves as a perfect gas with constant properties [latex](c_p=1.005\; kJ/kg.K, c_v=0.718\; kJ/kg.K, R=0.287 kJ/kg.K)[/latex]. Final temperature of the air inside the tank is _______K (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} T_{2}=\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}} T_{1} \\ T_{2}=\left(\frac{1.005}{0.718}\right) \times 400 \\ T_{2}=559.888 \mathrm{~K} \approx 560 \mathrm{~K} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 34 Keeping all other parameters identical, the Compression Ratio (CR) of an air standard
diesel cycle is increased from 15 to 21. Take ratio of specific heats = 1.3 and cut-off
ratio of the cycle [latex]r_c = 2[/latex]. The difference between the new and the old efficiency values, in percentage, [latex](\eta _{new}|_{ CR = 21})-(\eta _{old}|_{CR = 15})=[/latex] _______ %. (round off to one decimal place)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta_{d, r=21} &=1-\left(\frac{1}{r}\right)^{\gamma-1} \times \frac{\left(\rho^{\gamma}-1\right)}{\gamma(\rho-1)}=54.87 \% \\ \eta_{d, r=15} &=1-\left(\frac{1}{r}\right)^{\gamma-1} \times \frac{\left(\rho^{\gamma}-1\right)}{\gamma(\rho-1)}=50.08 \% \\ \eta_{d, r=21}-\eta_{d, r=15} &=4.8 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 35 In a steam power plant, superheated steam at 10 MPa and 500[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex], is expanded isentropically
in a turbine until it becomes a saturated vapour. It is then reheated at constant pressure
to 500[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]. The steam is next expanded isentropically in another turbine until it reaches
the condenser pressure of 20 kPa. Relevant properties of steam are given in the following
two tables. The work done by both the turbines together is ______ kJ/kg (roundoff to
the nearest integer).
solution: Given data: [latex] h_{1}=3373.6 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}, h_{3}=3478.4 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}, h_{2}=2778.1 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}, s_{1}=s_{2} [/latex] (as from table ) [latex] \begin{aligned} s_{3} &=s_{4} \\ s_{3} &=7.7621=0.8319+x+(7.9085-0.8319) \\ x_{4} &=0.9793 \\ h_{4} &=h_{f}+x_{4} \times\left(h_{g}-h_{f}\right)=2560.91 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ W_{T} &=\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)+\left(h_{3}-h_{4}\right)=1512.95 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 36 Moist air at 105 kPa, 30[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] and 80% relative humidity flows over a cooling coil in an
insulated air-conditioning duct. Saturated air exits the duct at 100 kPa and 15[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]. The
saturation pressure of water at 30[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] and 15[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] are 4.24 kPa and 1.7 kPa respectively.
Molecular weight of water is 18 g/mol and that of air is 28.94 g/mol. The mass of water
condensing out from the duct is ______ g/kg of dry air (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{t 1} &=105 \mathrm{kPa}, \mathrm{DBT}_{1}=30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \phi_{1}=0.8 \\ P_{t 2} &=100 \mathrm{kPa}, \mathrm{DBT}_{2}=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \phi_{2}=1 \\ P_{v s 1} &=4.24 \mathrm{kPa} \\ P_{v s 2} &=1.7 \mathrm{kPa} \\ M_{\text {water }} &=18 \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{mol} \\ M_{\mathrm{air}} &=28.94 \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{mol} \\ \omega_{1} &=\frac{18}{28.94} \times \frac{P_{v 1}}{P_{t 1}-P_{v 1}} \\ \phi_{1} &=\frac{P_{v 1}}{P_{v s 1}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 0.8&=\frac{P_{\mathrm{v}}}{4.24} \\ \therefore \qquad P_{\mathrm{v} 1}&=3.392 \\ \therefore \qquad \omega_{1}&=\frac{18}{28.94} \times \frac{3.392}{105-3.392}\\ &=0.02076 \mathrm{kgV} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{d} . \mathrm{a} \\ &=20.76 \mathrm{gv} / \mathrm{kgd.a} \\ \omega_{2}&=\frac{18}{28.94} \times \frac{P_{\mathrm{v} 2}}{P_{\mathrm{t} 2}-P_{\mathrm{v} 2}} \\ \phi_{2}&=\frac{P_{\mathrm{v} 2}}{P_{\mathrm{vs} 2}} \\ 1&=\frac{P_{\mathrm{v} 2}}{1.7} \\ \therefore \qquad P_{\mathrm{v} 2}&=1.7 \\ \therefore \qquad \omega_{2}&=\frac{18}{28.94} \times \frac{1.7}{100-1.7}\\&=0.01075 \mathrm{Kgv} / \mathrm{kgda} \end{aligned}[/latex] Mass of water condensing [latex]=\omega_{1}-\omega_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =20.76-10.75 \\ =10.01 \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{kgd} . \mathrm{a} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 37 Air is contained in a frictionless piston-cylinder arrangement as shown in the figure. The atmospheric pressure is 100 kPa and the initial pressure of air in the cylinder is
105 kPa. The area of piston is 300 [latex]cm^2[/latex]. Heat is now added and the piston moves slowly
from its initial position until it reaches the stops. The spring constant of the linear spring
is 12.5 N/mm. Considering the air inside the cylinder as the system, the work interaction
is ________ J. (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{0}&=100 \mathrm{kPa}, P_{1}=105 \mathrm{kPa}, \mathrm{K}=12.5 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}=12.5 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \\ A&=300 \mathrm{cm}^{2}=300 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ x&=8 \mathrm{cm}=8 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] 1-2 constant pressure [latex] \begin{aligned} W_{1-2} &=P_{1} \times A \times x=105 \times 300 \times 10^{-4} \times 8 \times 10^{-2} \\ &=0.252 \mathrm{kJ}=252 \mathrm{J} \\ P_{2} &=105 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{3} \times A &=P_{2} A+K x \\ P_{3} &=P_{2}+\frac{K x}{A}\\ &=105+\frac{12.5 \times 8 \times 10^{-2}}{300 \times 10^{-4}} \\& =138.33 \mathrm{kPa} \\ W_{2-3} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(P_{2}+P_{3}\right) \times\left(V_{3}-V_{2}\right)\\ &=\frac{1}{2}(105+138.33) A \times x \\ &=\frac{1}{2}(243.33) \times 300 \times 10^{-4} \times 8 \times 10^{-2} \\ W_{2-3} &=0.2919 \mathrm{kJ}=291.9 \mathrm{J} \\ \therefore \quad  W_{\text {total }} &=W_{1-2}+W_{2-3}\\&=0.5439 \mathrm{kJ}=543.91 \approx 544 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternate Solution: Total work = Workdone because of 105 kPa pressure + Workdone against spring which is equal to energy stored in spring [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Workdone } &=P_{1} \times A \times 2 x+\frac{1}{2} k \cdot x^{2} \\ &=105 \times 300 \times 10^{-4} \times 2 \times 8 \times 10^{-2}\\ & +\frac{1}{2} \times 12.5 \times\left(8 \times 10^{-2}\right)^{2} \\ &=0.504+0.04 \\ &=0.544 \mathrm{kJ}=544 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 38 One kg of air in a closed system undergoes an irreversible process from an initial state
of [latex]p_1 = 1[/latex] bar (absolute) and [latex]T_1 = 27^{\circ}C[/latex], to a final state of [latex]p_2 = 3[/latex] bar (absolute) and [latex]T_2= 127^{\circ}C[/latex]. If the gas constant of air is 287 J/kg.K and the ratio of the specific heats
[latex]\gamma = 1.4[/latex], then the change in the specific entropy (in J/kg.K) of the air in the process is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} P_{1}=1 \text { bar, } P_{2}=1 \text { bar, } T_{1}=300 \mathrm{K}, T_{2}=400 \mathrm{K} \\ c_{p}=\frac{\gamma R}{\gamma-1}=1005 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ \Delta S=c_{p} \ln \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}-R \ln \frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}=1005 \ln \frac{400}{300}-287 \mathrm{ln} \frac{3}{1}=-26.32 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{array}[/latex]

options.D: indeterminate, as the process is irreversible

question:
Question 39 If a reversed Carnot cycle operates between the temperature limits of [latex]27^{\circ}C[/latex] and [latex]-3^{\circ}C[/latex],
then the ratio of the COP of a refrigerator to that of a heat pump (COP of refrigerator/
COP of heat pump) based on the cycle is __________ (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{H}&=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=300 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{L}&=-3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=270 \mathrm{K} \\ \frac{\mathrm{COP}_{\mathrm{ref}}}{\mathrm{COP}_{\mathrm{HP}}}&=\frac{\frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}-T_{L}}}{\frac{T_{H}}{T_{H}-T_{L}}}=\frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}}=\frac{270}{300}=0.9 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 The indicated power developed by an engine with compression ratio of 8, is calculated
using an air-standard Otto cycle {constant properties). The rate of heat addition is
10 kW. The ratio of specific heats at constant pressure and constant volume is 1.4.
The mechanical efficiency of the engine is 80 percent. The brake power output of the
engine is ________ kW (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=1-\frac{1}{r_{c}^{\gamma-1}}=1-\frac{1}{8^{0.4}}=0.5647 \\ \frac{W}{Q_{1}} &=0.5647 \\ W &=\frac{10 \times 5647}{1000}=5.647 \mathrm{kW} \\ \mathrm{BP} &=\eta_{m} \times W=0.8 \times 5.647 \\ &=4.5175 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 For an ideal Rankine cycle operating between pressures of 30 bar and 0.04 bar, the work
output from the turbine is 903 kJ/kg and the work input to the feed pump is 3 kJ/kg.
The specific steam consumption is _________________ kg/kW.h (round off to 2 decimal
places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} (WD)_{\text {turbine }} &=903 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ (WD)_{\text {pump}} &=3 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \text { Specific steam consumption }=& ?(\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kW}-\mathrm{hr}) \\ \mathrm{SSC} &=\frac{3600}{W_{T}-W_{C}} \\ &=\frac{3600}{903-3}=4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kW}-\mathrm{hr} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 One kg of air, initially at a temperature of 127[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex], expands reversibly at a constant
pressure until the volume is doubled. If the gas constant of air is 287 J/kg.K, the
magnitude of work transfer is __________ kJ (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m=1 \mathrm{kg} ; T_{1}=127^{\circ} \mathrm{C} &=400 \mathrm{K} \\ P=C ; V_{2}=2 V_{1} ; \quad R=& 0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ W &=P_{1}\left(V_{2}-V_{1}\right) \\ &=P_{1}\left(2 V_{1}-V_{1}\right) \\ &=P_{1} \cdot V_{1}=\mathrm{mRT}_{1} \\ &=114.8 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 46 Air (ideal gas) enters a perfectly insulated compressor at a temperature of 310 K. The
pressure ratio of the compressor is 6. Specific heat at constant pressure for air is
1005 J/kg.K and ratio of specific heats at constant pressure and constant volume is
1.4. Assume that specific heats of air are constant. If the isentropic efficiency of the
compressor is 85 percent, the difference in enthalpies of air between the exit and the
inlet of the compressor is ________ kJ/kg (round off to nearest integer).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{1} &=310 \mathrm{K} \\ r_{p} &=\frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}=6 \quad \eta_{s}=0.85 \\ C_{p} &=1.005 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ \gamma &=1.4 \\ \therefore \quad \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} &=\left(\frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{T_{2}}{310} &=(6)^{1.4-1 / 1.4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{2} &=517.225 \mathrm{K} \\ \text{Now,}\quad \eta_{\text {isen }} &=\frac{W_{\text {isen }}}{W_{\text {actual }}}=\frac{h_{2}-h_{1}}{h_{2}-h_{1}} \\ 0.85 &=\frac{C_{p}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right)}{h_{2}-h_{1}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad h_{2}-h_{1} &=\frac{1.005(517.22-310)}{0.85}=245 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 The compressor of a gas turbine plant, operating on an ideal intercooled Brayton cycle,
accomplishes an overall compression ratio of 6 in a two-stage compression process,
Intercooling is used to cool the air coming out from the first stage to the inlet temperature
of the first stage, before its entry to the second stage. Air enters the compressor at
300 K and 100 kPa. If the properties of gas are constant, the intercooling pressure for
minimum compressor work is________ kPa (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\frac{P_{3}}{P_{1}}=6\, \, \Rightarrow P_{3}=600\, kPa[/latex] intermediate Pressure  [latex]=\sqrt{P_{3}P_{1}}=\sqrt{600\times 100}=244.94kPa[/latex]

question:
Question 48 For an ideal gas, a constant pressure line and a constant volume line intersect at a point,
in the Temperature (T) versus specific entropy (s) diagram. [latex]C_P[/latex] is the specific heat at
constant pressure and [latex]C_V[/latex] is the specific heat at constant volume. The ratio of the slopes
of the constant pressure and constant volume lines at the point of intersection is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { If } \qquad v & =C \\ T d s & =d u+p d v \\ T d s & =d u\\ d u &=C_{V} d T &[\therefore V=C ]\\ T d s &=C_{V} d T \\ \left(\frac{d T}{d s}\right)_{V} &=\frac{T}{C_{V}} \\ \text{If}\qquad P &=C\\ T d s&=d h-v d P \\ d h &=C_{P} d T \qquad [\therefore P=C]\\ T d s &=C_{P} d T \\ \left(\frac{d T}{d s}\right)_{P} &=\frac{T}{C_{P}} \\ \text{Ratio, }\quad\frac{(d T / d s)_{P}}{(d T / d s)_{V}} &=\frac{\left(T / C_{P}\right)_{P}}{\left(T / C_{V}\right)_{V}}=\frac{C_{V}}{C_{P}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 For an ideal gas, the value of the Joule-Thomson coefficient is
solution: Value of Joule Thomson coefficient for ideal gas [latex]\mu=\left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial P}\right)_{h}=0[/latex]

question: Question 50 An air standard Otto cycle has thermal efficiency of 0.5 and the mean effective pressure of the cycle is 1000 kPa. For air, assume specific heat ratio [latex]\gamma =1.4[/latex] and specific gas constant R=0.287 kJ/kg.K. If the pressure and temperature at the beginning of the compression stroke are 100 kPa and 300 K, respectively, then the specific net work output of the cycle is______ kJ/kg (round off to two decimal places).
solution: Given: [latex] \eta_{0}=0.5 [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{m}}=100 \mathrm{kPa} [/latex] [latex] \gamma=1.4 [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{R}=0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{P}_{1}=100 \mathrm{kPa} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{T}_{1}=300 \mathrm{K} [/latex] [latex] \eta_{0}=0.5=1-\frac{1}{(\mathrm{r})^{\gamma-1}} [/latex] [latex] 0.5=1-\frac{1}{(\mathrm{r})^{1.4-1}} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{r}=5.656 [/latex] At state(1) [latex] \mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}=\mathrm{RT}_{1} [/latex] [latex] 100 v_{1}=0.287 \times 300 [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{v}_{1}=0.861 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{r}=\frac{\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{v}_{2}} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{v}_{2}=0.1522 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} [/latex] [latex] P_{m}=\frac{W_{\text {net }}}{v_{1}-v_{2}} [/latex] [latex] 1000=\frac{\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}}{0.861-0.1522} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{net}}=708.77 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex]

question: Question 51 Water flowing at the rate of 1 kg/s through a system is heated using an electric heater such that the specific enthalpy of the water increases by 2.50 kJ/kg and the specific entropy increases by 0.007 kJ/kg.K. The power input to the electric heater is 2.50 kW. There is no other work or heat interaction between the system and the surroundings. Assuming an ambient temperature of 300 K, the irreversibility rate of the system is ______kW (round off to two decimal places).
solution: Given: [latex]\begin{aligned} (h_2-h_1)_{water} &=2.5 kJ/kg \\ (s_2-s_1)_{water}&=0.007kJ/kgK \\ [\text{Power}]_{input}&= 2.5kW\\ T_0&=300K \\ [\text{Power}]_{input}&= m(h_2-h_1)_{water}\\ 2.5&=m(2.5) \\ m&=1kg/s \\ (ds)_{water}&=m(s_2-s_1)_{water}\\ &=0.007kW/K \\ (ds)_{surrounding} &=0 \\ (ds)_{universe}&=0.007kW/K\\ \text{Irreversibility}&=300 \times 0.007=2.1kW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 The figure shows a heat engine (HE) working between two reservoirs. The amount of heat ([latex]Q_2[/latex]) rejected by the heat engine is drawn by a heat pump (HP). The heat pump receives the entire work output (W) of the heat engine. If temperatures, [latex]T_1 \gt T_3\gt T_2[/latex], then the relation between the efficiency ([latex]\eta[/latex]) of the heat engine and the coefficient of performance (COP) of the heat pump is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \eta=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}} \\ \frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=1-\eta \ldots \ldots(I) \\ \Rightarrow W=Q_{1}-Q_{2}=Q_{3}-Q_{2} \ldots \ldots (I I) \\ \begin{aligned} C O P&=\frac{R E}{W}=\frac{Q_{3}}{Q_{1}-Q_{2}} \\ &=\frac{Q_{3} / Q_{1}}{1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}}=\frac{1}{\eta} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Which one of the following modifications of the simple ideal Rankine cycle increases the thermal efficiency and reduces the moisture content of the steam at the turbine outlet?
solution:
Rankine cycle efficiency can be increased by increasing the mean temperature of heat addition and 
it can be obtain by increasing the super heated temperature of steam at the inlet to the steam turbine While the superheated steam temperature increases, the dryness fraction increases (i.e., moisture content decreases).

question: Question 54 For a simple compressible system, v, s, p and T are specific volume, specific entropy, pressure and temperature, respectively. As per Maxwell's relations, [latex]\left (\frac{\partial v}{\partial s} \right )_p[/latex] is equal to
solution: According to Maxwell's relation [latex]\left(\frac{\partial \mathrm{v}}{\partial \mathrm{s}}\right)_{\mathrm{p}}=\left(\frac{\partial \mathrm{T}}{\partial \mathrm{p}}\right)[/latex]

question: Question 55 A gas turbine with air as the working fluid has an isentropic efficiency of 0.70 when operating at a pressure ratio of 3. Now, the pressure ratio of the turbine is increased to 5, while maintaining the same inlet conditions. Assume air as a perfectgas withspecific heat ratio [latex]\gamma =1.4[/latex]. If the specific work output remains the same for both the cases, the isentropic efficiency of the turbine at the pressure ratio of 5 is ______ (round off to two decimal places)
solution: Given, [latex]r_{p 1}=3, r_{p_{2}}=5 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \qquad \begin{aligned} \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{act}} &=\eta_{\mathrm{s}} \times \mathrm{W}_{\text {iscatropic }} \\ &=\eta_{\mathrm{s}} \times \mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{p}}\left[\mathrm{T}_{3}-\mathrm{T}_{4}\right]\\ &=\eta_{\mathrm{s}} \times \mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{p}} \times \mathrm{T}_{3}\left[1-\frac{1}{\frac{T_{3}}{T{4}}}\right] \end{aligned} \\ \qquad \begin{aligned} \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{act}}=& \eta_{\mathrm{s}} \times \mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{p}} \times \mathrm{T}_{3}\left[1-\frac{1}{\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{p}}^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}}\right] \\ \left(\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{act})_{1}}\right.&=\left(\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{act}}\right)_{2} \end{aligned} \\ \therefore \eta_{\mathrm{s}} \times \left[1-\frac{1}{3^{\frac{1.4-1}{1.4}}}\right]=\eta_{\mathrm{s}_{2}} \times\left[1-\frac{1}{5^{\frac{1.4-1}{1.4}}}\right] \\  \Rightarrow \eta_{\mathrm{s}_{2}}=0.515 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 56 A steam power cycle with regeneration as shown below on the T-S diagram employs a single open feedwater heater for efficiency improvement. The fluids mix with each other in an open feedwater heater. The turbine is isentropic and the input (bleed) to the feedwater heater from the turbine is at state 2 as shown in the figure. Process 3-4 occurs in the condenser. The pump work is negligible. The input to the boiler is at state 5. The following information is available from the steam tables: The mass flow rate of steam bled from the turbine as a percentage of the total mass flow rate at the inlet to the turbineat state 1 is _______
solution:
Let '[latex]m_{1}[/latex]' kg of steam enters the turbine, '[latex]m_{2}[/latex]' kg of steam is bled from the turbine into the feed water heater and '[latex]m_{1}-m_{2}[/latex]' kg of steam enters the condenser. From energy balance of open feed water heater, [latex] \begin{aligned}  \mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{h}_{2}+\left(\mathrm{m}_{1}-\mathrm{m}_{2}\right) \mathrm{h}_{4}&=\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{h}_{5} \\ \mathrm{m}_{2} \times 2800+\left(\mathrm{m}_{1}-\mathrm{m}_{2}\right) 175 &=\mathrm{m}_{1} \times 700 \\ 2625 \mathrm{m}_{2} &=525 \mathrm{m}_{1} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex]    Percentage of steam bled from the turbine 
 [latex]=\frac{\mathrm{m}_{2}}{\mathrm{m}_{1}} \times 100=0.2 \times 100=20 \% [/latex]

question: Question 57 If one mole of [latex]H_2[/latex] gas occupies a rigid container with a capacity of 1000 litres and the temperature is raised from [latex]27^{\circ}C \; to \; 37^{\circ}C[/latex], the change in pressure of the contained gas (round offto two decimal places), assuming ideal gas behaviour, is ________ Pa. (R=8.314 J/mol.K)
solution: Volume , [latex]\mathrm{V}=1000 \mathrm{lit}=1 \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] For ideal gas, [latex]\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{n} \overline{\mathrm{R}} \mathrm{T} [/latex] Differntiating above expression we get, [latex] \mathrm{Vdp}=\mathrm{n} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{R}} \mathrm{d} \mathrm{T} [/latex] [latex] 1 \times \mathrm{dp}=1 \times 8.314 \times 10 [/latex] [latex] \therefore \mathrm{dP}=83.14 \mathrm{Pa}[/latex]

question: Question 58 A gas is heated in a duct as it flows over a resistance heater. Consider a 101 kW electric heating system. The gas enters the heating section of the duct at 100 kPa and [latex]27^{\circ}C[/latex] with a volume flow rate of 15 [latex]m^3/s[/latex]. If heat is lost from the gas in the duct to the surroundings at a rate of 51 kW, the exit temperature of the gas is (Assume constant pressure, ideal gas, negligible change in kinetic and potential energies and constant specific heat; [latex]C_p[/latex]=1 kJ/kg.K; R=0.5 kJ/kg.K)
solution: [latex]\dot{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{h}_{1}+\frac{\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}}{2000}\right]+\frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\dot{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{h}_{2}+\frac{\mathrm{V}_{2}^{2}}{2000}\right]+\frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{dt}}[/latex] where, [latex]\dot{\mathrm{m}}=\frac{\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{V}_{1}}{\mathrm{RT}_{1}}=\frac{100 \times 15}{0.5 \times 300}=10 [/latex] Thus, [latex] 10\left[\mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{p}} \mathrm{T}_{1}\right]+101-51=10 \times\left[\mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{p}} \times \mathrm{T}_{2}\right] \qquad\left[\because \mathrm{v}_{1}=0, \mathrm{v}_{2}=0 \text { and } \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{dt}}=0\right] [/latex] [latex] 10 \times 1 \times 300+50=10 \times 1 \times \mathrm{T}_{2} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{T}_{2}=305 \mathrm{K}=32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]

question: Question 59 Air of mass 1 kg, initially at 300 K and 10 bar, is allowed to expand isothermally till it reaches  a  pressure  of  1  bar.  Assuming  air  as  an  ideal  gas  with  gas  constant  of 0.287 kJ/kg.K, the change in entropy of air (in kJ/kg.K, round off to two decimal places) is____
solution: Given data: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{m}&=1 \mathrm{kg}, \mathrm{T}_{1}=300 \mathrm{K}, \mathrm{P}_{1}=10 \mathrm{bar} \\ \mathrm{T}_{2}&=300 \mathrm{K}, \mathrm{P}_{2}=1 \mathrm{bar} \\ \mathrm{dS}&=\frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{T}}=\frac{\mathrm{mRT} \ell \mathrm{n} \frac{\mathrm{P}_{1}}{\mathrm{P}_{2}}}{\mathrm{T}}=\mathrm{mR} \ell \mathrm{n} \frac{\mathrm{P}_{1}}{\mathrm{P}_{2}} \\ &=1 \times 0.287 \times \ell n 10=0.66 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 During a non-flow thermodynamic process(1-2) executed by a perfect gas, the heat interaction is equal to the work interaction ([latex]Q_{1-2}=W_{1-2}[/latex]) when the process is
solution: Given, [latex]\mathrm{Q}_{1-2}=\mathrm{W}_{1-2} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \Delta \mathrm{U}_{1-2}=0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{v}}\left[\mathrm{T}_{2}-\mathrm{T}_{1}\right]=0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{1}=\mathrm{T}_{2} [/latex] So, the process is isothermal.

question: Question 61 A vehicle powered by a spark ignition engine follows air standard Otto cycle ([latex]\gamma[/latex] =1.4). The engine generates 70 kW while consuming 10.3 kg/hr of fuel. The calorific value of fuel is 44,000 kJ/kg. The compression ratio is _______ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma &=1.4 \\ \mathrm{B.P.} &=70 \mathrm{kN} \\ \dot{m}_{f} &=10.3 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{hr} \\ C V &=44000 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \eta &=\frac{B P}{\dot{m}_{f} \times C V}=\frac{70}{\frac{10.3}{3600} \times 44000} \times 100 \% \\ \eta &=0.556 \\ \eta_{\mathrm{otto}} &=1-\frac{1}{(n)^{\gamma-1}}=0.556 \\ 1-\frac{1}{(n)^{1.4-1}} &=0.556 \\ \frac{1}{(n)^{0.4}} &=0.4439 \\ n &=7.61 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 Air is held inside a non-insulated cylinder using a piston (mass M=25 kg and area A=100 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex]  and stoppers (of negligible area), as shown in the figure. The initial pressure [latex]P_{i}[/latex] and temperature [latex]T_{i}[/latex] of air inside the cylinder are 200 kPa and [latex]400^{\circ}[/latex]C, respectively. The ambient pressure [latex]P_{\infty }[/latex]  and temperature [latex]T_{\infty }[/latex] are 100 kPa and [latex]27^{\circ}C[/latex], respectively. The temperature of the air inside the cylinder [latex](^{\circ}C)[/latex]  at which the piston will begin to move is _________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{\infty} &=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ P_{\text {piston }} &=\frac{M g}{A}=\frac{25 \times 9.81 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{kN}}{0.01 \mathrm{m}^{2}} \\ P_{\text {piston }} &=24.525 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \text { Total external pressure } &=P_{\infty}+P_{\text {piston }}=124.525 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Initial pressure of air, [latex]P_{i}=200 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Piston will be about to come down if system pressure is equal to total pressure i.e. 124.525kPa [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Final pressure of air at which is about to move is [latex]p_{f}=124.525 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Applying mass conservation at two states [latex]i \xi f [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{i} &=M_{f} \\ \frac{P_{i} V_{i}}{R T_{i}} &=\frac{P_{f} V_{f}}{R T_{f}}=V_{i}=V_{f} \\ \frac{200 \mathrm{kPa}}{673 \mathrm{K}} &=\frac{124.525 \mathrm{kPa}}{T_{f}} \\ T_{f} &=419.026 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{f} &=146.026^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 63 A frictionless circular piston of area  [latex]10^{-2}\: m^{2}[/latex]  and mass 100 kg sinks into a cylindrical container of the same area filled with water of density 1000 kg/m^{3}  as shown in the figure. The container has a hole of area [latex]10^{-3}\:m^{2}[/latex] at the bottom that is open to the atmosphere. Assuming there is no leakage from the edges of the piston and considering water to be in compressible, the magnitude of the piston velocity (in m/s) at the instant shown is _____ (correct to three decimal places).

Question 64 For an ideal gas with constant properties undergoing a quasi-static process, which one of
the following represents the change of entropy [latex](\Delta s)[/latex] from state 1 to 2?
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l}\mathrm{Tds}=\mathrm{dH}-\mathrm{VdP}\\ \mathrm{dS}=\frac{\mathrm{dH}}{\mathrm T}-\frac{\mathrm V}{\mathrm T}\mathrm{dP}\\ \mathrm{For}\;\mathrm{an}\;\mathrm{ideal}\;\mathrm{gas}\\ \mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{RT}\\ \frac{\mathrm V}{\mathrm T}=\frac{\mathrm R}{\mathrm P}\\ \mathrm{dS}={\mathrm C}_{\mathrm P} \frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm T}-\frac{\mathrm R}{\mathrm p}\mathrm{dP}\\ {\mathrm S}_2-{\mathrm S}_1={\mathrm C}_\mathrm P\ln\frac{{\mathrm T}_2}{{\mathrm T}_1}-\mathrm{Rln}\frac{{\mathrm P}_2}{{\mathrm P}_1}\\\\\end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 65 An engine working on air standard Otto cycle is supplied with air at 0.1 MPa and [latex]35^{\circ}C[/latex]. The compression ratio is 8.  The heat supplied is 500 kJ/kg.   Property data for air: [latex]c_{p}[/latex] = 1.005 kJ/kg K, [latex]c_{v}[/latex] = 0.718 kJ/kg K, R = 0.287 kJ/kg K. The maximum temperature (in K) of the cycle is _________ (correct to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} P_{1}=0.1 \mathrm{MPa}, T_{1}=35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=308 \mathrm{K} \\ \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}=n=8 \\ Q_{s}=500 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ c_{p}=1.005 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ c_{v}=0.718 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ R=0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ \gamma=\frac{c_{p}}{c_{v}}=1.399 \simeq 1.40 \\ T_{3}=T_{\max }=? \end{array}[/latex] For process 1-2 [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma} &=P_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma} \\ P_{2} &=P_{1}\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma}=0.1 \times(8)^{1.4} \\ P_{2} &=1.8379 \mathrm{MPa}\\ \text{and}\qquad \frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{T_{1}} &=\frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{T_{2}} \Rightarrow T_{2} \frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{P_{1} V_{1}} T_{1} \\ T_{2} &=\frac{1.8379 \times 1}{0.1 \times 8} \times 308 \\ T_{2} &=707.6 \mathrm{K}\\ \text{For process } 2 \rightarrow 3 \\ Q_{s}&=C_{V}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right)=500 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}\\ 0.718\left(T_{3}-707.6\right) &=500 \\ T_{3} &=1403.97 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 66 A tank of volume 0.05 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]  contains a mixture of saturated water and saturated steam at [latex]200^{\circ}C[/latex] . The mass of the liquid present is 8 kg.  The entropy (in kJ/kg K) of the mixture is ___________ (correct to two decimal places). Property data for saturated steam and water are: At [latex]200^{\circ}C[/latex] , [latex]p_{sat}[/latex] = 1.5538 MPa [latex]v_{f}[/latex]  = 0.001157 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] /kg,  [latex]v_{g}[/latex]  = 0.12736 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] /kg [latex]s_{fg}[/latex] =4.1014 kJ/kg K, [latex]s_{f}[/latex]= 2.3309 kJ/kg K
solution: Total volume of tank (V) = 0.05 m3 Means of liquid ([latex]m_{2}[/latex]) = 8 kg [latex]\begin{aligned} x &=\frac{m_{v}}{m_{v}+m_{L}}(\text { dryness fraction }) \\ V &=V_{L}+v_{v} \\ \text{where, } &V_{L}-\text{ liquid in tank} \\&V_{v} - \text{ vapour in tank}\\ V_{V} &=m_{v} v_{v} \\ v_{v} &=v_{g} @ 200^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ &=0.12736 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \\ V_{V} &=m_{L} v_{L} \\ v_{L} &=v_{f} @ 200^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ &=0.001157 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \\ V_{L} &=8 \times 0.001157=9.256 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ 0.05 &=9.256 \times 10^{-3}+\mathrm{V}_{V} \\ V_{V} &=0.0474 \mathrm{m}^{3}\\ \text{So,}\qquad 0.04074 &=m_{v} \times 0.12736 \\ m_{v} &=0.3198 \mathrm{kg} \\ x &=\frac{0.3198}{0.3198+8} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x &=0.0384 \end{aligned}[/latex] Specific entropy of mixture(s) [latex] \begin{aligned} s&=s_{f}+x s_{f g} \\ s&=2.3309+0.0384 \times 4.1014 \\ s&=2.4884 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 An ideal gas undergoes a process from state  1 [latex](T_{1} = 300K, p_{1} = 100kPa)[/latex]  to state 2 [latex](T_{2} = 600K, p_{2} = 500kPa)[/latex]. The specific heats of the ideal gas are : [latex]C_{p} = 1kJ/kg-K[/latex] and [latex]C_{v} = 0.7kJ/kg-K[/latex] . The change in specific entropy of the ideal gas from state 1 to state 2 (in kJ/kg-K) is ________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: Ideal gas [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { State-1: } T_{1}=300 \mathrm{K}, P_{1}=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \text { State-2: } T_{2}=600 \mathrm{K}, P_{2}=500 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \begin{aligned} c_{p}=1 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{K}, c_{p}-c_{v}&=R, c_{v}=0.7 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{K} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad c_{p}-c_{v}&= 1-0.7=R \\ R &=0.3 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{K} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex] Change in specific entropy [latex] \begin{aligned} s_{2}-s_{1} &=c_{p} \ln \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}-R \ln \frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}} \\ &=1 \times \ln \frac{600}{300}-0.3 \ln \frac{500}{100}=0.21 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 Which one of the following statements is correct for a superheated vapour?
solution:
[latex] P_{\text {sat }} @ T_{1} \rightarrow [/latex] saturation pressure at [latex] T_{1} [/latex] temperature [latex] P_{1} \rightarrow [/latex] pressure of superheated vapour at state 1 [latex]
P_{1} \lt P_{\text {sat }} @_{T_{1}}[/latex]

options.A: Its pressure is less than the saturation pressure at a given temperature.
options.B: Its temperature is less than the saturation temperature at a given pressure.
options.C: Its volume is less than the volume of the saturated vapour at a given temperature.
options.D: Its enthalpy is less than the enthalpy of the saturated vapour at a given pressure.

question: Question 69 The volume and temperature of air (assumed to be an ideal gas) in a closed vessel is 2.87 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]  and 300K, respectively. The gauge pressure indicated by a manometer fitted to the wall of the vessel is 0.5bar. If the gas constant of air is [latex]R=287\, J/kg\! \cdot \! K[/latex]  and the atmospheric pressure is 1 bar, the mass of air (in kg) in the vessel is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{g}&=5 \mathrm{bar}=50 \mathrm{kPa} \\ R&=287 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK}=0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}^{\mathrm{K}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Ideas gas equation: [latex] P V=m R T[/latex] Here P is absolute pressure: [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=P_{a b s}=P_{\text {gauge }}+P_{\text {atm }} \\ &=50+101.325=151.325 \mathrm{kPa} \\ m &=\frac{P V}{R T}=\frac{151.325 \times 2.87}{0.287 \times 300}=5.04 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 70 One kg of an ideal gas (gas constant R=287 J/kg.K) undergoes an irreversible process from state-1 (1 bar,300K) to state -2 (2 bar, 300 K). The change in specific entropy ([latex]s_{2}-s_{1}[/latex]) of the gas (in J/[latex]kg\cdot K[/latex]) in the process is ______
solution: Change in specific entropy of ideal gas [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{f}-s_{i} &=c_{p} \ln \frac{T_{f}}{T_{i}}-R \ln \frac{P_{f}}{P_{i}} \\ &=1005 \ln \frac{300}{300}-287 \ln \frac{2}{1} \\ &=0-287 \ln 2=-198.93 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg}^{-k} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 A calorically perfect gas (specific heat at constant pressure 1000 J/[latex]kg\cdot K[/latex] ) enters and leaves a gas turbine with the same velocity. The temperatures of the gas at turbine entry and exit are 1100 K and 400 K, respectively. The power produced is 4.6 MW and heat escapes at the rate of 300 kJ/s through the turbine casing. The mass flow rate of the gas (in kg/s) through the turbine is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} c_{p}&1\mathrm{kJ}/\mathrm{kg-K}\\ V_{i}&=V_{e}(\text { Inlet and exit velocity same }) \\ \dot{W}_{C . V} &=4.6 \mathrm{MW}=4.6 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{kW} \\ \dot{Q} &=300 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying SFEE, [latex] \begin{aligned} \dot{m}(h_{i}+\frac{1}{2} V_{i}^{2}+g z_{i})+ \dot{Q} &=\dot{m}(h_{e}+\frac{1}{2} V_{e}^{2}+g z_{e})+\dot{W}_{C . V} \\ \dot{m}[c_{p}(T_{i}-T_{e})]+\dot{Q}&=\dot{W}_{C . V} \quad \text { (Let } z_{i}=z_{e}) \\ \dot{m}[1 \times(1100-400)]+(-300)&=4.6 \times 10^{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \dot{m}&=7 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 In the Rankine cycle for a steam power plant the turbine entry and exit enthalpies are 2803 kJ/kg and 1800 kJ/kg, respectively. The enthalpies of water at pump entry and exit are 121 kJ/kg and 124 kJ/kg, respectively. The specific steam consumption (in kg/k W.h) of the cycle is _______
solution: Given data [latex]h_{1}=2803\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} h_{2} &=1800 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{3} &=121 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{4} &=124 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{T} &=h_{1}-h_{2} \\ &=2803-1800=1003 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{P} &=h_{4}-h_{3} \\ &=124-121=3 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{\text {net }} &=w_{T}-w_{P}=1003-3 \\ &=1000 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \mathrm{SSC} &=\frac{3600}{W_{\text {net }}}=\frac{3600}{1000}=3.6 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 A mass m of a perfect gas at pressure [latex]P_{1}[/latex]  and volume [latex]V_{1}[/latex]  undergoes an isothermal process. The final pressure is [latex]P_{2}[/latex]  and volume is [latex]V_{2}[/latex]. The work done on the system is considered positive. If R is the gas constant and T is the temperature, then the work done in the process is
solution: Work done on the system is considered as positive, so [latex] \delta W=-P d V[/latex] (-ve sign is taken as dV is-ve during compression) [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=-\int_{1}^{2} P d V=-\int_{1}^{2} m R T \frac{d V}{V} \\ &=-m R T \int_{1}^{2} \frac{d V}{V}=-m R T \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \\ &=-m R T \ln \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=-P_{1} V_{1} \ln \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 74 Air contains 79% N2 and 21%  [latex]O_{2}[/latex] on a molar basis. Methane ([latex]CH_{4}[/latex]) is burned with 50% excess air than required stoichiometrically. Assuming complete combustion of methane, the molar percentage of [latex]N_{2}[/latex]  in the products is _______________
solution: Stoichiometrically balanced equation for combustion of [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4[/latex] [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4+2{\mathrm O}_2\rightarrow{\mathrm{CO}}_2+2{\mathrm H}_2\mathrm O[/latex] Actual moles of [latex]{\mathrm{O}}_2[/latex] used [latex]=2\times\left(\frac{150}{100}\right)=3[/latex] moles of [latex]{\mathrm{O}}_2[/latex] Actual equation [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4+3{\mathrm o}_2\rightarrow{\mathrm{Co}}_2+2{\mathrm H}_2\mathrm o+{\mathrm O}_2[/latex] Consider Air instead of pure [latex]{\mathrm{O}}_2[/latex] [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4+\left[3{\mathrm o}_2+3\left(\frac{79}{21}\right){\mathrm N}_2\right]\rightarrow{\mathrm{Co}}_2+2{\mathrm H}_2\mathrm O+{\mathrm O}_2+\frac{79}7\mathrm N2[/latex] Total moles in product  [latex]=1+2+1+\frac{79}7=15.285[/latex] Molar percentage of [latex]{\mathrm N}_2=\frac{11.285}{15.285}\times100=73.830\%[/latex]

question: Question 75 The Pressure ratio across a gas turbine (for air, specific heat at constant pressure,[latex]c_{\textrm{p}}[/latex] 1040 J / kg .K and ratio of specific heats, [latex]\gamma =1.4[/latex]  ) is 10. If the inlet temperature to the turbine is 1200K and the isentropic efficiency is 0.9, the gas temperature at turbine exit is ______ K.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given data:}\;\mathrm{c}_{p}&=1040 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} ; \gamma=1.4 ; r_{p}=10; \\ T_{3}&=1200 \mathrm{K};\;\eta=0.9 \\ \frac{T_{7}}{T_{4 s}}&=\left(r_{p}\right) \frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1200}{T_{4 s}} &=(10)^{(1.4-1) / 1.4} \\ \text { or } \quad T_{4 s} &=621.53 \mathrm{K} \\ \eta_{T} &=\frac{T_{3}-T_{4}}{T_{3}-T_{4 s}} \\ 0.9 &=\frac{1200-T_{4}}{1200-621.53} \\ \text{or}\qquad T_{4} &=679.4 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 One kg of an ideal gas (gas constant, R = 400 J/kg.K; specific heat at constant volume,[latex]c_{\textrm{v}}[/latex] =1000 J / kg .K) at 1 bar, and 300 K is contained in a sealed rigid cylinder. During an adiabatic process, 100kJ of work is done on the system by a stirrer. The increase in entropy of the system is _________ J/K.
solution: [latex]m=1 \mathrm{kg} ; \quad R=400 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{k}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} c_{v}&=1000 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{K} \\ T_{i}&=300 \mathrm{K} ; P_{i}=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ W&=100 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying first law: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\Delta U+W\\ \Rightarrow \quad 0&=m c_{v}\left(T_{f}-T_{i}\right)+(-100) \times 10^{3} J \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0&=1 \times 1000 \times\left(T_{f}-300\right)-100 \times 10^{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{f}&=400 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Entropy change for ideal gas [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S &=m\left[C_{v} \ln \frac{T_{f}}{T_{i}}+R \ln \frac{V_{f}}{V_{i}}\right] \quad \because V_{i}=V_{f} \\ &=1 \times\left[1000 \ln \frac{400}{300}+0\right] \\ &=287.682 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 A heat pump absorbs 10kW of heat from outside environment at 250 K while absorbing 15 kW of work. It delivers the heat to a room that must be kept warm at 300K. The coefficient of Performance (COP) of the heat pump is _________.
solution: Given that: [latex] \dot{Q}_{L}=10 \mathrm{kW} [/latex] [latex]\dot{W}=15 \mathrm{kW}[/latex] Applying first law on heat pump [latex] \begin{array}{c} \dot{Q}_{L}+\dot{W}=\dot{Q}_{H} \\ 10 \mathrm{kW}+15 \mathrm{kW}=\dot{Q}_{H} \\ \dot{Q}_{H}=25 \mathrm{kW} \\ (\mathrm{COP})_{\mathrm{H.P.}}=\frac{\dot{Q}_{H}}{\dot{W}}=\frac{25 \mathrm{kW}}{15 \mathrm{kW}}=1.67 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 78 The molar Specific heat at constant volume of an ideal gas in equal to 2.5 times the universal gas constant(8.314 J/mol K). When the temperature increases by 100 K, the change in molar specific enthalpy is__________ J/mol.
solution: Given that:[latex] \bar{C}_{v}=2.5 \bar{R} [/latex] [latex] \bar{C}_{v} \rightarrow [/latex] Molar specific heat at constant volume [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{C}_{p}-\bar{C}_{v}&=\bar{R}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \bar{C}_{p}&=\bar{R}+\bar{C}_{v}=\bar{R}+2.5 \bar{R} \\ \bar{C}_{p}&=3.5 \bar{R} \end{aligned}[/latex] Molar specific enthalpy change of ideal gas (A H) [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta H &=n \bar{C}_{p} \Delta T \\ \overline{\Delta H} &=\frac{\Delta H}{n}=\overline{\Delta H}=\bar{C}_{p} \Delta T \\ &=3.5 \times 8.314 \times 100 \\ \overline{\Delta H} &=2909.9 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mole} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 79 In a 3-stage air compressor, the inlet pressure is [latex]p_{1}[/latex], discharge pressure is [latex]p_{4}[/latex] and the intermediate pressures are [latex]p_{2}[/latex] and [latex]p_{3}[/latex] ( [latex]p_{2}\lt p_{3}[/latex]). The total pressure ratio of the compressor is 10 and the pressure ratios of the stages are equal. If [latex]p_{1}[/latex] = 100 kPa, the value of the pressure [latex]p_{3}[/latex] (in kPa) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{p_{4}}{p_{1}}&=10 \\ \frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}&=\frac{p_{3}}{p_{2}}=\frac{p_{4}}{p_{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] To calculate [latex]p_{3}=? [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{4}}{p_{3}} \times \frac{p_{3}}{p_{2}} \times \frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}&=10 \\ r_{p} \times r_{p} \times r_{p}&=10 \\ r_{p}^{3} &=10 \\ r_{p} &=(10)^{1 / 3}\\ p_{2}&=r_{p} p_{1} \\ p_{3}&=r_{p} p_{2}=r_{p}^{2} p_{1}=(10)^{2 / 3} \times 100\\ &=464.16 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 Steam at an initial enthalpy of 100 kJ/kg and inlet velocity of 100 m/s, enters an insulated horizontal nozzle. It leaves the nozzle at 200 m/s. The exit enthalpy (in kJ/kg) is __________
solution: Applying steady flow energy equation between section 1 and 2. [latex] h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}+g z_{1}+q=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2}+g_{2}+w [/latex] where q=0 insulated nozzle [latex] z_{1}=z_{2} \quad[/latex] horizontal nozzle w=0  always for nozzle [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2} &=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2} \\ h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2000} &=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2000} \end{aligned}[/latex] where [latex] h_{1}[/latex] and [latex]h_{2}[/latex] are in kJ/kg and [latex]V_{1}[/latex] and [latex]V_{2}[/latex] are in m/s [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore 100+\frac{(100)^{2}}{2000} &=h_{2}+\frac{(200)^{2}}{2000} \\ 100+5 &=h_{2}+20 \\ \text{or}\quad h_{2} &=85 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 81 The INCORRECT statement about the characteristics of critical point of a pure substance is that
solution: At critical point liquid directly converts vapour phase.

options.A: there is no constant temperature vaporization process
options.B: it has point of inflection with zero slope
options.C: the ice directly converts from solid phase to vapor phase
options.D: saturated liquid and saturated vapor states are identical

question: Question 82 A reversible cycle receives 40 kJ of heat from one heat source at a temperature of [latex]127^{\circ}[/latex]C and 37 kJ from another heat source at [latex]97^{\circ}[/latex]C. The heat rejected (in kJ) to the heat sink at  [latex]47^{\circ}[/latex]C is __________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{1} &=127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(127+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=400 \mathrm{K}\\ T_{2} &=97^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(97+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=370 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{3} &=47^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(47+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=320 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] For reversible cycle Clausius inequality, [latex] \oint \frac{S Q}{T}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad \frac{40}{400}+\frac{37}{370}-\frac{Q_{3}}{320}&=0 \\ 0.1+0.1&=\frac{Q_{3}}{320}\\ \text{or}\qquad Q_{3}&=64 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 83 A piston-cylinder device initially contains 0.4 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] of air (to be treated as an ideal gas) at 100 kPa and [latex]80^{\circ}[/latex]C. The air is now isothermally compressed to 0.1 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] .The work done during this process is ________ kJ. (Take the sign convention such that work done on the system is negative)
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} V_{1}=0.4 \mathrm{m}^{3} ; \quad p_{1}=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ T_{1}=80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(80+273) \mathrm{K}=353 \mathrm{K} \\ V_{2}=0.1 \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{array}[/latex] For isothermal process [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=p_{1} V_{1} \log _{e} \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \\ &=100 \times 0.4 \log _{e} \frac{0.1}{0.4} \\ &=-55.45 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 84 Consider a simple gas turbine (Brayton) cycle and a gas turbine cycle with perfect regeneration. In both the cycles, the pressure ratio is 6 and the ratio of the specific heats of the working medium is 1.4. The ratio of minimum to maximum temperatures is 0.3 (with temperatures expressed in K) in the regenerative cycle. The ratio of the thermal efficiency of the simple cycle to that of the regenerative cycle is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given: }r_{p}&=6\\ y&=1.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \frac{T_{\max }}{T_{\min }}=0.3 \quad[/latex] [for regenerative cycle ] [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_\text { Tregenerative cycle } &=1-\frac{T_{\max }}{T_{\min }} \times\left(r_{p}\right)^{(\gamma-1) / \gamma} \\ &=1-0.3\times(6)^{\frac{0.4}{1.4}}\\ &=0.49945 \times(6)^{\frac{0.4}{1.4}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta_{\text {simplecycle }} &=1-\frac{1}{\left(r_{p}\right)^{(\gamma-1) / \gamma}} \\ &=1-\left(r_{p}\right)^{(1-\gamma) / \gamma} \\ &=1-(6)^{-\frac{0.4}{1.4}}=0.4066 \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Required ratio } &=\frac{\eta_{\text {simple cycle }}}{\eta_{\text {regenerative cycle }}} \\ &=\frac{0.40666}{0.49945}=0.8141 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 The heat removal rate from a refrigerated space and the power input to the compressor are 7.2 kW and 1.8 kW, respectively. The coefficient of performance (COP) of the refrigerator is ______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{2}&=7.2 \mathrm{kW} \\ W&=1.8 \mathrm{kW} \\ (\mathrm{COP})_{R} &=\frac{Q_{2}}{W} \\ &=\frac{7.2}{1.8}=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 The internal energy of an ideal gas is a function of
solution: Internal energy for ideal gas depends on only Temperature, whereas an real gas depends on both pressure and temperature.

question: Question 87 In a steam power plant operating on an ideal Rankine cycle, superheated steam enters the turbine at 3  MPa  and [latex]350^{\circ}C[/latex] .The condenser pressure is 75 kPa. The thermal efficiency of the cycle is ________ percent. Given data: For saturated liquid, at P = 75 kPa. [latex]h_{f}=384.39[/latex]  kJ/kg, [latex]v_{f}=0.001037 m^{3}/kg[/latex]  , [latex]s_{f}=1.213[/latex]  kJ/kg-K At 75 kPa, [latex]h_{fg}[/latex] =2278.6 kJ/kg,[latex]s_{fg}[/latex] =6.2434 kJ/kg-K At P = 3 MPa and T = [latex]350^{\circ}C[/latex]  (superheated steam), h = 3115.3kJ/kg, s = 6.7428 kJ/kg-K
solution: Calculating dryness fraction at point 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{1} &=S_{2} \\ 6.7248 &=s_{f}+x_{2} s_{f g} \\ &=1.213+x_{2} \times 6.2434 \\ x_{2} &=\frac{6.7428-1.213}{6.2434}\\ &=0.8857 \end{aligned}[/latex] Calculating enthalpy at point 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{2} &=h_{f}+x_{2} h_{f g} \\ &=384.39+0.8857 \times 2278.6 \\ &=2402.546 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \text { Given: } \quad h_{1} &=3115.3 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{4} &=h_{3}+v d P \\ &=384.39+0.001037 \times[3000-75] \\ &=387.423 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \text { Pump work } &=v d P \\ &=0.001037 \times[3000-75] \\ &=3.033 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{\text {net }} &=w_{T}-w_{P}=\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)-3.033 \\ &=(3115.3-2402.546)-3.033 \\ &=709.721 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}\\ \text{Heat input }&=h_{1}-h_{4}\\ &=3115.3-387.423 \\ &=2727.877 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}\\ \text{Efficiency of cycle }&=\frac{\text { Work delivered }}{\text { Heat input }} \\ & \frac{709.721}{2727877} \\ &=0.2601=26.01 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 88 An ideal gas undergoes a reversible process in which the pressure varies linearly with volume. The conditions at the start (subscript 1) and at the end (subscript 2) of the process with usual notation are: [latex]p_{1}[/latex]  = 100 kPa, [latex]V_{1}[/latex]  =0.2 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]  and [latex]p_{2}[/latex]  =200 kPa , [latex]v_{2}[/latex] = 0.1 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]  and the gas constant, R = 0.275 kJ/kg-K. The magnitude of the work required for the process (in kJ) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} p_{1}=100 \mathrm{kPa}, v_{1}=0.2 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ p_{2}=200 \mathrm{kPa}, v_{2}=0.1 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ R=0.275 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ p \propto V \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] p-V diagram will be a straight line Work done is equal to area under p-V diagram, [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \text { Work } &=\frac{1}{2}(100+200) \times(0.2-0.1) \\ &=15 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex] The work is done on the gas, since the process is compression. since only magnitude is asked hence final answer is without -ve sign.

question: Question 89 For water at [latex]25^{\circ}C[/latex] , [latex]dp_{s}/dT_{s}=0.189 KPa/K[/latex]  ([latex]p_{s}[/latex]   is the saturation pressure in kPa and [latex]T_{s}[/latex]  is the saturation temperature in K) and the specific volume of dry saturated vapour is 43.38  [latex]m^{3}[/latex] /kg. Assume that the specific volume of liquid is negligible in comparison with that of vapour. Using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation, an estimate of the enthalpy of evaporation of water at [latex]25^{\circ}C[/latex]  (in kJ/kg) is __________
solution: At [latex]25^{\circ}C, \frac{dp_s}{dT_s}=0.189kPa/K[/latex] Specific volume of saturated vapour, [latex]v_s=43.38 m^3/kg[/latex] From clausis-clapeyron equation neglecting specific volume of liquid [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dp_s}{dT_s}&=\frac{h_{fg}}{T_s \times v_s}\\ h_{fg}&=\text{Enthalpy of vapourisation}\\ 0.189&=\frac{h_{fg}}{(25+273) \times 43.38}\\ \therefore \;\; h_{fg}&=2443.248\; kJ/kg \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 90 The INCORRECT statement about regeneration in vapor power cycle is that
solution: Regeneration is used to decreases the irreversibility between the hot and cold fluids in the boiler drum.

options.A: it increases the irreversibility by adding the liquid with higher energy content to the steam generator
options.B: heat is exchanged between the expanding fluid in the turbine and the compressed fluid before heat addition
options.C: the principle is similar to the principle of Stirling gas cycle
options.D: it is practically implemented by providing feed water heaters

question: Question 91 Propane (C3H8) is burned in an oxygen atmosphere with 10% deficit oxygen with respect to the stoichiometric requirement. Assuming no hydrocarbons in the products, the volume percentage of CO in the products is __________
solution: For stoichiometric burning (i.e., chemically correct), number of moles of [latex]\mathrm{O}_{2}[/latex] required =5. As it si burnt with 10 % deficient \mathrm{O}_{2} , it will generate CO. That is, the new equation is [latex] \mathrm{C}_{3} \mathrm{H}_{8}+0.9 \times 5 \mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow \alpha \mathrm{CO}_{2}+\beta \mathrm{CO}+\gamma \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}[/latex] Balancing carbon atoms, we get [latex] 3=\alpha+\beta \quad \cdots(i)[/latex] Balancing hydrogen atoms, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 8&=2 \gamma\\ \text{or }\quad \gamma&=4\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Balancing oxygen atoms, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 0.9 \times 10 &=2 \alpha+\beta+\gamma \\ 9 &=2 \alpha+\beta+4 \\ 5 &=2 \alpha+\beta\quad \cdots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Eq. (ii) - Eq.
