(i), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 2&=\alpha\\ \text{or }\quad \alpha&=2 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{C}_{3} \mathrm{H}_{8}+\mathrm{aO}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{bCO}_{2}+\mathrm{cH}_{2} \mathrm{O}[/latex] Balancing carbon atoms, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 3&=b\\ \text{or } \quad b&=3\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Balancing hydrogen atoms, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 8&=2 c\\ \text{or}\quad c&=4\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Balancing oxygen atoms, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 a &=2 b+c \\ 2 a &=2 \times 3+4=10 \\ a &=5 \end{aligned}[/latex] Substituting [latex]\alpha=2[/latex] in Eq. (ii), we get [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad 5=2 \times 2 \times \beta \\ \text { or } \quad \beta=1 \\ \therefore \mathrm{C}_{3} \mathrm{H}_{8}+4.5 \mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow 4 \mathrm{CO}_{2}+\mathrm{CO}+4 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \end{array}[/latex] The volume percentage of CO in the product [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\left(\frac{\beta}{\alpha+\beta+\gamma}\right) \times 100 \\ =\left(\frac{1}{2+1+4}\right) \times 100 \\ =14.28 \% \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 92 Which of the following statements are TRUE with respect to heat and work? (i) They are boundary phenomena (ii) They are exact differentials (iii) They are path functions
solution:
Heat and work are boundary phenomenon and 
depend upon the path followed between initial 
and final states. Both heat and work are inexact 
differential since [latex]
\begin{array}{l}
\int_{1}^{2} d W \neq W_{2}-W_{1} \\
\int_{1}^{2} d Q \neq Q_{2}-Q_{1}
\end{array}[/latex] Hence statement (ii) alone is wrong. Answer should be (B).

question: Question 93 A mixture of ideal gases has the following composition by mass: If the universal gas constant is 8314 J/kmol-K, the characteristic gas constant of the mixture         (in J/kg-K) is ________
solution: Equation state for [latex]N_{2}, [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{N_{2}} V&=m_{N_{2}} R_{N_{2}} T\\ \text{or}\quad \frac{p_{N_{2}} V}{T}&=m_{N_{2}} R_{N_{2}} \\ \text { where }\quad R_{N_{2}}&=\frac{\bar{R}}{M_{N_{2}}}\\ \therefore \quad \frac{p_{N_{2}} V}{T}&=\frac{m_{N_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{N_{2}}} \qquad\cdots(i)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Similarly for [latex]\mathrm{O}_{2}[/latex] and [latex] \mathrm{CO}_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{O_{2}} V}{T} &=\frac{m_{O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{O_{2}}} \qquad\cdots(ii)\\ \text { and } \frac{p_{C O_{2}} V}{T} &=\frac{m_{C O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\qquad\cdots(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Adding Eqs. (i), (ii) and (iii), we get [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{V}{T}\left(p_{N_{2}}+p_{O_{2}}+p_{C O_{2}}\right)=\frac{m_{N_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{m_{O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{C O_{2}}} \\ \frac{V}{T} p=\left(\frac{m_{N_{2}}}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{m_{O_{2}}}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \cdots(iv) \end{array}[/latex] where [latex]p=p_{N_{2}}+p_{O_{2}}+p_{C O_{2}}[/latex] pressure of mixture Equation of state for mixture of ideal gas [latex] p V=m R T[/latex] [latex] \text{or}\frac{p V}{T}=m R[/latex] Equating Eqs. (iv) and (v), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} m R &=\left(\frac{m_{N_{2}}}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{m_{O_{2}}}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \\ m R &=\left(\frac{0.60 m}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{0.30 m}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \\ P &=\left(\frac{0.60}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{0.30}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{0.10}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \\ &=\left(\frac{0.60}{28}+\frac{0.30}{32}+\frac{0.10}{44}\right) \times 8314 \\&=(0.02142+0.00937+0.00227) \times 8314 \\ &=0.03306 \times 8134 \\ &=274.86 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 94 One side of a wall is maintained at 400 K and the other at 300 K. The rate of heat transfer through the wall is 1000 W and the surrounding temperature is 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Assuming no generation of heat within the wall, the irreversibility (in W) due to heat transfer through the wall is ________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{1}=400 \mathrm{K} ; & T_{2}=300 \mathrm{K} ; Q=1000 \mathrm{W} \\ T_{0} &=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(25+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=298 \mathrm{K} \\ \Delta S_{\mathrm{sys}} &=-\frac{Q}{T_{1}}+\frac{Q}{T_{2}} \\ &=-\frac{1000}{400}+\frac{1000}{300} \\ &=-2.5+3.333=0.833 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{K}\\ & Irreversibility,\\ I &=T_{0} \Delta S_{\text {uni }} \\ &=T_{0}\left(\Delta S_{\text {sys }}+\Delta S_{\text {surr }}\right) \\ &=298(0.833+0) \qquad \because \Delta S_{\text {surf }}=0 \\ &=248.23 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 95 Steam enters a turbine at 30 bar, [latex]300^{\circ}[/latex] (u = 2750 kJ/kg, h = 2993 kJ/kg) and exits the turbine as saturated liquid at 15 kPa (u = 225 kJ/kg, h = 226 kJ/kg). Heat loss to the surrounding is 50 kJ/kg of steam flowing through the turbine. Neglecting changes in kinetic energy and potential energy, the work output of the turbine (in kJ/kg of steam) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given data: }\\ \text{At inlet,}\; u_{1} &=2750\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ h_{1}&=2993\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ \text { At exit }\;u_{2}&=225\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ h_{2}&=226\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ q_{1-2}&=-50\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ \text{Specific work done,}\\ w_{1-2} &=\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)+q_{1-2} \\ &=(2993-226)-5 \\ &=2717 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 An air-standard Diesel cycle consists of the following processes: 1-2:  Air is compressed isentropically. 2-3:  Heat is added at constant pressure. 3-4:  Air expands isentropically to the original volume. 4-1:  Heat is rejected at constant volume. If [latex]\gamma[/latex] and T denote the specific heat ratio and temperature, respectively, the efficiency of the cycle is
solution: Heat added to the system [latex]Q_H=c_p(T_3-T_2)[/latex] Heat rejected to the system [latex]Q_L=c_v(T_4-T_1)[/latex] Therefore, Efficinecy is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta&=1-\frac{Q_L}{Q_H}\\ \eta&=1-\frac{c_v}{c_p}\frac{T_4-T_1}{T_3-T_2}\\ \eta&=1-\frac{T_4-T_1}{\gamma (T_3-T_2)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 97 A rigid container of volume 0.5 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] contains 1.0 kg of water at [latex]120^{\circ}C[/latex] ([latex]v_{f}[/latex] = 0.00106 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/kg, [latex]v_{g}[/latex]= 0.8908 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/kg). The state of water is
solution: [latex]v=\frac{V}{m}=\frac{0.5}{1}=0.5 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] It is lying between [latex]v_{f}[/latex] and [latex]v_{g}[/latex]. The state of water is a mixture of saturated liquid and saturated vapour.

options.C: a mixture of saturated liquid and saturated vapor

question: Question 98 In a Rankine cycle, the enthalpies at turbine entry and outlet are 3159 kJ/kg and 2187 kJ/kg, respectively. If the specific pump work is 2 kJ/kg, the specific steam consumption (in kg/kW-h) of the cycle based on net output is _______________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} w_{\text {turbine }} &=h_{1}-h_{2} \\ &=(3159-2187) \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{\text {net }} &=w_{\text {turbine }}-w_{\text {pump }} \\ &=972-2=970 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Specific steam consumption [latex] =\frac{3600}{970} \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh}=3.711 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh}[/latex] Specific steam consumption is amount of steam required to produce 1 kWh(or) 3600 kJ of work.

question: Question 99 For the same values of peak pressure, peak temperature and heat rejection, the correct order of efficiencies for Otto, Dual and Diesel cycles is
solution: For same peak pressure, peak temperature and heat rejection [latex]\eta_{Dieseal}\gt\eta_{Dual}\gt\eta_{Otto}[/latex] For same compression ratio and heat rejection [latex]\eta_{Otto}\gt\eta_{Dual}\gt\eta_{Dieseal}[/latex]

question: Question 100 One kg of air (R = 287 J/kg-K) undergoes an irreversible process between equilibrium state 1      ([latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]C, 0.9 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] ) and equilibrium state 2 ([latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]C, 0.6 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] ). The change in entropy [latex]s_{2}[/latex]-[latex]s_{1}[/latex] (in J/kg-K)    is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} s_{2}-s_{1} &=c_{v} \ln \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}+R \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \\ &=R \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \quad \because T_{1}=T_{2} \\ &=287 \ln \frac{0.6}{0.9}=-116.368 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 101 Work is done on an adiabatic system due to which its velocity changes from 10 m/s to 20 m/s, elevation increases by 20 m and temperature increases by 1 K. The mass of the system is 10 kg,  [latex]C_{v}[/latex]  = 100 J/(kg.K) and gravitational acceleration is 10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex] . If there is no change in any other component of the energy of the system, the magnitude of total work done (in kJ) on the system is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta Q&=d E+\delta W \\ 0&=\Delta U+\Delta K \cdot E+\Delta P \cdot E+\delta W \\ 0&=m c_{v} d T+\frac{1}{2} m\left(V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}\right)+m g \\ &\qquad +(z_{2}-z_{1})+\delta W\\ 0&=10 \times 0.1 \times 1+\frac{1}{2} \times 10\left((20)^{2}-(10)^{2}\right) \times 10^{-3} \\ &\qquad +10 \times 10 \times 20 \times 10^{-3}+\delta W \\ \therefore \quad \delta W&=-4.5 \mathrm{kJ} \\ &=4.5 \mathrm{kJ}, \text{work don on the system} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 102 A rope-brake dynamometer attached to the crank shaft of an I.C. engine measures a brake power of 10 kW when the speed of rotation of the shaft is 400 rad/s. The shaft torque (in N-m) sensed by the dynamometer is ___________
solution: Brake power = Brake torque x angular velocity [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=T\omega \\ T&= \frac{P}{\omega }=\frac{P}{\left ( \frac{2 \pi N}{60} \right )}\\ &= \frac{10,000}{400}=25Nm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 103 The Van der Waals equation of state is [latex](p+\frac{a}{v^{2}})(v-b)=RT[/latex]  where p is pressure, v is specific volume, T is temperature and R is characteristic gas constant. The SI unit of a is
solution: [latex]p+\frac{a}{v^{2}},[/latex] where both the terms p and [latex]\frac{a}{v^{2}} [/latex]have same unit. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad p &=\frac{a}{v^{2}} \\ \frac{N}{m^{2}} &=\frac{a}{\left(m^{3} / k g\right)^{2}} \\ \frac{k g m}{s^{2}} \times \frac{1}{m^{2}} &=\frac{a \times(k g)^{2}}{m^{6}}\\ \text{or}\quad a&=m^{5} / k g s^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 104 Which of the following statements regarding a Rankine cycle with reheating are TRUE? (i) increase in average temperature of heat addition (ii) reduction in thermal efficiency (iii) drier steam at the turbine exit
solution: Rankine cycle with reheating: Advantages: (i) Increase in a average temperature of heat addition. (ii) Increase in thermal efficiency. (iii) Drier steam at the turbine exit i.e., decrease in moisture content of the steam at the low-pressure turbine exit, reducing the turbine blade erosion.

question:
Question 105 Steam enters a well insulated turbine and expands isentropically throughout. At an intermediate pressure, 20 percent of the mass is extracted for process heating and the remaining steam expands isentropically to 9 kPa. Inlet to turbine: P = 14 MPa, T =[latex]560^{\circ}C[/latex] , h = 3486 kJ/kg, s = 6.6 kJ/(kg.K) Intermediate stage: h = 2776 kJ/kg Exit of turbine: P = 9 kPa,  [latex]h_{f}[/latex] = 174 kJ/kg,  [latex]h_{g}[/latex] = 2574 kJ/kg,  [latex]s_{f}[/latex] = 0.6 kJ/(kg.K), [latex]s_{g}[/latex] = 8.1 kJ/(kg.K) If the flow rate of steam entering the turbine is 100 kg/s, then the work output (in MW) 
 is _________
solution: Given data: At turbine inlet: [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{1} &=3486 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \mathrm{s}_{1} &=6.6 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K} \\ m_{1} &=100 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] At intermediate stage: [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{2}&=2776 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ m_{2}&=0.2 \mathrm{m}_{1}=0.2 \times 100=20 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] At turbine exit: [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{3} &=9 \mathrm{kPa} \\ m_{3} &=0.8 \mathrm{m}_{1}=0.8 \times 100=80 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s}\\ \mathrm{At} \quad P_{3}&=9 \mathrm{kPa} \\ h_{f} &=174 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{g} &=2574 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ s_{f} &=0.6 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ s_{g} &=8.1 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ s_{3} &=s_{1}=s_{f}+x_{3}\left(s_{g}-s_{f}\right) \\ 6.6 &=0.6+x_{3}(8.1-0.6) \\ 6 &=7.5 x_{3} \\ \text{or}\quad x_{3} &=0.8\\ h_{3}&=h_{f}+x_{3}\left(h_{g}-h_{f}\right)\\ &=174+0.8(2574-174) \\ &=2094 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Work output, [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=m_{1}\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)+m_{3}\left(h_{2}-h_{3}\right) \\ &=100(3486-2776) \\ &\quad +80(2776-2094) \\ &=71000+54560 \\ &=125560 \mathrm{kW} \\ &=125.56 \mathrm{MW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 A well insulated rigid container of volume 1[latex]m^{3}[/latex]  contains 1.0 kg of an ideal gas [[latex]C_{p}[/latex] = 1000 J/(kg.K) and [latex]C_{v}[/latex] = 800 J/(kg.K)] at a pressure of [latex]10^{5}[/latex] Pa. A stirrer is rotated at constant rpm in the container for 1000 rotations and the applied torque is 100 N-m.  The final temperature of the gas (in K) is
solution: Work done = Torque [latex]\times[/latex] angular displacement [latex] \begin{aligned} &=100 \times 2 \pi \times 1000=-628.318 \mathrm{kJ} \\ p_{1} V_{1} &=m R T_{1} \\ T_{1}=\frac{p_{1} V_{1}}{m R} &=\frac{10^{2} \times 1}{0.2 \times 1}=500 \mathrm{K} \\ \therefore \quad R &=c_{p}-c_{v}=0.2 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{aligned}[/latex] According to 1 st law of thermodynamic [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad Q-W=\Delta U \\ -(-628.318) \mathrm{kJ}=m c_{v}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right) \\ \text { or } \quad T_{2}=500+\frac{628.318}{1 \times 0.8}=1285.39 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 107 Temperature of nitrogen in a vessel of volume 2 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]  is 288 K. A U-tube manometer connected to the vessel shows a reading of 70 cm of mercury (level higher in the end open to atmosphere). The universal gas constant is 8314 J/kmol-K, atmospheric pressure is 1.01325 bar, acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]  and density of mercury is 13600 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] . The mass of nitrogen (in kg) in the vessel is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \left(P_{\text {absolute }}\right) \text { of } N_{2}=[101.3 \mathrm{kPa}+w h] \mathrm{kPa} \\ =101.3+\left(13.6 \times 9.81 \times \frac{70}{100}\right) \mathrm{kPa} \\ =194.6 \mathrm{kPa} \end{array}[/latex] As [latex]N_{2}[/latex] being ideal gas, [latex] \begin{aligned} p V &=m R T \\ m &=\left(\frac{p V}{R T}\right) \mathrm{kg} \\ \text{where}\quad R &=\frac{8.314}{28}=0.296 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K}\\ \therefore \qquad m&=\frac{194.6 \times 2}{0.296 \times 288}\\ &=4.56 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 Air enters a diesel engine with a density of 1.0 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] . The compression ratio is 21. At steady state, the air intake is 30 x [latex]10^{-3}[/latex]  kg/s and the net work output is 15 kW. The mean effective pressure (in kPa) is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho &= 1kg/m^3\\ r&= \frac{V_1}{V_c}=21\\ m &=30 \times 10^{-3}kg/s \\ W&=15kW \\ V_1&=\frac{m}{\rho }=\frac{30 \times 10^{-3}}{1}m^3/s \\ &= 30 \times 10^{-3}m^3/s\\ V_c &=\frac{V_1}{r}=\frac{30 \times 10^{-3}}{21} \\ &= 1.428 \times 10^{-3}m^3/s\\ V_s&=V_1-V_c \\ &= 30 \times 10^{-3} -1.428 \times 10^{-3}\\ &= 28.572 \times 10^{-3}m^3/s \end{aligned}[/latex] Mean effective pressure, [latex]\rho _m=\frac{W}{V_s}=\frac{15}{28.572 \times 10^{-3}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=524.99kW\approx 525kW[/latex]

question: Question 109 A Carnot engine (CE-1) works between two temperature reservoirs A and B, where [latex]T_{A}[/latex] = 900 K and [latex]T_{B}[/latex]  = 500 K. A second Carnot engine (CE-2) works between temperature reservoirs B and C, where [latex]T_{C}[/latex]  = 300 K. In each cycle of CE-1 and CE-2, all the heat rejected by CE-1 to reservoir B is used by CE-2. For one cycle of operation, if the net Q absorbed by CE-1 from reservoir A is 150 MJ, the net heat rejected to reservoir C by CE-2 (in MJ) is ______________
solution: For Carnot engine (CE-2) [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{2}&=1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}}\\ \text{also}\qquad \eta_{2} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \therefore \quad 1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}}\\ \text{or}\qquad\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \frac{300}{500} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{\frac{5 \times 150}{9}}\\ \text{or}\qquad Q_{c}&=50 \mathrm{MJ} \end{aligned}[/latex] For Carnot engine (CE-2) [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{2}&=1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}}\\ \text{also}\qquad \eta_{2} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \therefore \quad 1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}}\\ \text{or}\qquad\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \frac{300}{500} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{\frac{5 \times 150}{9}}\\ \text{or}\qquad Q_{c}&=50 \mathrm{MJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 110 For an ideal gas with constant values of specific heats, for calculation of the specific enthalpy,
solution: For constant valves of specific heats dh = F(T) only So for calculation of specific enthalpy it is sufficient to know only the temperature.

options.A: it is sufficient to know only the temperature
options.B: both temperature and pressure are required to be known
options.C: both temperature and volume are required to be known
options.D: both temperature and mass are required to be known

question: Question 111 In a compression ignition engine, the inlet air pressure is 1 bar and the pressure at the end of isentropic compression is 32.42 bar. The expansion ratio is 8. Assuming ratio of specific heats ([latex]\gamma[/latex] ) as 1.4, the air standard efficiency (in percent) is _______
solution: Given, [latex]p_{1}=1[/latex] bar, [latex]p_{2}=32.42 [/latex] bar [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma &=\frac{C_{p}}{c_{v}}=1.4 \\ \frac{V_{4}}{V_{3}} &=\frac{V_{1}}{V_{3}}=8 \end{aligned}[/latex] For process 1-2 [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1} v_{1}^{\gamma}&=p_{2} v_{2}^{\gamma} \\ \therefore\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma}&=\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}=32.42 \\ \text { or } \quad \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}} &=(32.42)^{1 / 1.4}=11.999 \approx 12 \\ r_{c} &=\frac{V_{3}}{V_{2}}=\frac{V_{1}}{8} \times \frac{12}{V_{1}}=1.5 \\ \eta_{\text {Diesel }} &=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}\left[\frac{r_{C}^{\gamma}-1}{\gamma\left(r_{C}-1\right)}\right] \\ &=1-\frac{1}{12^{0.4}}\left[\frac{1.5^{1.4}-1}{1.4 \times 0.5}\right] \\ &=0.596=59.6 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 112 Steam with specific enthalpy (h) 3214 kJ/kg enters an adiabatic turbine operating at steady state with a flow rate 10 kg/s. As it expands, at a point where h is 2920 kJ/kg, 1.5 kg/s is extracted for heating purposes. The remaining 8.5 kg/s further expands to the turbine exit, where h = 2374 kJ/kg. Neglecting changes in kinetic and potential energies, the net power output (in kW) of the turbine   is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m_{1} &=10 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} ; \quad m_{2}=1.5 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} ; \quad m_{3}=8.5 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ h_{1} &=3214 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} ; \quad h_{2}=2920 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{3} &=2374 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ W_{T} &=m_{1}\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)+m_{3}\left(h_{2}-h_{3}\right) \\ &=10(3214-2920)+8.5(2920-2374) \\ &=7581 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 113 Two identical metal blocks L and M (specific heat = 0.4 kJ/kg.K), each having a mass of 5 kg, are initially at 313 K. A reversible refrigerator extracts heat from block L and rejects heat to block M until the temperature of block L reaches 293 K. The final temperature (in K) of block M is _______
solution: Given data: Specified heat, [latex] \begin{aligned} c&=0.4 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \text{ each body}\\ \text{Mass:}m&=5 \mathrm{kg} \quad \text { each body } \end{aligned}[/latex] Initial temperature, [latex] T_{1}=313 \mathrm{K} \quad \text { each body }[/latex] Final temprature of block L [latex] T_{2}=293 \mathrm{K}[/latex] Let [latex]\quad T_{f}=[/latex] Final temperature of block M, Entropy change of block L [latex] \Delta S_{L}=m c \log _{e} \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}[/latex] Entropy change of block M [latex] \Delta S_{M}=m c \log _{e} \frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}[/latex] Entropy change of universe, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S_{\text {univ }} &=\Delta S_{L}+\Delta S_{M} \\ &=mc \log _{e} \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}+mc \log _{e} \frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}} \end{aligned}[/latex] For a reversible refrigeration, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S_{\text {univ }}&=0 \\ m c \log _{e} \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}&+m_{c} \log _{e} \frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}=0\\ mc \log _{e} \frac{T_{2} T_{f}}{T_{1}^{2}}&=0\\ \text{or}\quad \log _{e} \frac{T_{2} T_{f}}{T_{1}^{2}}&=0\\ \text{or}\quad \frac{T_{2} T_{f}}{T_{1}^{2}} &=e^{0}=1 \\ T_{f} &=\frac{T_{1}^{2}}{T_{2}}=\frac{(313)^{2}}{293}=334.36 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 114 A closed system contains 10 kg of saturated liquid ammonia at 10[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Heat addition required to convert the entire liquid into saturated vapour at a constant pressure is 16.2 MJ. If the entropy of the saturated liquid is 0.88 kJ/kg.K, the entropy (in kJ/kg.K) of saturated vapour is _______
solution: For closed system, [latex]\delta Q=T d S [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \delta Q&=m T\left(s_{g}-s_{f}\right) \\ \therefore s_{g}&=\frac{\delta Q}{m T}+s_{f} \\ s_{g} &=\frac{16.2 \times 10^{3}}{10 \times(273+3)}+0.88 \\ &=5.724+0.88\\ &=6.604 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK}  \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 115 A diesel engine has a compression ratio of 17 and cut-off takes place at 10% of the stroke. Assuming ratio of specific heats ([latex]\gamma[/latex]) as 1.4, the air-standard effeciency is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}&=17 \\ \frac{c_{p}}{c_{v}}&=\gamma=1.4 \\ \text { or } \quad V_{3}-V_{2}&=0.1\left(V_{1}-V_{2}\right) \\ \text { or } \quad \frac{V_{3}}{V_{2}}-1&=0.1\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}-1\right)\\ \text { or } \quad \frac{V_{3}}{V_{2}}&=0.1 \times 16+1=2.6\\ r_{c}&=\frac{V_{3}}{V_{2}}=2.6\\ &\begin{array}{l} \eta_{\text {Disel }}=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}\left[\frac{r_{c}^{\gamma}-1}{\gamma\left(r_{c}-1\right)}\right] \\ \begin{array}{l} =1-\frac{1}{17^{0.4}}\left[\frac{2.6^{1.4}-1}{1.4(2.6-1)}\right] \\ =1-\frac{1}{17^{0.4}}\left(\frac{3.81-1}{1.4 \times 1.6}\right)\\=0.596=59.6 \% \end{array} \end{array} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 An amount of 100 kW of heat is transferred through a wall in steady state. One side of the wall is maintained at 127[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and the other side at 27[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The entropy generated (in W/K) due to the heat transfer through the wall is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} s_{2}-s_{1} &=\int_{1}^{2} \frac{d Q}{T}+S_{\text {gen }} \\ \therefore \qquad 0 &=\frac{100}{400}-\frac{100}{300}+S_{\text {gen }} \\ \text{or} \qquad S_{\text {gen }} &=\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{1}{12} \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{K} \\ \therefore \qquad S_{\text {gen }} &=\frac{1000}{12} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{K}=83.33 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 A certain amount of an ideal gas is initially at a pressure [latex]p_{1}[/latex]  and temperature [latex]T_{1}[/latex] . First, it undergoes a constant pressure process 1-2 such that [latex]T_{2}[/latex]=[latex]3T_{1}/4[/latex]. Then, it undergoes a constant volume process  2-3 such that [latex]T_{3}[/latex]=[latex]T_{1}/2[/latex]. The ratio of the final volume to the initial volume of the ideal gas is
solution: Process 1-2: Cooling at p=C [latex] T=\frac{3 T_{1}}{4} \text { given condition }[/latex] [latex] \text{Or} \quad \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=\frac{3}{4}[/latex] According to Charle's law [latex] \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}=\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=\frac{3}{4}[/latex] Process 2-3: Cooling at V=C [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{3} &=\frac{T_{2}}{2} \text { given condition } \\ \frac{\text { Final volume }}{\text { Initial volume }} &=\frac{V_{3}}{V_{1}}=\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \quad \because V_{3}=V_{2} \\ &=\frac{3}{4}=0.75 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 118 A source at a temperature of 500 K provides 1000 kJ of heat. The temperature of environment is 27[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The maximum useful work (in kJ) that can be obtained from the heat source is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{1} &=500 \mathrm{K} \\ Q_{1} &=1000 \mathrm{kJ} \\ T_{0} &=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(27+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=300 \mathrm{K} \\ \eta &=1-\frac{T_{0}}{T_{1}}=1-\frac{300}{500} \\ &=1-0.6=0.4 \\ \text{also}\quad \eta &=\frac{W_{\max }}{Q_{1}} \\ \therefore \quad 0.4 &=\frac{W_{\max }}{1000}\\ \text{or }\quad W_{\max }&=0.4 \times 1000=400 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 119 For a gas turbine power plant, identify the correct pair of statements P. Smaller in size compared to steam power plant for same power output Q. Starts quickly compared to steam power plant R. Works on the principle of Rankine cycle S. Good compatibility with solid fuel
solution:
(i) A GT plant can be started up as well  
shutdown quickly, like a diesel engine. (ii) The weight of the GT plant per kW output is low, which is a favaourable feature in all vehicle (land, air and sea). (iii) A GT plant works on the principle of Brayton cycle. (iv) Any hydrocarbon fuel from high octane gasoline to heavy diesel oil and pulverized coal can be used effectively.

question: Question 120 Which one of the following pairs of equations describes an irreversible heat engine?
solution:
1. Clausius inequality, [latex]
\oint \frac{\delta Q}{T} \leq 0[/latex] (i) [latex] \oint \frac{\delta Q}{T} \lt 0 [/latex] for irreversible heat engine. (ii) [latex] \oint \frac{\delta Q}{T}=0 [/latex] for reversible heat engine. (iii) [latex] \oint \frac{\delta Q}{T} \gt 0 [/latex] for impossible heat engine 2. [latex] \oint \delta Q \geq [/latex] both for reversible and irreversible heat engine. (i). [latex] \oint \delta Q \gt 0 [/latex] for irreversible heat engine. (ii). [latex] \oint \delta Q=0 [/latex] for reversible heat engine.

question: Question 121 Steam at a velocity of 10 m/s enters the impulse turbine stage with symmetrical blading having blade angle 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The enthalpy drop in the stage is 100 kJ. The nozzle angle is 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The maximum blade efficiency (in percent) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta_{b, \max } &=\cos ^{2} \alpha=\left(\cos 20^{\circ}\right)^{2}=0.883 \\ &=88.3 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 122 In an ideal Brayton cycle, atmospheric air (ratio of specific heats, [latex]c_{p}/c_{v} = 1.4[/latex] , specific heat at constant pressure = 1.005 kJ/kg.K) at 1 bar and 300 K is compressed to 8 bar. The maximum temperature in the cycle is limited to 1280 K. If the heat is supplied at the rate of 80 MW, the mass flow rate (in kg/s) of air required in the cycle is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } \frac{c_{p}}{c_{v}}&=\gamma=1.4 \\ c_{p} &=1.005 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ p_{1} &=1 \mathrm{bar} \\ T_{1} &=300 \mathrm{K} \\ p_{2} &=8 \mathrm{bar} \\ T_{3} &=T_{\max }=1280 \mathrm{K} \\ Q_{s} &=80 \mathrm{MW}=80 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] For process 1-2 [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}&=\left(\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}=8^{\frac{0.4}{1.4}}=1.8114\\ \text{or}\quad T_{2} &=300 \times 1.8114=543.43 \mathrm{K} \\ Q_{s} &=m c_{p}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right) \\ 80 \times 10^{3} &=m \times 1.005(1280-543.43)\\ \text{or}\quad m&=108.07 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 A pure substance at 8 MPa and [latex]400^{\circ}C[/latex]  is having a specific internal energy of 2864 kJ/kg and a specific volume of 0.03432 [latex]m^{3}/kg[/latex] . Its specific enthalpy (in kJ/kg) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} p&=8 \mathrm{MPa}=8 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{kPa} \\ T&=400^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ u&=2864 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ v&=0.03432 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] By definition of specific enthalpy, [latex] \begin{aligned} h &=u+p v \\ &=2864+8 \times 10^{3} \times 0.03432 \\ &=3138.56 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 124 The thermal efficiency of an air-standard Brayton cycle in terms of pressure ratio [latex]r_{p}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma (=c_{p}/c_{v})[/latex]  is given by
solution: Thermal efficiency, [latex]\begin{aligned} n &=1-\frac{T_1}{T_2} \\ &= 1-\frac{1}{\left ( \frac{T_2}{T_1} \right )}\\ \frac{T_2}{T_1} &=\left ( \frac{P_2}{P_1} \right )^{\frac{\gamma -1}{\gamma }}=r_p^{\frac{\gamma -1}{\gamma }} \\ r_p &=\text{Pressure ratio} \\ So, \;\;n &=1-\frac{1}{r_p^{\frac{\gamma -1}{\gamma }}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 125 An ideal reheat Rankine cycle operates between the pressure limits of 10 kPa and 8 MPa, with reheat being done at 4 MPa. The temperature of steam at the inlets of both turbines is 500[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and the enthalpy of steam is 3185 kJ/kg at the exit of the high pressure turbine and 2247 kJ/kg at the exit of low pressure turbine. The enthalpy of water at the exit from the pump is 191 kJ/kg. Use the following table for relevant data. Disregarding the pump work, the cycle efficiency (in percentage) is __________
solution: Given [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{2} &=10 \mathrm{kPa} ; \quad p_{1}=8 \mathrm{MPa} \\ p_{3} &=4 \mathrm{MPa} ; \quad h_{2}=3185 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{4} &=2247 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} ; \quad h_{1}=3399 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{3} &=3446 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} ; \quad h_{6}=191 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{\mathrm{T}} &=\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)+\left(h_{3}-h_{4}\right) \\ q_{s} &=\left(h_{1}-h_{6}\right)+\left(h_{3}-h_{2}\right) \\ \therefore \quad w_{T} &=(3399-3185)+(3446-2247) \\ &=1413 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ q_{\mathrm{s}} &=(3399-191)+(3446-3185) \\ &=3469 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \eta &=\frac{w_{\mathrm{T}}}{q_{\mathrm{s}}}=\frac{1413}{3469}=0.4073 \\ &=40.73 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 A reversible heat engine receives 2 kJ of heat from a reservoir at 1000 K and a certain amount of heat from a reservoir at 800 K. It rejects 1 kJ of heat to a reservoir at 400 K. The network output (in kJ) of the cycle is
solution: For reversible heat engine, [latex]\begin{aligned} (\Delta S)_{\text{ Reversible cycle }}&=0\\ \frac{Q_1}{T_1}+\frac{Q_2}{T_2}-\frac{Q_3}{T_3}&=0\\ \frac{2}{1000}+\frac{Q_2}{800}-\frac{1}{400}&=0\\ Q_2&=0.4 kJ\\ \text{From heat balance, }\\ Q_1+Q_2&=W+Q_3\\ 2+0.4&=W+1\\ W&=1.4 kJ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 In an air-standard Otto cycle, air is supplied at 0.1 MPa and 308 K. The ratio of the specific heats ([latex]\gamma[/latex] ) and the specific gas constant (R) of air are 1.4 and 288.8 J/kg.K, respectively. If the compression ratio is 8 and the maximum temperature in the cycle is 2660 K, the heat (in kJ/kg) supplied to the engine is _______
solution:
Given: [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1}&=0.1 \mathrm{MPa} ; \quad T_{1}=308 \mathrm{K} ; \quad \gamma=1.4 \\ R&=288.8 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} ; \quad r=8 \\ T_{s}&=2660 \mathrm{K} \\ &\begin{aligned} Q_{s}&=m c_{v}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right) \\ c_{v}&=\frac{R}{\gamma-1}=\frac{288.8}{0.4}=722 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}&=\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma-1}=(8)^{0.4}\\
T_{2} &=308 \times 8^{0.4}=707.6 \mathrm{K} \\
Q_{s} &=m c_{v} \Delta T \\
&=1 \times 722(2660-707.6) \\
&=1409.6 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 128 1.5 kg of water is in saturated liquid state at 2 bar ([latex]v_{f}= 0.001061 m^3/kg[/latex], [latex]u_{f}[/latex]=504.0 kJ/kg,  [latex]h_{f}[/latex]=505 kJ/kg). Heat is added in a constant pressure process till the temperature of water reaches 400[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C  (v=1.5493 [latex]m^3[/latex]/kg, u = 2967.0 kJ/kg, h = 3277.0 kJ/kg). The heat added (in kJ) in the process is  _______
solution: From the first law of thermodynamics [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta q &=d u+p d v \\ \delta q &=\left(u_{2}-u_{1}\right)+p\left(v_{2}-v_{1}\right) \\ \delta q &=(2967-504)+2 \times 10^{2} \\ &(1.5493-0.001061) \\ \delta q &=2463+309.6478 \\ &=2772.6478 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] For 1.5kg of water [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=2772.6478 \times 1.5 \\ &=4158.97 \mathrm{kj} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=m\left(h_{2}-h_{1}\right) \\ &=1.5(3277-505) \\ &=4158 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 129 In a power plant, water (density = [latex]1000 kg/m^{3}[/latex] ) is pumped from 80 kPa to 3 MPa. The pump has an isentropic efficiency of 0.85. Assuming that the temperature of the water remains the same, the specific work (in kJ/kg) supplied to the pump is
solution: Ideal work input: [latex] w=v_{f} \Delta p [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{\rho_{\text {water }}}\left(p_{2}-p_{1}\right) \\ &=\frac{(3000-80)}{1000} \\ &=\frac{2920}{1000}=2.92 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \text { Actual input work }&=\frac{w}{\eta}= \frac{2.92}{0.85}\\ &=3.43\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 130 The maximum theoretical work obtainable, when a system interacts to equilibrium with a reference environment, is called
solution: Exergy is also known as availability and it is maximum theoretical work obtainable, when a system interacts to equilibrium with dead state or reference environment.

question: Question 131 In a simple Brayton cycle, the pressure ratio is 8 and temperatures at the entrance of compressor and turbine are 300 K and 1400 K, respectively. Both compressor and gas turbine have isentropic efficiencies equal to 0.8. For the gas, assume a constant value of [latex]c_{p}[/latex] (specific heat at constant pressure) equal to 1 [latex]kJ/kgK[/latex] and ratio of specific heats as 1.4. Neglect changes in kinetic and potential energies. The thermal efficiency of the cycle in percentage (%) is
solution: For adiabatic process 3-4 s [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{3}}{T_{4 s}} &=\left(\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}=(8)^{\frac{1.4-1}{1.4}} \\ &=(8)^{0.2857}=1.811 \\ \text{or}\quad T_{4 s} &=\frac{T_{3}}{1.811}=\frac{1400}{1.811} \\ &=773.05 \mathrm{K} \\ \eta_{T} &=\frac{\text { Actual fall in temperature }}{\text { Isentropic fall in temperature }}\\ \eta_{T} &=\frac{T_{3}-T_{4}}{T_{3}-T_{4 s}} \\ 0.8 &=\frac{1400-T_{4}}{1400-773.05} \\ 0.8 &=\frac{1400-T_{4}}{626.95}\\ \text{or }\quad 1400-T_{4}&=0.8 \times 626.95 \\ 1400-T_{4} &=501.56 \\ T_{4} &=898.44 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Power developed by the turbine, [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{T} &=c_{p}\left(T_{3}-T_{4}\right) \\ &=1(1400-898.44) \\ &=501.56 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net power output, [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{\text {net }} &=w_{T}-w_{C}=501.56-304.12 \\ &=197.44 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat supplied, [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{2-3} &=c_{p}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right) \\ &=1(1400-604.12) \\ &=795.88 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thermal efficiency of the cycle, [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{\mathrm{th}} &=\frac{\text { Net power output : } w_{\text {net }}}{\text { Heat supplied : } q_{2-3}} \\ &=\frac{197.44}{795.88}=0.2480 \\ &=24.80 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 132 In a simple Brayton cycle, the pressure ratio is 8 and temperatures at the entrance of compressor and turbine are 300 K and 1400 K, respectively. Both compressor and gas turbine have isentropic efficiencies equal to 0.8. For the gas, assume a constant value of [latex]c_{p}[/latex] (specific heat at constant pressure) equal to 1 [latex]kJ/kgK[/latex] and ratio of specific heats as 1.4. Neglect changes in kinetic and potential energies. The power required by the compressor in kW/kg of gas flow rate is
solution: Given data: Pressure ratio, [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{p}&=8\\ T_{1} &=300 \mathrm{K} ; T_{3}=1400 \mathrm{K} \\ \eta_{c} &=\eta_{T}=0.8 \\ c_{p} &=1 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ \gamma &=1.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] For adiabatic isentropic process 1-2s, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{2 s}}{T_{1}}&=\left(\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}} \\ \frac{T_{2 s}}{300}&=\left(r_{p}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}=(8)^{\frac{1.4-1}{1.4}}=(8)^{0.2857} \\ \frac{T_{2 s}}{300}&=1.811\\ \text{or }\qquad T_{2 s} &=300 \times 1.811=543.3 \mathrm{K} \\ n_{c} &=\frac{\text { Isentropic rise in temperature }}{\text { Actual rise in temperature }} \\ &=\frac{T_{2 s}-T_{1}}{T_{2}-T_{1}} \\ \therefore \quad 0.8 &=\frac{543.3-300}{T_{2}-300}\\ \text{or }\qquad T_{2}-300&=\frac{243.3}{0.8}=304.12\\ \text{or }\qquad T_{2}&=604.12 \mathrm{K}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Power required by compressure, [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{C} &=c_{p}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right) \\ &=1(604.12-300) \\ &=304.12 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 133 The pressure, temperature and velocity of air flowing in a pipe are 5 bar, 500 K and 50 m/s, respectively. The specific heats of air at constant pressure and at constant volume are 1.005 kJ/kgK and 0.718 kJ/kgK, respectively. Neglect potential energy. If the pressure and temperature of the surroundings are 1 bar and 300 K, respectively, the available energy in kJ/kg of the air stream is
solution: Available energy [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\left(h_{1}-h_{0}\right)-T_{0}\left(s_{1}-s_{0}\right)+\left(\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}-\frac{V_{0}^{2}}{2}\right) \\ \text { where } s_{1}-s_{0}=c_{p} \ln \frac{T_{1}}{T_{0}}-R \ln \frac{p_{1}}{p_{0}}\\ =1.005 \ln \left(\frac{500}{300}\right)-0.287 \ln \left(\frac{5}{1}\right) \\ =0.05147 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Available energy [latex] =1.005(500-300)-300(0.5147)+\frac{(50)^{2}}{2} \times 10^{-3}\\ =186.8 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \approx 187 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex]

question: Question 134 Specific enthalpy and velocity of steam at inlet and exit of a steam turbine, running under steady state, are as given below: The rate of heat loss from the turbine per kg of steam flow rate is 5 kW. Neglecting changes in potential energy of steam, the power developed in kW  by the steam turbine per kg of steam flow rate, is
solution: Applying steady flow energy equation [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}+q &=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2}+w \\ 3250+\frac{180^{2}}{2000} &-5=2360+\frac{5^{2}}{2000}+w \\ \text{or}\quad w &=901.2 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 135 A cylinder contains 5 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]
 of an ideal gas at a pressure of 1 bar. This gas is compressed in a reversible isothermal process till its pressure increases to 5 bar. The work in kJ required for this process is
solution: For Reversible isothermal Process work done is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{1-2}&=p_1v_1\ln \frac{p_1}{p_2} \\ &=1 \times 10^5 \times 5 \times \ln \left ( \frac{1}{5} \right ) \\ &= -804.7\; KJ \end{aligned}[/latex] The negative sign shows that the compression process is taking place in this process.

question: Question 136 Air enters an adiabatic nozzle at 300kPa, 500K with a valocity of 10 m/s. It  leaves the nozzle at 100kPa with a velocity of 180m/s. The inlet area is 80 [latex]cm^2[/latex]. The specific heat of air [latex]C_p[/latex] is 1008J/kg.K. The exit area of the nozzle in [latex]cm^2[/latex] is
solution: Continuity equation for compressible flow [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{A_1V_1}{v_1}&=\frac{A_2V_2}{v_2}\\ \frac{A_1V_1}{\frac{RT_1}{p_1}}&=\frac{A_2V_2}{\frac{RT_2}{p_2}}\;\;(\because \; pv=RT)\\ \frac{A_1V_1p_1}{T_1}&=\frac{A_2V_2p_2}{T_2}\\ \frac{80 \times 10 \times 300}{500}&=\frac{A_2 \times 180 \times 100}{484}\\ A_2&=12.90\; cm^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 Air enters an adiabatic nozzle at 300kPa, 500K with a valocity of 10 m/s. It  leaves the nozzle at 100kPa with a velocity of 180m/s. The inlet area is 80 [latex]cm^2[/latex]. The specific heat of air [latex]C_p[/latex] is 1008J/kg.K. The exit temperature of the air is
solution: Applying the steady flow energy equation, [latex]h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}+g z_{1}+q=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2}+g z_{2}+w[/latex] Assumptions: [latex]\begin{aligned} z_1 &= z_2\\ q&=0\;\; \text{adiabatic flow} \\ w &=0\;\; \text{always for nozzle} \\ h_1 +\frac{V_1^2}{2}&= h_2 +\frac{V_2^2}{2}\\ c_pT_1+\frac{V_1^2}{2}&= c_pT_2+\frac{V_2^2}{2}\\ 1008 \times 500+\frac{(10)^2}{2}&=1008 \times T_2 +\frac{(180)^2}{2} \\ 504050&=1008T_2+16200 \\ T_2&=483.97K \approx 484K \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 138 An ideal gas of mass m and temperature [latex]T_{1}[/latex]
 undergoes a reversible isothermal process from an initial pressure [latex]P_{1}[/latex]
 to final pressure [latex]P_{2}[/latex]
 . The heat loss using the process is Q. the entropy change [latex]\Delta[/latex]S of the gas is
solution: We know that [latex] \Delta S=\frac{\delta Q}{T}[/latex] Integrating between states 1 and 2 gives [latex] \begin{aligned} \int_{1}^{2} \Delta S &=\int_{1}^{2} \frac{\delta Q}{T} \\ S_{2}-S_{1} &=\frac{1}{T} \int_{1}^{2} \delta Q \quad \because T=C\\ &=\frac{1}{T} \times Q_{1-2}=\frac{m R T \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}}{T} \\ &=m R \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}=m R \ln \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] where [latex]\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}[/latex] for isothermal process Alternatively We know that the entropy change in terms of temperature and pressure ratios, [latex] S_{2}-S_{1}=m c_{P} \ln \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}-m R \ln \frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}[/latex] where [latex] T_{1}=T_{2} [/latex] for isothermal process [latex] \therefore \quad S_{2}-S_{1}=-m R \ln \frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}=m R \ln \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}[/latex]

question: Question 139 Steam enters an adiabatic turbine operating at steady state with an enthalpy of 3251.0kJ/kg and leaves as a saturated mixture at 15 kPa with quality (dryness fraction) 0.9. The enthalpies of the saturated liquid and vapour at 15 kPa are [latex]h_f[/latex]=225.94kJ/kg and [latex]h_g[/latex]=2598.3 kJ/kg respectively. The mass flow rate of steam is 10kg/s. Kinetic and potential energy changes are negligible. The power output of the turbine in MW is

Question 140 The temperature and pressure of air in a large reservoir are 400K and 3 bar respectively. A converging-diverging nozzle of exit area 0.005[latex]m^{2}[/latex]
 is fitted to the wall of the reservoir as shown in the figure. The static pressure of air at the exit section for isentropic flow through the nozzle is 50kPa. The characteristic gas constant and the ratio of specific heats of air are 0.287kJ/kgK and 1.4 respectively. The mass flow rate of air through the nozzle in kg/s is
solution: Mass flow rate of air through nozzle = mass entering nozzle = mass exit from nozzle [latex] \begin{aligned} m &=\rho_{i} A_{i} V_{i}=\rho_{e} A_{e} V_{e} \\ \text { where } & i=\text { inlet } \\ e &=\text { exit } \\ \rho &=\text { density } \\ A &=\text { Area } \\ V &=\text { velocity } \\ p &=\rho R T \\ m &=\frac{A_{e} V_{e} p_{e}}{R T_{e}}\\ \text{Given }R&=0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ p_{e}&=50 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] For isentropic process [latex] \begin{array}{l} \left(\frac{T_{e}}{T_{i}}\right)=\left(\frac{p_{e}}{p_{i}}\right)^{\gamma-1 / \gamma} \\ \frac{T_{e}}{400}=\left(\frac{50}{500}\right)^{0.4 / 1.4}\\ \text{or}\quad T_{e}=239.73 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex] Mass flow rate, [latex] m=\frac{50 \times 0.005 \times V_{e}}{0.287 \times 239.73} \qquad \cdots(1)[/latex] Using steady flow energy equation [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{i}+\frac{V_{i}^{2}}{2}+q&=h_{e}+\frac{V_{e}^{2}}{2}+w\\ \text{where }\quad V_{i}&=0 \\ q&=0 \quad \text{adiabatic flow}\\ w &=0 \\ \therefore \quad h_{i} &=h_{e}+\frac{V_{e}^{2}}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] On units balancing, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{i} &=h_{e}+\frac{V_{e}^{2}}{2000} \\ \text{or}\quad h_{i}-h_{e} &=\frac{V_{e}^{2}}{2000}\\ c_{p}\left(T_{i}-T_{e}\right)&=\frac{V_{e}^{2}}{2000}\\ 1 \times(400-239.73)&=\frac{V_{e}^{2}}{2000} \\ V_{e}&=567.57 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] From Eq. (1), we get [latex] m=\frac{50 \times 0.005 \times 567.57}{0.287 \times 239.73}[/latex] [latex] =2.06 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question:
Question 141 The temperature and pressure of air in a large reservoir are 400K and 3 bar respectively. A converging-diverging nozzle of exit area 0.005[latex]m^{2}[/latex]
 is fitted to the wall of the reservoir as shown in the figure. The static pressure of air at the exit section for isentropic flow through the nozzle is 50kPa. The characteristic gas constant and the ratio of specific heats of air are 0.287kJ/kgK and 1.4 respectively. The density of air in [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]
 at the nozzle exit is
solution: Density of air in [latex]\left(\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}\right)[/latex] at nozzle exit is [latex] \frac{p_{1}}{\rho_{1}^{\gamma}}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho_{2}^{\gamma}}[/latex] where [latex]\rho=[/latex] density [latex] \begin{array}{l} \rho_{2}=\left(\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\gamma}} \rho_{1} \\ =\left(\frac{50}{300}\right)^{1 / 1.4} \times \frac{3 \times 10^{5}}{0.287 \times 1000 \times 400} \\ =0.727 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 142 In an experimental set-up, air flows between two stations P and Q adiabatically. The direction of flow depends on the pressure and temperature conditions maintained at P and Q. The conditions at station P are 150kPa and 350K. The temperature at station Q is 300K. The following are the properties and relations pertaining to air: Specific heat at constant pressure, [latex]C_{p}[/latex]=
 1.005kJ/kgK; Specific heat at constant volume, [latex]C_{v}[/latex]=
 0.718kJ/kgK; Characteristic gas constant, R=0.287kJ/kgK Enthalpy, h=[latex]C_{p}T[/latex] Internal energy, u=[latex]C_{v}T[/latex] If the pressure at station Q is 50kPa, the change in entropy ([latex]s_{Q}-s_{P}[/latex])
in kJ/kgK is
solution: If [latex]p_{Q}=50 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Change in entropy, [latex] \begin{aligned} s_{Q}-s_{P} &=c_{p} \ln \frac{T_{Q}}{T_{P}}-R \ln \frac{p_{Q}}{p_{P}} \\ &=1.005 \ln \frac{300}{350}-0.287 \ln \frac{50}{150} \\ &=1.005(-0.1541)-0.287(-1.098) \\ &=-0.1548+0.3151=0.160 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 143 In an experimental set-up, air flows between two stations P and Q adiabatically. The direction of flow depends on the pressure and temperature conditions maintained at P and Q. The conditions at station P are 150kPa and 350K. The temperature at station Q is 300K. The following are the properties and relations pertaining to air: Specific heat at constant pressure, [latex]C_{p}[/latex]=
 1.005kJ/kgK; Specific heat at constant volume, [latex]C_{v}[/latex]=
 0.718kJ/kgK; Characteristic gas constant,  R=0.287kJ/kgK Enthalpy, h=[latex]C_{p}T[/latex] Internal energy, u=[latex]C_{v}T[/latex] If the air has to flow from station P to station Q, the maximum possible value of pressure in kPa at station Q is close to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} c_{p} &=1.005 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ c_{v} &=0.718 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ R &=0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ \gamma &=\frac{c_{p}}{c_{v}}=\frac{1.005}{0.718}=1.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] For adiabatic process P-Q, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{Q}}{T_{P}} &=\left(\frac{p_{Q}}{p_{P}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}} \\ \frac{300}{350} &=\left(\frac{p_{Q}}{150}\right)^{\frac{1.4-1}{1.4}}=\left(\frac{p_{Q}}{150}\right)^{0.285} \\ \text{or}\qquad \frac{p_{Q}}{150} &=\left(\frac{300}{350}\right)^{3.5}\\ \frac{p_{Q}}{150}&=0.583\\ \text{or}\qquad p_{Q}&=87.45 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 144 An ideal Brayton cycle, operating between the pressure limits of 1 bar and 6 bar, has minimum and maximum temperatures of 300K and 1500K. The ratio of specific heats of the working fluid is 1.4. The approximate final temperatures in Kelvin at the end of the compression and expansion processes are respectively
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{ll} p_{1}=1 \text { bar; } & p_{2}=6 \text { bar } \\ T_{1}=300 \mathrm{K} ; & T_{3}=1500 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex] For process 1-2 [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}&=\left(\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}\\ \frac{T_{2}}{300} &=\left(\frac{6}{1}\right)^{\frac{1.4-1}{1.4}}=(6)^{0.285}=1.666 \\ \text{or}\quad T_{2} &=300 \times 1.666 \\ &=499.8 \mathrm{K} \\ & \approx 500 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] For process 3-4 [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{3}}{T_{4}}&=\left(\frac{p_{3}}{p_{4}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}=\left(\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}\\ &\qquad \because p_{3}=p_{2}, p_{4}=p_{1} \\ \frac{1500}{T_{4}}&=(6)^{\frac{1.4-1}{1.4}}=(6)^{0.285}=1.666 \\ \text{or}\quad T_{4} &=\frac{1500}{1.666}=900.36 \mathrm{K} \\ &\approx 900 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 146 The values of enthalpy of steam at the inlet and outlet of a steam turbine in a Rankine cycle are 2800kJ/kg and 1800kJ/kg respectively. Neglecting pump work, the specific steam consumption in kg/kW-hour is
solution: Given data: Specific enthalpy at turbine inlet, [latex] h_{1}=2800 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] Specific enthalpy at turbine [latex] \text { outlet: } \quad h_{2}=1800 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] Specific work output by the turbine, [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{T} &=h_{1}-h_{2} \\ &=2800-1800\\ &=1000\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Networkoutput, [latex] w_{\text {net }}=w_{T}-w_{P}[/latex] Where Pump work [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{p} &=0 \\ w_{\text {net }} &=w_{T}=1000 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Specific steam consumption, [latex] S S C=\frac{3600}{1000} \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh}[/latex] [latex] =3.6 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh}[/latex]

question: Question 147 The contents of a well-insulated tank are heated by a resistor of [latex]23\Omega[/latex] in which 10A current is flowing. Consider the tank along with its contents as a thermodynamic system. The work done by the system and the heat transfer to the system are positive. The rates of heat (Q), work (W) and change in internal energy ([latex]\Delta U[/latex]) during the process in kW are
solution: Heat transfer , Q=0 well-insulated wall Increase in internal energy, [latex] \Delta U= [/latex] rate of heat dissipated by a resistor [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta U &=I^{2} R=(10)^{2} \times 23 \\ &=2300 \mathrm{W}=2.3 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] According to first law of thermodynamic for process, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=d U+W \\ 0&=2.3+W\\ \text{or}\quad W&=-2.3 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Then it enters the condenser and exits as saturated water. Next, a pump feeds back the water to the boiler. The adiabatic efficiency of the turbine is 90%. The thermodynamic states of water and steam are given in the table. h is specific enthalpy, s is specific entropy and v the specific volume; subscripts f and g denote saturated liquid state and saturated vapour state. Heat supplied ([latex]kJ kg^{-1}[/latex]
) to the cycle is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{also, }\quad w_{p}&=h_{4}-h_{3} \\ \therefore \quad 4.04 &=h_{4}-226.95 \\ \text{or}\quad h_{4} &=230.99 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat supplied to the cycle, [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{4-1} &=h_{1}-h_{4} \\ &=3092.5-230.99 \\ &=2861.51 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ & \approx 2863 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 150 In a steam power plant operating on the Rankine cycle, steam enters the turbine at 4MPa, 350[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and exits at a pressure of 15kPa. Then it enters the condenser and exits as saturated water. Next, a pump feeds back the water to the boiler. The adiabatic efficiency of the turbine is 90%. The thermodynamic states of water and steam are given in the table. h is specific enthalpy, s is specific entropy and v the specific volume; subscripts f and g denote saturated liquid state and saturated vapour state. The net work output ([latex]kJ kg^{-1}[/latex]
) of the cycle is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{l} p_{1}=p_{4}=4 \mathrm{MPa}=4000 \mathrm{kPa}\\ T_{1}=350^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ p_{2}=p_{3}=15 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \eta_{T}=90 \%=0.90 \end{array}[/latex] From given saturated steam table at [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1} &=4 \mathrm{MPa}, T_{1}=350^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \text { we get, } h_{1}&=3092.5 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ s_{1} &=6.5821 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] From given saturated steam table (pressure based) [latex]\begin{aligned} h_{f} &=h_{3}=226.95 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{g} &=2599.1 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ s_{f} &=0.7549 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ s_{g} &=8.0085 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K} \\ v_{f} &=v_{3}=0.001014 \mathrm{m}^{3} \mathrm{kg} \\ s_{1} &=s_{2 s}=s_{f}+x_{2 s}\left(s_{g}-s_{f}\right) \\ 6.5821 &=0.7549+x_{2 s} \\ &(8.0085-0.7549) \\ 6.5821 &=0.7549+7.2536 x_{2 s} \\ \text{or}\quad 7.2536 x_{2 s} &=5.8272 \\ \text{or}\quad x_{2 s} &=0.8033 \\ h_{2 s} &=h_{f}+x_{2 s}\left(h_{g}-h_{f}\right) \\ &=226.95+0.8033 \\ &(25991.1-226.95) \\ &=226.95+1905.54 \\ &=2132.49 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ n_{T} &=\frac{(\Delta h)_{\mathrm{act}}}{(\Delta h)_{\mathrm{sen}}}=\frac{h_{1}-h_{2}}{h_{1}-h_{2 s}}\\ 0.90 &=\frac{3092.5-h_{2}}{3092.5-2132.49} \\ 0.90 &=\frac{3092.5-h_{2}}{960.01} \\ \text { or }\quad 960.01 \times 0.90 &=3092.5-h_{2}\\ \text { or }\quad 864&=3092.5-h_{2}\\ \text { or }\quad h_{2}&=2228.5 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Turbine work, [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{T} &=h_{1}-h_{2}=3092.5-2228.5 \\ &=864 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Pump work, [latex] w_{p}=v_{3}\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right) \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] where [latex]v_{3}[/latex] in [latex]m^{3 / k g}[/latex] and [latex]p_{1}[/latex] and [latex]p_{2}[/latex] in kPa [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad w_{p} &=0.001014(4000-15) \\ &=4.04 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net work output of the cycle, [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{\text {net }} &=w_{T}-w_{P}=864-4.04 \\ &=859.96 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ & \approx 860 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 151 Consider the following two processes: a. A heat source at 1200K loses 2500kJ of heat to sink at 800K b. A heat source at 800K loses 2000kJ of heat to sink at 500K Which of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: Process-I Entropy change of process 1 [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S_{1} &=-\frac{Q_{1}}{T_{1}}+\frac{Q_{1}}{T_{2}} \\ &=-\frac{2500}{1200}+\frac{2500}{800} \\ &=-2.08+3.12 \\ &=1.04 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Process-II Entropy change of process 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S_{2} &=-\frac{Q_{2}}{T_{2}}+\frac{Q_{2}}{T_{2}} \\ &=-\frac{2000}{800}+\frac{2000}{500} \\ &=-2.5+4 \\ &=1.5 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, [latex]\Delta S_{2}>\Delta S_{1},[/latex] process-II is more irreversible than process-I.

options.A: Process I is more irreversible than Process II
options.B: Process II is more irreversible than Process I
options.C: Irreversibility associated in both the processes is equal

question:
Question 154 A turbo-charged four-stroke direct injection diesel engine has a displacement volume of [latex]0.0259m^{3}[/latex]
(25.9litres) . The engine has an output of 950kW at 2200rpm. The mean effective pressure in MPa is closest to
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} n&=\frac{N}{2} \text{for four-stroke engine}\\ V_{s}&=0.0259 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ P&=950 \mathrm{kW}\\ N&=2200 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that power output, [latex] P=\frac{p_{m} A ln x}{60} k W=\frac{p_{m} V_{s} n x}{60}[/latex] where P is in kW [latex] p_{m} [/latex] is in [latex]\mathrm{kPa} [/latex] [latex] V_{s} [/latex] is in [latex]m^{3} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} n&=\frac{N}{2} \mathrm{rpm}\\ x&=1, \text{number of cylinder}\\ \therefore \quad 950&=\frac{p_{m} \times 0.0259}{60} \times \frac{N}{2} \times 1\\ 950 &=\frac{p_{m} \times 0.0259 \times 2200}{120} \\ \text{or}\quad p_{m} &=2000 \mathrm{kPa}=2 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 155 The inlet and the outlet conditions of stream for an adiabatic steam turbine are as indicated in the notations are as usually followed Assume the above turbine to be part of a simple Rankine cycle. The density of water at the inlet to the pump is [latex]1000kg/m^{3}[/latex]
. Ignoring kinetic and potential energy effects, the specific work (in kJ/kg) supplied to the pump is
solution: Specific work supplied to the pump, [latex] v_{P}=v\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right) \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} [/latex] Where v is in [latex]\mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} [/latex] [latex] p_{1}[/latex] and [latex]p_{2}[/latex] are in kPa [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad w_{p} &=\frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{p}=\frac{3000-70}{1000} \\ &=2.93 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 156 The inlet and the outlet conditions of stream for an adiabatic steam turbine are as indicated in the notations are as usually followed If mass flow rate of steam through the turbine is 20kg/s, the power output of the turbine (in MW) is
solution: Applying the steady flow energy equation, [latex] m\left(h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}+g z_{1}\right)+Q=m\left(h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2}+g z_{2}\right)+W[/latex] where Q=0 for adiabatic flow, [latex] m\left(h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}+g z_{1}\right)=m\left(h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2}+g z_{2}\right)+W[/latex] On units balancing, we get [latex] \begin{array}{l} \qquad m\left(n_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2000}+\frac{g z_{1}}{1000}\right)=m\left(h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2000}+\frac{g z_{2}}{1000}\right)+W \\ 20\left(3200+\frac{(160)^{2}}{2000}+\frac{9.81 \times 10}{1000}\right)=20(2600+ \\ \qquad \left.\frac{(100)^{2}}{2000}+\frac{9.81 \times 6}{1000}\right)+W \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 64257.96 &=52101.17+W \\ W &=12156.79 \mathrm{kW}\\ &=12.1568 \mathrm{MW} \\ &\approx 12.157 \mathrm{MW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 157 An irreversible heat engine extracts heat from a high temperature source at a rate of 100kW and rejects heat to a sink at a rate of 50kW. The entire work output of the heat engine is used to drive a reversible heat pump operating between a set of independent isothermal heat reservoirs at 17[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and 75[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The rate (in kW) at which the heat pump delivers heat to its high temperature sink is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{ll} Q_{1}=100 \mathrm{kW} ; & Q_{2}=50 \mathrm{kW} \\ T_{3}=290 \mathrm{K} ; & T_{4}=348 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex] Heat engine work output, [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=Q_{1}-Q_{2} \\ W &=100-50=50 \mathrm{kW} \\ &=\text { Pump input work } \\ (\mathrm{COP})_{\mathrm{HP}} &=\frac{Q_{4}}{W} \\ \text{also}(\mathrm{COP})_{\mathrm{HP}} &=\frac{T_{4}}{T_{4}-T_{3}} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{Q_{4}}{W} &=\frac{T_{4}}{T_{4}-T_{3}} \\ \frac{Q_{4}}{50} &=\frac{348}{348-290}=\frac{348}{58}\\ \text{or}\quad Q_{4}&=300 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 158 In an air-standard Otto cycle, the compression ratio is 10. The condition at the beginning of the compression process is 100kPa and 27[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Heat added at constant volume is 1500kJ/kg, while 700kJ/kg of heat is rejected during the other constant volume process in the cycle. Specific gas constant for air=0.287 kJ/kgK. The mean effective pressure (in kPa) of the cycle is
solution: Given data for Otto cycle: Compression ratio, [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=10 \\ p_{1} &=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ T_{1} &=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(27+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=300 \mathrm{K} \\ q_{1} &=1500 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ q_{2} &=700 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ R &=0.287 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ p_{1} v_{1} &=R T_{1} \\ 100 \times v_{1} &=0.287 \times 300 \\ \text{or }\quad v_{1} &=0.861 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}\\ \text { also } \quad v_{1}&=10 v_{2} \\ \therefore \quad 0.861&=10 v_{2} \\ \text{or}\quad v_{2} &=0.0861 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Specific work done per cycle, [latex] \begin{aligned} w &=q_{1}-q_{2} \\ &=1500-700=800 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that mean effective pressure, [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{m} &=\frac{w}{v_{s}}=\frac{800}{v_{1}-v_{2}} \\ &=\frac{800}{0.861-0.0861}=1032.39 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 159 A compressor undergoes a reversible, steady flow process. The gas at inlet and outlet of the compressor is designated as state 1 and state 2 respectively. Potential and kinetic energy changes are to be ignored. The following notations are used: v= specific volume and P=pressure of the gas. The specific work required to be supplied to the compressor for this gas compression process is
solution: Reversible steady flow process State 1: Inlet State 2: Outlet Potential and kinetic energy change ignored. v= Specific volume of the gas P= Pressure of the gas Specific work required to be supplied to the compressor for this gas compression process is [latex] w=\int_{1}^{2} v d p \quad [/latex] (Open system flow in compressor)

question: Question 160 A frictionless piston-cylinder device contains a gas initially at 0.8MPa and 0.015 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]. It expands quasi-statically at constant temperature to a final volume of 0.030 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The work output (in kJ) during this process will be
solution: Given data for constant temperature process [latex] \begin{array}{l} p_{1}=0.8 \mathrm{MPa}=800 \mathrm{kPa} \\ V_{1}=0.015 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ V_{2}=0.030 \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{array}[/latex] We know that work done for constant temperature process, [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=p_{1} V_{1} \log _{e} \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \\ &=800 \times 0.015 \log _{e} \frac{0.030}{0.015} \\ &=8.317 \mathrm{kJ} \approx 8.32 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 162 In the figure shown, the system is a pure substance kept in a piston- cylinder arrangement. The system is initially a two-phase mixture containing 1 kg of liquid and 0.03 kg of vapour at a pressure of 100 kPa. Initially, the piston rests on a set of stops, as shown in the figure. A pressure of 200kPa is required to exactly balance the weight of the piston and the outside atmospheric pressure. Heat transfer takes place into the system until its volume increases by 50%. Heat transfer to the system occurs in such a manner that the piston, when allowed to move, does so in a very slow (quasi - static
/quasi - equilibrium) process. The thermal reservoir from which heat is transferred to the system has a temperature of 400[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Average temperature of the system boundary can be taken as175[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The
heat transfer to the system is 1kJ, during which its entropy increase by 10 J/K. Specific volume of liquid ([latex]v_f[/latex]) and vapour ([latex]v_g[/latex]) phases, as well as values of saturation temperatures, are given below The net entropy generation (considering the system and the thermal reservoir together) during the process is closest to
solution: Heat transfer: [latex] Q=1 \mathrm{kJ}=1000 \mathrm{J}[/latex] Entropy of the surrounding (i.e., reservoir) [latex] (\Delta S)_{\text {surr }}=-\frac{1000}{673}=-1.485 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{K}[/latex] Entropy of the system increases, [latex] (\Delta S)_{\mathrm{sys}}=10 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{K}[/latex] Net entropy generation, [latex] \begin{aligned} (\Delta S)_{\text {uni }} &=(\Delta S)_{\text {sys }}+(\Delta S)_{\text {surr }} \\ &=10-1.485=8.51 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 163 In the figure shown, the system is a pure substance kept in a piston- cylinder arrangement. The system is initially a two-phase mixture containing 1 kg of liquid and 0.03 kg of vapour at a pressure of 100 kPa. Initially, the piston rests on a set of stops, as shown in the figure. A pressure of 200kPa is required to exactly balance the weight of the piston and the outside atmospheric pressure. Heat transfer takes place into the system until its volume increases by 50%. Heat transfer to the system occurs in such a manner that the piston, when allowed to move, does so in a very slow (quasi - static
/quasi - equilibrium) process. The thermal reservoir from which heat is transferred to the system has a temperature of 400[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Average temperature of the system boundary can be taken as175[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The
heat transfer to the system is 1kJ, during which its entropy increase by 10 J/K. Specific volume of liquid ([latex]v_f[/latex]) and vapour ([latex]v_g[/latex]) phases, as well as values of saturation temperatures, are given below The work done by the system during the process is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Work done } &=m\left(p_{2}\right)\left(v_{2}-v_{1}\right) \\ &=1.03(200)(0.0057-0.0038) \\ &=0.3914 \mathrm{kJ} \approx 0.4 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 164 In the figure shown, the system is a pure substance kept in a piston- cylinder arrangement. The system is initially a two-phase mixture containing 1 kg of liquid and 0.03 kg of vapour at a pressure of 100 kPa. Initially, the piston rests on a set of stops, as shown in the figure. A pressure of 200kPa is required to exactly balance the weight of the piston and the outside atmospheric pressure. Heat transfer takes place into the system until its volume increases by 50%. Heat transfer to the system occurs in such a manner that the piston, when allowed to move, does so in a very slow (quasi - static
/quasi - equilibrium) process. The thermal reservoir from which heat is transferred to the system has a temperature of 400[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Average temperature of the system boundary can be taken as175[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The
heat transfer to the system is 1kJ, during which its entropy increase by 10 J/K. Specific volume of liquid ([latex]v_f[/latex]) and vapour ([latex]v_g[/latex]) phases, as well as values of saturation temperatures, are given below At the end of the process, which one of the following situations will be true?
solution: Mass of liquid, [latex] m_{f}=1 \mathrm{kg}[/latex] Mass of vapor, [latex] m_{g}=0.3 \mathrm{kg}[/latex] Total mass in system, [latex] \begin{aligned} m &=m_{f}+m_{g}=1+0.03 \\ &=1.03 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Dryness fraction, [latex] \begin{aligned} x=\frac{m_{g}}{m}&=\frac{0.03}{1.03}=0.029\\ \text{At}\quad p_{1} &=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ v_{f} &=0.001 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \\ m_{g} &=0.1 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] \therefore Specific volume [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{1} &=v_{f}+x\left(v_{g}-v_{f}\right) \\ &=0.001+0.029(0.1-0.001) \\ &=0.0038 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] As pressure increases from 100kPa to 200 kpa at constant temperature (quasi-static), volume increases by 50% [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{i.e., }\quad v_{2}&=1.5 v_{1}=1.5 \times 0.0038 \\ &=0.0057 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] As [latex]\quad v_{2}=v_{g, 200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}},[/latex] the steam is superheated vapor in the system

options.A: superheated vapour will be left in the system
options.B: no vapour will be left in the system
options.C: a liquid + vapour mixture will be left in the system
options.D: the mixture will exist at a dry saturate vapour state

question: Question 165 In a steady state flow process taking place in a device with a single inlet and a single outlet, the work done per unit mass flow rate is given by [latex]w=-\int_{inlet}^{outlet}vdp[/latex] , where v is the specific volume and p is the pressure. The expression for w given above
solution:
The expression, [latex] W=-\int_{\text {inlet }}^{\text {outlet }} v d p [/latex] is valid for
reversible process

options.A: is valid only if the process is both reversible and isothermal
options.B: is valid only if the process is both reversible and adiabatic
options.C: is valid for any reversible process

question:
Question 166 A thermal power plant operates on a regenerative cycle with a single open feed water heater, as
shown in the figure. For the state points shown, the specific enthalpies are: [latex]h_1[/latex]=2800 kJ/kg and
[latex]h_2[/latex] = 200 kJ/kg. The bleed to the feed water heater is 20% of the boiler steam generation rate. The
specific enthalpy at state 3 is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{1}&=2800 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{2}&=200 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using energy balance equation for open feedwater heater [latex] \begin{aligned} m h_{3} &=0.2 m h_{1}+0.8 m h_{2} \\ \text{or}\quad h_{3} &=0.2 h_{1}+0.8 h_{2} \\ &=0.2 \times 2800+0.8 \times 200 \\ &=560+160 \\ &=720 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 167 A rigid, insulated tank is initially evacuated. The tank is connected with a supply line through
which air (assumed to be ideal gas with constant specific heats) passes at 1 MPa, 350[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C . A valve
connected with the supply line is opened and the tank is charged with air until the final pressure
inside the tank reaches 1 MPa. The final temperature inside the tank
solution: Applying unsteady flow energy equation, [latex] \begin{array}{c} Q=m_{2} u_{2}-m_{1} u_{1}+m_{e}\left(h_{e}+\frac{v_{e}^{2}}{2}+g z_{e}\right) \\ m_{i}\left(h_{i}+\frac{V_{i}^{2}}{2}+g z_{i}\right)+W \end{array}[/latex] For given problem, [latex] m_{1}=0 \quad \text{evacuated tank}[/latex] [latex] m_{e}=0 \quad \text{no exit}[/latex] [latex] V_{i} [/latex] is neglected [latex] z_{i}=0 ; \quad Q=0 ; \quad W=0[/latex] Above Eq. (i) becomes [latex] \begin{aligned} 0 &=m_{2} u_{2}-m_{i} h_{i} \\ \text{or}\quad m_{i} h_{i} &=m_{2} u_{2}\\ h_{i} &=u_{2} \qquad \because m_{i}=m_{2}\\ c_{p} T_{i} &=c_{v} T_{2} \\ \frac{c_{p}}{c_{v}} T_{i} &=T_{2} \\ \gamma T_{i} &=T_{2} \\ \text{or}\quad T_{2}&=\gamma T_{i} \qquad \text{where}\;\gamma=\frac{c_{p}}{c_{v}}\\ &=1.4 \times 623 \mathrm{K} \\ &=872.3 \mathrm{K}=599.2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] The final temperature, [latex]T_{2}=599.2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] inside to tank is greater than [latex]350^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]

options.D: may be greater than, less than, or equal to 350[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C, depending on the volume of the tank

question:
Question 168 A balloon containing an ideal gas is initially kept in an evacuated and insulated room. The balloon
ruptures and the gas fills up the entire room. Which one of the following statements is TRUE at the
end of above process?
solution: The balloon ruptures in an evacuated and insulated  room, the gas fills up the entire room. This case  related to free expansion. [latex] i.e.,\delta Q=0, \quad \delta W=0[/latex] According to first law of thermodynamics, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta Q &=d U+\delta W \\ 0 &=d U+0 \\ d U &=0 \\ U_{2}-U_{1} &=0 \\ U_{2} &=U_{1} \\ m c_{v} T_{2} &=m c_{v} T_{1}\\ \text{or }\quad m c_{p} T_{2} &=m c_{p} T_{1} \\ H_{2} &=H_{1}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] For free expansion of an ideal gas, both internal energy and enthalpy of the gas remain constant.

options.A: The internal energy of the gas decreases from its initial value, but the enthalpy remains constant
options.B: The internal energy of the gas increases from its initial value, but the enthalpy remains constant
options.C: Both internal energy and enthalpy of the gas remain constant
options.D: Both internal energy and enthalpy of the gas increase

question:
Question 169 A cyclic device operates between three thermal reservoirs, as shown in the figure. Heat is
transferred to/from the cyclic device. It is assumed that heat transfer between each thermal
reservoir and the cyclic device takes place across negligible temperature difference. Interactions
between the cyclic device and the respective thermal reservoirs that are shown in the figure are all
in the form of heat transfer. The cyclic device can be
solution: According to Clausius's inequality, [latex] \begin{aligned} \oint \frac{\delta Q}{T} & \leq 0 \\ \frac{100}{1000}+\frac{50}{500}-\frac{60}{300} & \leq 0 \\ 0.1+0.1-0.2 &=0 \\ 0 &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, the cyclic device can be a reversible heat engine.

options.B: a reversible heat pump or a reversible refrigerator
options.D: an irreversible heat pump or an irreversible refrigerator

question:
Question 170 A gas expands in a frictionless piston-cylinder arrangement. The expansion process is very slow,
and is resisted by an ambient pressure of 100kPa. During the expansion process, the pressure of
the system (gas) remains constant at 300kPa. The change in volume of the gas is 0.01[latex]m^3[/latex]. The
maximum amount of work that could be utilized from the above process is
solution: Given data: Pressure of gas in a cylinder [latex] p=300 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Ambient pressure, [latex] p_{\mathrm{atm}}=100 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Change in volume, [latex] d V=0.01 \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Maximum amount of work, [latex] \begin{aligned} W_{\max } &=\left(p-p_{\mathrm{atm}}\right) d V \\ &=(300-100) \times 0.01 \\ &=2 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 171 Which one of the following is NOT a necessary assumption for the air-standard Otto cycle?
solution: Assumption of air-standard Otto cycle 1. All process are both internally as well as externally reversible. 2. Air behaves as ideal gas. 3. Specific heat remains constant. 4. Intake process is constant volume heat addition process and exhaust process is constant volume heat rejection process.

options.A: All processes are both internally as well as externally reversible.
options.B: Intake and exhaust processes are constant volume heat rejection processes.
options.C: The combustion process is a constant volume heat addition process.
options.D: The working fluid is an ideal gas with constant specific heats.

question:
Question 172 2 moles of oxygen are mixed adiabatically with another 2 moles of oxygen in mixing chamber, so
that the final total pressure and temperature of the mixture become same as those of the
individual constituents at their initial states. The universal gas constant is given as R. The change
in entropy due to mixing, per mole of oxygen, is given by
solution: [latex]d S \geq \frac{\delta Q}{T}[/latex] since process is adiabatic [latex](\delta Q=0)[/latex], entropy change will be zero.

question:
Question 173 A thermodynamic cycle with an ideal gas as working fluid is shown below. If the specific heats of the working fluid are constant and the value of specific heat ratio [latex]\gamma[/latex]
 is 1.4, the thermal efficiency (%) of the cycle is
solution: the The given cycle is Lenoir cycle for which efficiency is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta&=1-\frac{\gamma\left(r_{p}^{1 / \gamma}-1\right)}{r_{p}-1}\\ \text{where }\quad \gamma&=1.4 \\ r_{p} &=\frac{p_{3}}{p_{2}}=\frac{400}{100}=4 \\ \therefore \quad \eta &=1-\frac{1.4\left(\frac{4 \sqrt{1.4}}{4-1}\right)}{4-1} \\ &=21.05 \% \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively Process 2-3 [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{23} &=\left(U_{3}-U_{2}\right)+W_{2-3} \\ Q_{23} &=\left(U_{3}-U_{2}\right)+0 \\ &=m_{v}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right) \\ &=m_{v}\left(\frac{p_{3} V_{3}}{m R}-\frac{p_{2} V_{2}}{m R}\right) \\ &=\frac{c_{v}}{R}\left(p_{3} v_{3}-p_{2} V_{2}\right) \\ &=\frac{c_{v}}{c_{p}-c_{v}}(400 \times 1-100 \times 1) \\ Q_{23} &=\frac{1}{\gamma-1}(400-100) \\ &=\frac{300}{1.4-1}=\frac{300}{0.4}=750 \mathrm{kJ} \\ Q_{1-2} = & \left(U_{2}-U_{1}\right)+W_{1-2} \\ & =m_{0}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right)+p\left(V_{2}-V_{1}\right) \\ & =m_{0}\left[\frac{p_{2} V_{2}}{m R}-\frac{p_{1} V_{1}}{m R}\right]+p\left(V_{2}-V_{1}\right)\\ &=\frac{c_{v}}{R}\left[p\left(V_{2}-V_{1}\right)\right]+p\left(V_{2}-V_{1}\right) \\ &=p\left(V_{2}-v_{1}\right)\left\{\frac{c_{v}}{R}+1\right\} \\ &\qquad \because V_{2}=1 \mathrm{m}^{3}\\ &=p\left(1-v_{1}\right)\left\{\frac{c_{v}}{c_{p}-c_{v}}+1\right\} \\ &=100\left(1-V_{1}\right)\left\{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}+1\right\} \end{aligned}[/latex] Calculating [latex]V_{1}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{3} V_{3}^{\gamma} &=P_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma} \\ \therefore \quad V_{1} &=\left[\frac{P_{3} \cdot V_{3}^{\gamma}}{P_{1}}\right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma}} \\ &=\left[\frac{400}{100} \times 1\right]^{\frac{1}{1.4}}=2.692 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ Q_{1-2} &\left.=100[1-2.692] \times\left\{\frac{1}{0.4}+1\right\}\right\} \\ &=-592.2 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex] (minus sign represent heat is rejected) There is no heat transfer in process 3-1 as it is reversible adiabatic process. Efficiency of cycle, [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta &=1-\frac{Q_{\text {reject }}}{Q_{\text {added }}}=1-\frac{592.2}{750} \\ &=0.2104=21.04 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]
