question: Question 175 Which combination of the following statements is correct? The incorporation of reheater in a steam power plant: P: always increases the thermal efficiency of the plant. Q: always increases the dryness fraction of steam at condenser inlet. R: always increases the mean temperature of heat addition. S: always increases the specific work output.
solution: We know, dryness fraction or quality of the liquid vapour mixture, [latex]x=\frac{m_v}{m_v+m_l}=\frac{1}{1+m_l/m_v}\;\;\;\;...(i)[/latex] Where, [latex]m_v\rightarrow[/latex]  Mass of vapour and [latex]m_l\rightarrow[/latex]  Mass of liquid The value of [latex]x[/latex] varies between 0 to 1. Now from equation (i) if incorporation of reheater in a steam power plant adopted then Mass of vapour [latex]m_v[/latex] increase and Mass of liquid [latex]m_l[/latex] decreases So, dryness fraction [latex]x[/latex] increases. In practice the use of reheater only gives a small increase in cycle efficiency, but it increases the net work output by making possible the use of higher pressure.

question: Question 176 A heat transformer is a device that transfers a part of the heat, supplied to it at an intermediate temperature, to a high temperature reservoir while rejecting the remaining part to a low temperature heat sink.  In such a heat transformer, 100 kJ of heat is supplied at 350 K. The maximum amount of heat in kJ that can be transferred to 400 K, when the rest is rejected to a heat sink at 300 K is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{1}+Q_{2} &=100 \mathrm{kJ} \\ T &=350 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{1} &=400 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{2} &=300 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Entropy change of the heat temperature device: [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S &=-\frac{\left(Q_{1}+Q_{2}\right)}{350}=-\frac{100}{350} \\ &=-\frac{2}{7} \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Entropy change of reservoir- 1 [latex] \Delta S_{1}=\frac{Q_{2}}{T_{2}}=\frac{100-Q_{1}}{300} \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K}[/latex] Entropy change of reservoir- 2 [latex] \Delta S_{2}=\frac{Q_{1}}{T_{1}}=\frac{Q_{1}}{400} \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K}[/latex] Total entropy [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S_{\text {total }} &=0 \\ \Delta S+\Delta S_{1}+\Delta S_{2} &=0 \\ -\frac{2}{7}+\frac{100-Q_{1}}{300}+\frac{Q_{1}}{400} &=0 \\ -\frac{2}{7}+\frac{1}{3}-\frac{Q_{1}}{300}+\frac{Q_{1}}{400} &=0 \\ -\frac{400 Q_{1}+300 Q_{1}}{120000}=\frac{2}{7}-\frac{1}{3} &=\frac{6-7}{21}=-\frac{1}{21} \\ -\frac{100 Q_{1}}{120000} &=-\frac{1}{21} \\ \text{or } \qquad Q_{1} &=57.14 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 177 The stroke and bore of a four stroke spark ignition engine are 250 mm and 200 mm respectively. The clearance volume is 0.001 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]. If the specific heat ratio [latex]\gamma = 1.4[/latex],
 the air-standard cycle efficiency of the engine is
solution: Stroke length, [latex] \begin{aligned} l &=250 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text{Bore dia:}\quad d &=200 \mathrm{mm}=0.2 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Clearance volume, [latex] \begin{array}{c} V_{c}=0.001 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \gamma=1.4 \end{array}[/latex] Displacement volume, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{s} &=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} \times l=\frac{3.14}{4} \times(2)^{2} \times 0.25 \\ &=7.85 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total volume in the cylinder, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1} &=V_{c}+V_{s} \\ &=0.001+7.83 \times 10^{-3} \\ &=8.85 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Compression ratio, [latex] r=\frac{V_{1}}{V_{c}}=\frac{8.85 \times 10^{-3}}{0.001}=8.85[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Air-standard cycle efficiency, [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta &=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}=1-\frac{1}{(8.85)^{1.4-1}} \\ &=1-\frac{1}{8.85^{0.4}} \\ &=0.5819 \approx 58.2 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 178 Water has a critical specific volume of 0.003155 [latex]m^3[/latex]/kg. A closed and rigid steel tank of volume 0.025 [latex]m^3[/latex] contains a mixture of water and steam at 0.1 MPa. The mass of the mixture is 10 kg. The tank is now slowly heated. The liquid level inside the tank
solution: Given data: Critical specific volume of water [latex] v_{c}=0.003155 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] Volume of steel tank, [latex] V=0.025 \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Pressure of mixture of water and steam, [latex] p=0.1 \mathrm{MPa}=1 \mathrm{bar}[/latex] Mass of mixture of water and steam, [latex] m=10 \mathrm{kg}[/latex] Specific volume of mixture, [latex] \begin{aligned} v &=\frac{V}{m}=\frac{0.025}{10} \\ &=0.0025 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] As [latex] v \lt v_{c^{\prime}} [/latex] the condition of steam lies near to  saturated liquid line and the liquid level inside the tank will rise with heating.

options.D: may rise or fall depending on the amount of heat transferred

question: Question 179 Which of the following relationships is valid only for reversible processes undergone by a closed system of simple compressible substance (neglect changes in kinetic and potential energy)?
solution: [latex]\delta Q=d U+p d V[/latex] This equation holds good for a closed system when only pdV work is present. This is true only for a reversible (quasistatic) process.

question: Question 180 A football was inflated to a gauge pressure of 1 bar when the ambient temperature was 15[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. When the game started next day, the air temperature at the stadium was 5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Assume that the volume of the football remains constant at 2500 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] Gauge pressure of air to which the ball must have been originally inflated so that it would equal 1 bar gauge at the stadium is:
solution: [latex]\text { If } \quad p_{G 1}=1 \text { bar }=100 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Absolute pressure, [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1} &=p_{\mathrm{G} 1}+p_{\mathrm{atm}} \\ &=100+101.325 \\ &=201.325 \mathrm{kPa} \\ T_{1} &=278 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{2} &=288 \mathrm{K} \\ \text{At }V=C\\ \frac{p_{2}}{T_{2}} &=\frac{p_{1}}{T_{1}} \\ \frac{p_{2}}{288} &=\frac{201.325}{278}\\ \text{or}\quad p_{2}&=208.56 \mathrm{kPa}\\ \text{also}\quad  p_{2} &=p_{G 2}+p_{\text {atm }} \\ \therefore \quad 208.56 &=p_{G 2}+101.325 \\ \text{or}\quad p_{G 2} &=107.235 \mathrm{kPa} \\ &=1.07 \mathrm{bar} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 181 A football was inflated to a gauge pressure of 1 bar when the ambient temperature was 15[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. When the game started next day, the air temperature at the stadium was 5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Assume that the volume of the football remains constant at 2500 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] The amount of heat lost by the air in the football and the gauge pressure of air in the football at the stadium respectively equal
solution: Given data: Gauge pressure, [latex] p_{G 1}=1 \text { bar }=100 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Ambient temperature, [latex] T_{1}=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(15+273) \mathrm{K}=288 \mathrm{K}[/latex] Absolute pressure, [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1} &=p_{G 1}+p_{\text {atm }} \\ &=100+101.325 \\ &=201.325 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \text{Volume}\;V &=2500 \mathrm{cm}^{3}=2500 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Temperature, [latex] T_{2}=5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(5+273) \mathrm{K}=278 \mathrm{K}[/latex] From equation equation of state, [latex] p_{1} V_{1}=m R T_{1} [/latex] [latex] 201.325\times 2500 \times 10^{-6}=m \times 0.287 \times 288[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{or}\quad m &=6.089 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{kg} \\ \text{Heat loss: }Q&=\mathrm{mc}_{\mathrm{v}}\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right) \\ &=6.089 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.718 \times(288-278) \\ &=0.0437 \mathrm{kJ}=43.7 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}[/latex] At V=C [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{1}}{T_{1}} &=\frac{p_{2}}{T_{2}} \\ \frac{201.325}{288} &=\frac{p_{2}}{278}\\ \text{or }\quad p_{2}&=194.33 \mathrm{kPa} \quad (absolute)\\ \text { also } \quad p_{2}&=p_{G 2}+p_{\text {atm }}\\ \therefore 194.33&=p_{G 2}+101.325\\ \text{or}\quad p_{G z}&=93 \mathrm{kPa}=0.93 \mathrm{bar}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{2} V&=m R T_{2} \\ p_{2} &\times 2500 \times 10^{-6}=6.089 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.287 \times 278\\ \text{or}\quad p_{2}&=194.32 \mathrm{kPa} \quad (absolute)\\ \text { also } \quad p_{2} &=p_{G 2}+p_{\text {atm }} \\ \therefore \quad 194.32 &=p_{G 2}+101.325 \\ \text{or}\quad p_{G 2} &=92.99 \mathrm{kPa} \\ & \approx 93 \mathrm{kPa}=0.93 \mathrm{bar} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 182 Group I shows different heat addition processes in power cycles. Likewise, Group II shows different heat removal processes. Group III lists power cycles. Match items from Groups I, II and III.
solution: Rankine cycle- Constant pressure heat addition. Constant pressure heat rejection. Otto cycle - Constant volume heat addition. Constant volume heat rejection. Carnot cycle - Constant temperature heat addition. Constant temperature heat rejection. Diesel cycle - Constant pressure heat addition. Constant volume heat rejection. Brayton cycle - Constant pressure heat addition. Constant pressure heat rejection.

question: Question 183 Match items from groups I, II, III, IV and V.

options.A: F - G -J -K - M   E - G -I - K-N
options.B: E - G -I -K - M   F - H -I - K-N
options.C: F - H -J -L - N   E - H -I - L-M
options.D: E - G -J -K - N   F - H -J - K-M

question: Question 184 Determine the correctness or otherwise of the following Assertion [a] and the Reason [r]. Assertion [a]: Condenser is an essential equipment in a steam power plant. Reason [r]: For the same mass flow rate and the same pressure rise, a water pump requires substantially less power than a steam compressor.
solution: Condenser is an essential equipment in a steam  power plant because it is not economical to feed   steam directly to the boiler.  For same mass flow rate and the same pressure rise, a water pump require very less power   because the specific volume of liquid is very less  as compare to specific volume of vapour.

options.A: Both [a] and [r] are true and [r] is the correct reason for [a].
options.B: Both [a] and [r] are true but [r] is NOT the correct reason for [a}

question: Question 185 Determine the correctness or otherwise of the following Assertion [a] and the Reason [r]. Assertion [a]: In a power plant working on a Ranking cycle, the regenerative feed water heating improves the efficiency of the steam turbine. Reason [r]: The regenerative feed water heating raises the average temperature of heat addition in the Rankine cycle.
solution: In order to reduce the external thermal irreversibility, increase in the mean temperature  of heat addition is required. Mean temperature of heat addition can also be increased by reducing the amount of heat added at low temperature in  liquid phase i.e., why regenerative feed water  heater are required.

options.A: Both [a] and [r] are true and [r] is the correct reason for [a].
options.B: Both [a] and [r] are true but [r] is NOT the correct reason for [a].

question: Question 186 Given below is an extract from steam tables. Specific enthalpy of water in kJ/kg at 150 bar and 45 [latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{3}&=150 \mathrm{bar}=p_{2} \\ T_{3}&=45^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] At saturated point 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{2}&=150 \mathrm{bar} \\ T_{2}&=T_{\mathrm{sat}}=342.24^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] At saturated point 1 [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1}&=0.09594 \text { bar } \\ T_{1}&=T_{3}=45^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] As [latex]T_{3} \lt T_{2},[/latex] the given condition of water is subcooled liquid. and [latex]\quad T_{3}=T_{1}=45^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] The specific enthalpy at point [latex]3\approx[/latex] the specific enthalpy at saturated liquid point 1 [latex] h_{3}=h_{1}=188.45 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex]

question: Question 187 The following table of properties was printed out for saturated liquid and saturated vapour of ammonia. The titles for only the first two columns are available. All that we know is that the other columns (columns 3 to 8) contain data on specific properties, namely, internal energy (kJ/kg), enthalpy (kJ/kg) and entropy (kJ/kg.K). When saturated liquid at 40[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is throttled to -20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C, the quality at exit will be
solution: For throttling process, Enthalpy of state 1= Enthalpy at state 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Where } h_{1}&=h_{2} \\ h_{1}&=h_{f}=371.43 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \text { at } 40^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ h_{2}&=h_{f}+x_{2}\left(h_{g}-h_{f}\right) \text { at } 20^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ h_{2}&=89.05+x_{2}(1418-89.05) \\ h_{2}&=89.05+1328.95 x_{2} \\ \text { also}\quad h_{2}&=h_{1} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore\;\;  89.05+1328.95x_{2}= 371.43[/latex] [latex] \text{or}\quad x_{2}=0.212[/latex]

question: Question 188 The following table of properties was printed out for saturated liquid and saturated vapour of ammonia. The titles for only the first two columns are available. All that we know is that the other columns (columns 3 to 8) contain data on specific properties, namely, internal energy (kJ/kg), enthalpy (kJ/kg) and entropy (kJ/kg.K). The specific enthalpy data are in columns
solution:

h=u+p v[/latex] i.e.,  [latex]h \gt u[/latex] and the value of entropy is less than u.

question:
Question 189 In two air standard cycles - one operating on the Otto and the other on the Brayton cycle - air is isentropically compressed from 300 to 450 K. heat is added to raise the temperature to 600 K in the Otto cycle and to 550 K in the Brayton cycle. If [latex]W_{O}[/latex]
 and [latex]W_{B}[/latex]
 are work outputs per unit mass, then
solution: For Otto cycle [latex] \begin{array}{l} T_{1}=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{2}=450 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{3}=600 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex] For process 1-2, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}&=\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma-1}\\ \text{or}\quad \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}} &=\left(\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}}=\left(\frac{450}{300}\right)^{\frac{1}{1.4-1}} \\ &=(1.25)^{2.5}=2.75 \end{aligned}[/latex] i.e., Compression ratio [latex]\begin{aligned} r&=\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}=2.75\\ \therefore \quad \eta_{\text {Otto }} &=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}=1-\frac{1}{(2.75)^{1.4-1}} \\ &=1-0.667=0.33=33 \% \end{aligned}\\ \text{For Brayton cycle}\\ \begin{aligned} T_{1}&=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{2}=450 \mathrm{K}\\ T_{3}&=550 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] For Brayton cycle [latex] T_{1}=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{2}=450 \mathrm{K}\\ T_{3}=550 \mathrm{K}[/latex] For process 1-2 Pressure ratio [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{p} &=\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}} \\ \eta_{\text {Brayton }} &=1-\frac{1}{\left(r_{p}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}} \\ &=1-\frac{1}{\left[\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}}\right]^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}} \\ &=1-\frac{1}{T_{1} / T_{2}}=1-\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=1-\frac{300}{450} \\ &=0.33=33 \% \\ \text { Thus, } \eta_{\text {Otto }} &=\eta_{\text {Brajton }}=0.33 \end{aligned}[/latex] Calculating work output in Otto and Brayton cycle [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { also } \eta_{\text {otto }}&=\frac{\text { Work output : } W_{\text {Otto }}}{\text { Heat supplied : } Q_{1}} \\ 0.33&=\frac{W_{\text {Otto }}}{Q_{1}} \\ \text{or}\quad W_{\text {Otto }}&=0.33 Q_{1}\\ &=0.33 \times c_{v}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right) \\ &=35.54 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \eta_{\mathrm{Braton}} &=\frac{\text { Work output }: \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{B}}}{\text { Heat supplied }} \\ 0.33 &=\frac{W_{\mathrm{B}}}{Q_{1}} \\ \text{or}\quad W_{B} &=0.33 Q_{1}\\ &=0.33 \times c_{p}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right)\\ &=0.33 \times 1.005(530-450) \\ &=31.165 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence work output per unit mass of the Otto cycle is more than the work output per unit mass of the Brayton cycle.

options.D: it is not possible to calculate the work outputs unless the temperature after the expansion is given.

question:
Question 190 In two air standard cycles - one operating on the Otto and the other on the Brayton cycle - air is isentropically compressed from 300 to 450 K. heat is added to raise the temperature to 600 K in the Otto cycle and to 550 K in the Brayton cycle. If [latex]\eta _{O}[/latex]
 and [latex]\eta _{B}[/latex]
 are the efficiencies of the Otto and Brayton cycles, then
solution: For Otto cycle [latex] \begin{array}{l} T_{1}=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{2}=450 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{3}=600 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex] For process 1-2, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}&=\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma-1}\\ \text{or}\quad \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}} &=\left(\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}}=\left(\frac{450}{300}\right)^{\frac{1}{1.4-1}} \\ &=(1.25)^{2.5}=2.75 \end{aligned}[/latex] i.e., Compression ratio [latex]\begin{aligned} r&=\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}=2.75\\ \therefore \quad \eta_{\text {Otto }} &=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}=1-\frac{1}{(2.75)^{1.4-1}} \\ &=1-0.667=0.33=33 \% \end{aligned}\\ For Brayton cycle\\ \begin{aligned} T_{1}&=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{2}=450 \mathrm{K}\\ T_{3}&=550 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] For Brayton cycle [latex] T_{1}=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{2}=450 \mathrm{K}\\ T_{3}=550 \mathrm{K}[/latex] For process 1-2 Pressure ratio [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{p} &=\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}} \\ \eta_{\text {Brayton }} &=1-\frac{1}{\left(r_{p}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}} \\ &=1-\frac{1}{\left[\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}}\right]^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}}} \\ &=1-\frac{1}{T_{1} / T_{2}}=1-\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=1-\frac{300}{450} \\ &=0.33=33 \% \\ \text { Thus, } \eta_{\text {Otto }} &=\eta_{\text {Brajton }}=0.33 \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.D: it is not possible to calculate the efficiencies unless the temperature after the expansion is given.

question:
Question 192 Nitrogen at an initial state of 10 bar, 1 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]
 and 300 K is expanded isothermally to a final volume of 2[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The p-v-T relation is [latex]\left ( p+\frac{a}{v^{2}} \right )v= RT[/latex]
 where a [latex]\gt[/latex] 0. The final pressure
solution: Given : [latex]p_1=10 \text{ bar}, v_1=1m^3, T_1=300K, v_2=2m^3[/latex] Given that Nitrogen Expanded isothermally. So,                 RT = Constant and from given relation, [latex]\begin{aligned} \left ( p+\frac{a}{v^2} \right )v &=RT=\text{Constant} \\ p_1v_1+\frac{a}{v_1} &=p_2v_2+\frac{a}{v_2} \\ p_2v_2&=p_1v_1+\frac{a}{v_1}-\frac{a}{v_2} \\ p_2 &=p_1\left ( \frac{v_1}{v_2} \right )+a\left ( \frac{1}{v_1v_2}-\frac{1}{v_2^2} \right ) \\ &= 10\left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )+a\left ( \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4} \right )=5+\frac{a}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] Here, [latex]a\gt 0[/latex], so above equation shows that [latex]p_2[/latex] is greater than 5 and +ve.

options.A: will be slightly less than 5 bar
options.B: will be slightly more than 5 bar
options.D: cannot be ascertained in the absence of the value of a

question:
Question 196 Consider a steam power plant using a reheat cycle as shown. Steam leaves the boiler and enters the turbine at 4 MPa, [latex]350^{\circ}C[/latex]
 ([latex]h_{3}[/latex]
 = 3095 kJ/kg). After expansion in the turbine to 400 kPa ([latex]h_{4}[/latex]
 = 2609 kJ/kg), the steam is reheated to [latex]350^{\circ}C[/latex]
 ([latex]h_{5}[/latex]
 = 3170 kJ/kg), and then expanded in a low pressure turbine to 10 kPa ([latex]h_{6}[/latex]
 = 2165 kJ/kg). The specific volume of liquid handled by the pump can be assumed to be The enthalpy at the pump discharge ([latex]h_{2}[/latex]
) is
solution: Enthalpy at exit of pump must be greater than  enthalpy at inlet of pump i.e. [latex] h_{2} [/latex] must be greater then   [latex] h_{1}=29.3 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}. [/latex] Among the given four  options only one option is greater than [latex] h_{1}=29.3 [/latex] kJ/kg. Which is 33.3 kJ/kg. Hence option (D) is correct

question:
Question 197 Consider a steam power plant using a reheat cycle as shown. Steam leaves the boiler and enters the turbine at 4 MPa, [latex]350^{\circ}C[/latex]
 ([latex]h_{3}[/latex]
 = 3095 kJ/kg). After expansion in the turbine to 400 kPa ([latex]h_{4}[/latex]
 = 2609 kJ/kg), the steam is reheated to [latex]350^{\circ}C[/latex]
 ([latex]h_{5}[/latex]
 = 3170 kJ/kg), and then expanded in a low pressure turbine to 10 kPa ([latex]h_{6}[/latex]
 = 2165 kJ/kg). The specific volume of liquid handled by the pump can be assumed to be The thermal efficiency of the plant neglecting pump work is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{l} h_{3}=3095 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} ; \quad h_{4}=2604 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{5}=3170 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} ; \quad h_{6}=2165 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{g} \\ h_{1}=29.3 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{array}[/latex] Network output per kg [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{\text {net }} &=\left(h_{3}-h_{4}\right)+\left(h_{5}-h_{6}\right) \\ &=(3095-2609)+(3170-2165) \\ &=1491 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net heat supplied, [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{s} &=\left(h_{3}-h_{2}\right)+\left(h_{5}-h_{4}\right) \\ &=h_{3}-h_{1}+h_{5}-h_{4} \quad \because h_{2} \approx h \\ &=3095-29.3+3170-2609 \\ &=3626.7 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thermal efficiency, [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta &=\frac{w_{\mathrm{net}}}{q_{\mathrm{s}}}=\frac{1491}{3626.7} \\ &=0.4111=41.11 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 198 An engine working on air standard Otto cycle has a cylinder diameter of 10 cm and stroke length of 15 cm. The ratio of specific heats for air is 1.4. If the clearance volume is 196.3 cc and the heat supplied per kg of air per cycle is 1800 kJ/kg, the work output per cycle per kg of air is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{l} d=10 \mathrm{cm} ; \quad l=15 \mathrm{cm} ; \quad \gamma=1.4 \\ V_{c}=196.3 \mathrm{cc}=196.3 \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ q_{s}=1800 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{array}[/latex] Swept volume, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{s} &=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} l=\frac{3.14}{4}(10)^{2} \times 15 \\ &=1177.5 \mathrm{cm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Compression ratio, [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\frac{V_{1}}{V_{c}}=\frac{V_{c}+V_{s}}{V_{c}} \\ &=\frac{196.3-1177.5}{196.3}=6.99 \\ \eta_{\text {Otto }} &=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}=1-\frac{1}{(6.99)^{1.4-1}} \\ &=1-0.4594=0.5406 \\ \text { also } \quad \eta_{\text {Otto }} &=\frac{w}{q_{s}} \\ \therefore \quad 0.5406 &=\frac{w}{1800}\\ \text{or}\quad w&=973.08 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 199 During a Morse test on a 4 cylinder engine, the following measurements of brake power were taken at constant speed. The mechanical efficiency of the engine is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { (B.P.) }_{1,2,3,4}=3037 \mathrm{kW} \\ \left(1 . P_{1}\right)_{1,2,3,4}=(\mathrm{B.P.})_{1,2,3,4}+(\mathrm{F.P.})_{1,2,3,4} \ldots \text { (i) } \end{array}[/latex] Number 1 cylinder not firing, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \left(B . P_{2,3,4}=2102 \mathrm{kW}\right. \\ (1.P) _{2,3,4}=(\mathrm{B.P.})_{2,3,4}+(\mathrm{F.P.})_{1,2,3,4}\quad \cdots(ii)\\ \end{array}[/latex] Eq. (ii) - Eq. (i), we get [latex] \begin{array}{l} \left(I.P)_{1,2,3,4}-\left(1 . P_{1}\right)_{2,3,4}=\left(B . P\right)_{1,2,3,4}+\left(B . P\right)_{1,2,3,4}\right. \\ (1 . P .)_{1}=3037-2102=935 \mathrm{kW} \\ \end{array}[/latex] similarly, number 2 cylinder not firing, [latex] \begin{aligned} (B . P .)_{1,3,4}&=2102 \mathrm{kW}\\ \therefore \quad (\mathrm{l} . \mathrm{P.})_{2} &=(\mathrm{B.P.})_{1,2,3,4}-(\mathrm{B} . \mathrm{P.})_{1,3,4} \\ &=3037-2102=935 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Number 3 cylinder not firing, [latex] \begin{aligned} (\mathrm{B.P})_{1,2,4} &=2100 \mathrm{kW} \\ \therefore \quad (\mathrm{l.P.})_{3} &=(\mathrm{B.P.})_{1,2,3,4}-(\mathrm{B.P.})_{1,2,4} \\ &=3037-2100=937 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Number 4 cylinder not firing, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { (B.P.) }_{1,2,3}&=2098 \mathrm{kW}\\ \therefore \quad (I.P.)_{4}&=(\mathrm{B} . \mathrm{P.})_{1,2,3,4}-(\mathrm{B.P.})_{1,2,3}\\ &=3037-2098=939 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total I.P. [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(I.P.\right)_{1,2,3,4} &=(1 . P .)_{1}+(1 . P .)_{2}+(1 . P .)_{3}+(1 . P .)_{1} \\ &=935+935+937+939 \\ &=3746 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}\\ Mechanical efficiency,\\ \begin{aligned} \eta_{m}&=\frac{(\mathrm{B} \cdot \mathrm{P} \cdot)_{1,2,3,4}}{(\mathrm{I} \cdot \mathrm{P} \cdot)_{1,2,3,4}}=\frac{3037}{3746} \\ &=0.8107=81.07 \%\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 200 A steel billet of 2000 kg mass is to be cooled from 1250 K to 450 K. The heat released during this process is to be used as a source of energy. The ambient temperature is 303 K and specific heat of steel is 0.5 kJ/kg K. the available energy of this billet is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=m c_{p} \Delta T \\ &=2000 \times(0.5 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK}) \times(1250-450) \\ &=800000 \mathrm{kJ}\\ \Delta S&=m c_{p} \ln \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=2000 \times 0.5 \times \ln \frac{1250}{450}\\ &=1021.165 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K} \\ \text { A.E. } &=Q-T_{0} \Delta S \\ &=490439.67 \mathrm{kJ}=490.44 \mathrm{MJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 201 A solar collector receiving solar radiation at the rate of 0.6 [latex]kW/m^{2}[/latex]
transforms it to the internal energy of a fluid at an overall efficiency of 50%. The fluid heated to 350 K is used to run a heat engine which rejects heat at 313 K. If the heat engine is to deliver 2.5 kW power, the minimum area of the solar collector required would be
solution: Given data: [latex] Q=0.6 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Overall efficiency of the fluid system, [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{\text {fluid }} &=50 \%=0.50 \\ T_{1} &=350 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{2} &=313 \mathrm{K} \\ W &=2.5 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Overall efficiency of the fluid system, [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{\text {fluid }} &=\frac{Q_{1}}{Q} \\ 0.50 &=\frac{Q_{1}}{0.6} \\ \text{or}\qquad Q_{1}&=0.05\times 0.6=0.3 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Let A= Minimum area of the solar collector [latex] \therefore Q_{1}=0.3 \mathrm{A} \mathrm{kW}[/latex] For minimum area of the solar collector, the heat engine is reversible [latex] \therefore [/latex] Thermal efficiency, [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta &=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} \\ &=1-\frac{313}{350}=1-0.895=0.105 \\ \text { also } \quad \eta &=\frac{W}{Q_{1}} \\ \therefore \qquad 0.105 &=\frac{2.5}{0.3 A} \\ A &=79.36 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ & \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 202 The compression ratio of a gas power plant cycle corresponding to maximum work output for the given temperature limits of [latex]T_{min}[/latex]
 and [latex]T_{max}[/latex]
 will be
solution: Work output during the cycle [latex] \begin{aligned} &=m c_{p}\left(T_{3}-T_{2}\right)-m c_{p}\left(T_{4}-T_{1}\right) \\ &=m c_{p}\left(T_{3}-T_{4}\right)-m c_{p}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right) \\ &=m c_{p}\left[T_{3}\left(1-\frac{T_{4}}{T_{3}}\right)-T_{1}\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}-1\right)\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] since [latex] \frac{T_{3}}{T_{4}}=\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=\left(r_{p}\right) \frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma} \quad\left(\text { Let } \frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}=x, m c_{p}=K\right)[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Work/cycle [latex] =K\left[T_{3}\left(1-\frac{1}{r_{p}^{x}}\right)-T_{1}\left(r_{p}^{x}-1\right)\right][/latex] For maximum power, differentiate with respect to [latex]r_{p}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d W}{d r_{p}}&=K\left[T_{3} \times \frac{x}{r_{p}(x+1)}-T_{1} \times r_{p}^{(x-1)}\right]=0 \\ &\qquad (For max.)\\ \Rightarrow \frac{x T_{3}}{r_{p}(x+1)}&=T_{1} \times\left(r_{p}\right)^{x-1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad r_{p}^{2 x}&=\frac{T_{3}}{T_{1}} \\ \therefore \quad r_{p}&=\left(\frac{T_{3}}{T_{1}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2 x}} \\ \text{or }\quad r_{p}&=\left(\frac{T_{\max }}{T_{\min }}\right)^{\frac{\gamma}{2(\gamma-1)}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 203 A gas contained in a cylinder is compressed, the work required for compression being 5000 kJ. During the process, heat interaction of 200 kJ causes the surroundings to the heated. The change in internal energy of the gas during the process is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} W&=-5000 \mathrm{kJ} \\ Q&=-2000 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex] According to first flow for process, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=d U+W \\ -2000 &=d U-5000\\ \text{or}\quad d U&=-2000+5000=+3000 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 205 Nitrogen gas (molecular weight 28) is enclosed in a cylinder by a piston, at the initial condition of 2 bar, 298 K and [latex]m^{3}[/latex]. In a particular process, the gas slowly expands under isothermal condition, until the volume becomes [latex]2m^{3}[/latex]. Heat exchange occurs with the atmosphere at 298 K during this process. The entropy change for universe during the process in kJ/K is
solution:
Given process is isothermal, so change in entropy of universe [latex](dS)_{universe}=(dS)_{system}+(dS)_{surrounding}[/latex] Work done in isothermal process [latex]
\begin{aligned}
 &=P_1V_1 lm(V_2/V_1) \\ 
 &=200 \times 1 ln(2/1) \\ 
 &= 138.62 kJ\\
\delta Q&=dU+\delta W\\
\delta Q&=138.62 kJ\;\;(\because \; dU=0)
\end{aligned}[/latex] Heat taken by sirrounding to the system =138.62 KJ Change in entropy of surrounding [latex]
(dS)_{surr}=\frac{-138.62}{298}=-0.465 kJ/K[/latex] Mass of nitrogen gas [latex]=\frac{PV}{RT}=\frac{200 \times 1 }{\frac{8.314}{28} \times 298}[/latex] [latex]
m=2.26kg[/latex] Change in entropy of system [latex]
\begin{aligned}
 &=mc_v ln\left ( \frac{T_2}{T_1} \right )+mR ln\left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right ) \\ 
 &=mR ln \left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right ) \;\;\because \; T_1=T_2\\ 
 &= 2.26 \times \frac{8.314}{28} ln\left ( \frac{2}{1} \right )\\ 
 &= 0.456kJ/K\\ 
 (dS)_{universe}&=0.465-0.465 \\ 
 &= 0
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Therefore, option (C) is correct.

question: Question 206 Nitrogen gas (molecular weight 28) is enclosed in a cylinder by a piston, at the initial condition of 2 bar, 298 K and 1 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]. In a particular process, the gas slowly expands under isothermal condition, until the volume becomes [latex]2m^{3}[/latex]. Heat exchange occurs with the atmosphere at 298 K during this process. The work interaction for the Nitrogen gas is
solution: For isothermal process [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Work } &=p_{1} V_{1} \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \\ &=\left(2 \times 10^{5}\right) \times(1) \times \ln \frac{2}{1} \\ &=138629.4 \mathrm{J}=138.63 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 207 For an engine operating on air standard Otto cycle, the clearance volume is 10% of the swept volume. The specific heat ratio of air is 1.4. The air standard cycle efficiency is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{c} &=10 \% V_{s}=0.10 V_{s} \\ \frac{V_{s}}{V_{c}} &=\frac{1}{0.10}=10 \\ \gamma &=1.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] Compression ratio, [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\frac{V_{1}}{V_{c}}=\frac{V_{c}+V_{s}}{V_{c}} \\ &=1+\frac{V_{s}}{V_{c}}=1+10=11\\ \eta_{ \mathrm{Otto}} &=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}=1-\frac{1}{11^{1.4-1}} \\ &=1-\frac{1}{11^{0.4}}=1-\frac{1}{2.609} \\ &=1-0.3832=0.6168=61.67 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 208 An automobile engine operates at a fuel air ratio of 0.05, volumetric efficiency of 90% and indicated thermal efficiency of 30%. Given that the calorific value of the fuel is 45 MJ/kg and the density of air at intake is 1 kg/[latex]m^3[/latex] , the indicated mean effective pressure for the engine is
solution: Volumetric efficiency [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\text { actual volume }}{\text { swept volume }}=\frac{V_{a}}{V_{s}}=0.9 \\ \text{or}\qquad V_{a}&=0.9 V_{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Mass of air, [latex] \begin{aligned} m_{a} &=\rho_{\text {air }} V_{a}=0.9 V_{s} \\ m_{f} &=0.05 \times 0.9 V_{s}=0.045 V_{s} \\ \eta_{\text {thermal }} &=\frac{p_{\text {mep }} \times L A}{m_{f} \times C . V} \\ 0.3 &=\frac{p_{m} \times V_{s}}{0.045 V_{s} \times 45 \times 10^{6}} \\ \text{or}\quad p_{m} &=0.6075 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{Pa}\\ &=6.075 bar \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 209 In a gas turbine, hot combustion products with the specific heats [latex]C_{p}[/latex]
 = 0.98 kJ/kgK, and [latex]C_{v}[/latex]
 = 0.7538 kJ/kgK, enter the turbine at 20 bar, 1500K exit at 1 bar. The isentropic efficiency of the turbine is 0.94 .The work developed by the turbine per kg of gas flow is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} c_{p} &=0.98 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ c_{v} &=0.7538 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ p_{1} &=20 \mathrm{bar} \\ T_{1} &=1500 \mathrm{K} \\ p_{2} &=1 \mathrm{bar} \\ \eta_{\mathrm{isen}} &=0.94 \\ \gamma &=\frac{c_{p}}{c_{v}}=\frac{0.98}{0.7538}=1.3 \end{aligned}[/latex] For process 1-2 s [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2 s}} &=\left(\frac{p_{1}}{p_{2}}\right)^{\frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma}} \\ \frac{1500}{T_{2 s}} &=\left(\frac{20}{1}\right)^{\frac{1.3-1}{1.3}}=(20)^{0.2307}=1.996 \\ \text{or}\quad T_{2 s} &=751.50 \mathrm{K} \\ \eta_{\mathrm{isen}} &=\frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{T_{1}-T_{2 s}} \\ 0.94 &=\frac{1500-T_{2}}{1500-751.50} \\ &=\frac{1500-T_{2}}{748.5} \\ \text{or}\quad 1500-T_{2}&=0.94 \times 748.5=703.59 \\ \text{or}\quad T_{2}&=796.41 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned} [/latex] Work developed by the turbine per kg of gas, [latex] \begin{aligned} w &=c_{p}\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right) \\ &=0.98(1500-796.41) \\ &=689.51 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 210 Considering the relationship TdS =dU + pdV  between the entropy (S), internal energy (U), pressure (p), temperature (T) and volume (V), which off the statement is correct .

It is equivalent to [latex]1^{st}[/latex]
 law, for a reversible process

question: Question 212 In a Rankine cycle, regeneration results in higher efficiency because
solution: From the observation of the T-s diagram of the rankine cycle, it reveals that heat is transferred to the working fluid during process 2-2' at a relatively low temperature. This lowers the average heat addition temperature and thus the cycle efficiency. To remove this remedy, we look for the ways to raise the temperature of the liquid leaving the pump (called the feed water ) before it enters the boiler. One possibility is to transfer heat to the feed water from the expanding steam in a counter flow heat exchanger built into the turbine, that is, to use regeneration. A practical regeneration process in steam power plant is accomplished by extracting steam from the turbine at various points. This steam is used to heat the feed water and the device where the feed water is heated by regeneration is called feed water heater. So, regeneration improves cycle efficiency by increasing the average temperature of heat addition in the boiler.

options.B: heat is added before steam enters the low pressure turbine
options.C: average temperature of heat addition in the boiler increases
options.D: total work delivered by the turbine increases

question: Question 213 A diesel engine is usually more efficient than a spark ignition engine because
solution: For same compression ratio and the same heat supplied, Otto cycle is most efficient and diesel cycle is least efficient. In practice, however, the compression ratio of the Diesel engine ranges between 14 and 25 whereas that of the Otto engine between 6 and 12 . Because of its higher efficiency than the Otto engine.

options.A: diesel being a heavier hydrocarbon, releases more heat per kg than gasoline
options.B: the air standard efficiency of diesel cycle is higher than the Otto cycle, at a fixed compression ratio
options.C: the compression ratio of a diesel engine is higher than that of an SI engine
options.D: self ignition temperature of diesel is higher than that of gasoline

question:
Question 214 For a spark ignition engine, the equivalence ratio ([latex]\phi[/latex]
) of mixture entering the combustion chamber has values
solution:

question:
Question 215 A 2 kW, 40 litre water heater is switched on for 20 minutes. The heat capacity [latex]C_{p}[/latex]
 for water is 4.2 kJ/kg K. Assuming all the electrical energy has gone into heating the water, increase of the water temperature in degree centrgrade is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=2 \mathrm{kW} \\ V &=40 \text { litres }=\frac{40}{1000}=0.04 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ t &=20 \mathrm{minutes}=20 \times 60 \mathrm{s} \\ &=1200 \mathrm{s} \\ c_{p} &=4.2 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat supplied: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=\text { Power } \times \text { Time } \\ &=2 \times 1200=2400 \mathrm{kJ} \\ \text { also } \qquad & Q=m c_{p} \Delta T=\rho V c_{p} \Delta T \quad \because m=p V \\ \therefore \qquad 2400 &=1000 \times 0.04 \times 4.2 \times \Delta T \\ \text { or } \qquad \Delta T &=14.28^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \approx 14.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 217 An ideal air standard Otto cycle has a compression ratio of 8.5. If the ratio of the specific heats of air ([latex]\gamma[/latex]) is 1.4, what is the thermal efficiency (in percentage) of the Otto cycle?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=1-\frac{1}{r^{\gamma-1}}=1-\frac{1}{(8.5)^{1.4-1}} \\ &=0.5751=57.51 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 219 In a spark ignition engine working on the ideal Otto cycle, the compression ratio is 5.5. The work output per cycle (i.e., area of the P-V diagram) is equal to [latex]23.625 \times 10^{5} \times V_{c} J[/latex]
, where [latex]V_{c}[/latex]
 is the clearance volume in [latex]m^{3}[/latex]
. The indicated mean effective pressure is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{mep} &=\frac{W}{V_{s}}=\frac{W}{V_{1}-V_{c}} \\ &=\frac{23.625 \times 10^{5} \times V_{c}}{5.5 V_{c}-V_{c}} \\ &=\frac{23.625 \times 10^{5} V_{c}}{4.5 V_{c}}=5.25 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{Pa} \\ &=5.250 \mathrm{bar} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 220 A small steam whistle (perfectly insulated and doing no shaft work) causes a drop of 0.8 kJ/kg in the enthalpy of steam from entry to exit. If the kinetic energy of the steam at entry is negligible, the velocity of the steam at exit is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta h &=-0.8 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{2}-h_{1} &=-0.8 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{1}-h_{2} &=0.8 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying steady flow energy equation, [latex] h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}+g z_{1}+q=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2}+g z_{2}+w[/latex] Assumptions: (i) q=0 adiabatic flow (ii) w=0 (iii) Change k.E. and P.E. are neglect (iv) Neglect inlet velocity. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad h_{1} &=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2} \\ h_{1} &=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2000} \\ h_{1}-h_{2} &=\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2000} \\ \text{or}\qquad 8 &=\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2000} \\ V_{2}^{2} &=1600 \\ \text{or}\qquad V_{2} &=40 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 222 A cyclic heat engine does 50 kJ of work per cycle. If the efficiency of the heat engine is 75%, the heat rejected per cycle is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=\frac{W}{Q} \\ 0.75 &=\frac{50}{Q} \\ Q &=66.67 \\ Q_{R} &=66.67-50=16.67 \mathrm{kJ} \\ &=16 \frac{2}{3} \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]
